PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Security
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Defence Security
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

The undersigned are convinced that an alliance, including full military co-operation, between Australia and the United States is indispensible to the defence security of the Australian Commonwealth; that every alliance involves co-operative arrangements of a practical nature; and that the following arrangements are indispensible to the effective conduct of A.N.Z.U.S. and any similar agreement, to wit; the reception of U.S. naval shipping (nuclear and non-nuclear) in Australian ports; the maintenance of the present U.S. installations in Australia; reasonable co-operation by Australia in U.S. missile testing programs.
Your petitioners, therefore, pray the Senate, in Parliament assembled, that you will give this matter your earnest consideration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows that:
We, the undersigned electors, are deeply concerned at the possibility of an increase in indirect taxation currently being considered by the government.
To pose a broadly based consumption tax would mean a proportionately greater burden on low income groups and worsen their already precarious and impoverished position.

Women who are supporting mothers, together with their children, are acknowledged as the largest single group forced to exist below the poverty line. As beneficiaries of an already inadequate government pension, their futures would be even more jeopardised if there were to be a change towards increased broadly based consumption taxation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government not adopt the proposed shift towards increased indirect taxation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions bring to its notice and due to have effect from 21 March, 1985 the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners, and calls upon the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's bill for the abolition of the Assets Test.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the passage of the Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill to repeal the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Abortion Clinic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we the undersigned, who have great concern for the protection of the unborn child, call upon the Government to reject the Vinson Enquiry recommendation that an Abortion Clinic be established in Canberra.
And your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will reject this recommendation.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we strongly oppose the 'A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Jack Evans, because it will adversely affect sporting organisations and small businesses in the A.C.T., it reverses the onus of proof, and represents an unnecessary intrusion by Government into the private affairs of individuals and other groups.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support 'The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of wide-spread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Additional Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes of death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
They adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
The Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

Any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ''windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
The owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PUBLIC SERVANTS' RIGHTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Public Servants' Rights in relation to Exposing Breaches of the Law, be appointed to inquire into and report upon-
(a) injustices suffered by public servants who seek to expose actions detrimental to Australia's interests;
(b) public servants being prevented by departmental heads from exposing blatant evasions of the law;
(c) threats to the 'national interest' in such circumstances; and

(d) public servants being threatened with prosecution on the basis of breaching the oath of confidentiality in such circumstances, and to recommend such legislative and administrative measures which it considers desirable to improve public servants' rights in the circumstances outlined.
(2) That the Committee consist of six Senators, as follows-
(a) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats after consultation with any minority group or groups of Senators or Independent Senator or Independent Senators.
(3) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee
(6) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(8) That the Committee (and any sub-committee) have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee report to the Senate by 30th June 1986.

(13) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy President, and, in that event
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate;
(b) the publication of the report is authorized by this Resolution;
(c) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report; and
(d) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Mason) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the dumping or disposal of radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter into the sea.
Bill presented by Senator Mason, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to prohibit the dumping or incineration at sea of any radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter, and the loading of any radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter for the purpose of being dumped at sea or incinerated at sea. The Bill applies to Australian waters, the sea above the Continental Shelf of Australia and the waters of external territories.

At present, under the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act of 1981, Section 22 allows the Minister to grant a permit for the loading or dumping of such radioactive wastes off the Australian coast.

In June 1981, during debate on the Principal Bill, the Labor Shadow Minister for the Environment moved an amendment to clause 22 which, if it had been passed, would have prohibited the dumping of radioactive wastes under any circumstances. This Bill seeks to do just that, and it also incorporates almost word for word the amendment moved by the then opposition.

In introducing this Bill, the Australian Democrats are mindful of a number of facts, including the fact that the World's Scientific and Industrial Community has not as yet developed safe, sure methods of disposing of radioactive wastes. This is many decades after the birth of the Nuclear Industry. We are also aware that, according to our research into United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation Dissertations, the behaviour of any radioactive isotope in the marine environment probably will be different at different locations, that the effect of radiation on living organisms is cumulative, and that, unlike other forms of contamination, the effects of radioactivity become more pronounced with time. We all know that the half life of plutonium, for example, is some 24,400 years, so we may expect contamination to continue for literally millenia. Even with low rates of radiation there is an increase in the rate of mutation of genes and, as each individual in the sea, as elsewhere, is after all a highly complex and integrated machine, any mutation is likely to be harmful rather than beneficial. That is basic to any genetic consideration.

Further, coastal waters are the most productive areas of our oceans, having the highest biological activity, and where primary production of the organic material which forms the base of the food chain ending in fish, birds and marine mammals takes place. The United Nations educational scientific and cultural organisation agrees that the greatest danger of harmful effects from any radioactive pollution of the oceans would be in coastal waters, including the waters over the continental shelf.

Looking regionally, we see that all nations comprising the South Pacific Forum, including Australia, have opposed the dumping of radioactive waste in the ocean. The people of the small Pacific nations face the greatest threat, for it is in the vast areas of the Pacific Ocean that some larger, nuclear nations, are looking to dispose of their poisonous radioactive wastes. This threatens the very life and livelihood of the people whose world is the thousands of islands of the Pacific, for if their waters and their food are poisoned, the Pacific people are poisoned.

The London Dumping Convention, an international treaty concerned with the dumping of radioactive waste and signed and/or ratified by over 50 countries, including Australia, announced in 1983 a two-year moratorium on the dumping of radioactive wastes in the ocean. While this moratorium is not binding on parties to the convention, it appears that the moratorium combined with public pressure have forced most, if not all, parties to suspend ocean dumping at least until a scientific study has been completed and discussed at the next London Dumping Convention to be held in September 1985.

However, while this is somewhat reassuring, there is strong and continuing international pressure seeking the allowance of the ocean dumping of radioactive wastes. While some of the waste involved relates to low level radioactive waste, there are also plans to load high level radioactive wastes into torpedoes which would penetrate deeply beneath the sea bed. Seven nations, including Britain, France, Japan and the United States comprise the 'Seabed Working Group' which is studying the seabed emplacement of such high level radioactive wastes.

Such a proposal would involve unbelievable amounts of long-life radioactive waste ''emplaced'' or dumped in the oceans far away from those nuclear powers who produced the poisons in the first place. I need hardly say that the areas being studied are close to small, non-nuclear countries.

It seems unlikely that these studies and negotiations are going to end in the immediate future and it appears that technical issues and attempts to find appropriate wording to meet concerns of the different states involved will delay any final conclusion in the foreseeable future. In the circumstances, Australia could quite legitimately make clear its own position in relation to vessels and areas under its own jurisdiction. Any subsequent international agreement should not detract from this position. Australia would merely be exercising its sovereign rights under International Law to determine for itself what dumping it would allow by its citizens or in its maritime belt.

The second report of the Commonwealth-State Committee on the Management of Radioactive wastes, released last evening, recommends the release of low level radioactive wastes into the air and water or buried in landfill areas in Australia. According to the Minister for Resources and Energy, these recommendations have the support of the Commonwealth.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, in 1981 the then shadow Minister for the Environment, the Hon. Stewart West, moved an amendment to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Bill 1981, an amendment which has been taken up by this Bill. In the words of the honourable member, 'There is no safe method known to science for the disposal of nuclear wastes'. This remains fact. I commend those words and this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1985NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage and the consideration of such Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.
Ordered that the Bills may be taken through all their stages without delay.
Bills (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.
Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of these Bills is to amend the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 (Parks Act) and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 Land Rights Act) to enable implementation of the Government's decision to grant the land in Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park to an Aboriginal land trust and implementation of the agreement with the Aboriginal traditional owners to lease the area back to the Director of National Parks and Wildlife to be managed as a national park.

A number of minor amendments are also being introduced to rectify anomalies which have been identified in the Parks Act relating to proclamation of parks and reserves and preparation of plans of management.

The Ayers Rock-Mount Olga area was proclaimed as part of the Petermann Aboriginal Reserve in the 1920. In the area was excised from the Petermann Reserve and proclaimed as a reserve under the Northern Territory Crown Lands Ordinance. It was then managed for many years by the Northern Territory Reserves Board. When the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, which we now propose to amend, was passed by the Parliament during the Whitlam Government, it was envisaged that the area would be proclaimed as a National Park under the Act. Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park was proclaimed in 1977.

Uluru National Park, which includes Ayers Rock and the Olgas, is of great cultural significance to the Aboriginal people. The majestic splendor of Ayers Rock and the Olgas has also become a magnetic attraction for tourists from within Australia and overseas and during the past year over one hundred thousand people have visited Uluru National Park. This figure is expected to increase significantly now that the magnificent tourist facilities at Yulara Village just outside the park are operational.

The real potential of Ayers Rock and the Olgas as a tourist destination was recognised in the late 1960's. Between 1968 and 1978 a number of studies were commissioned dealing with park visitor accommodation, air access, environmental matters and park planning. One report in particular, that in 1969 by Harris, Kerr, Foster and Company commissioned by the then Northern Territory Reserves Board, proposed a development plan which provided the initial stimulus for the development of the park and associated tourist facilities which has taken place in recent years.

The concept of a tourist village was developed during the Whitlam Government to the point where a site outside the boundaries of the park was selected and approved by the Central Land Council which represented Aboriginal interests. The site was not proclaimed, however, until 1976. The Yulara tourist village is thus the culmination of 15 years of planning and effort.

White Industries, the design and project managers and Philip Cox and Partners the consulting architects, have created a tourist village of world class at Yulara. The Village, which has cost over $150m, includes an international standard hotel, a motel, cabin accommodation and camping facilities providing a wide range of accommodation for visitors. The concept and design of the village display a sensitivity to the natural landscape and climate of the area. the architects, working with the environment, not against it, have incorporated the natural vegetation and the red sand dunes as features in the landscape design. A visitor to the village could only be favourably impressed with what has been created.

The amendments to the Land Rights Act are necessary for two reasons: first, to enable the deed of grant to be made by providing a description of Uluru in schedule 1 to the Act and, second, to require the land trust, to which the deed is granted, to lease the area to the Director of National Parks and Wildlife so as to enable Uluru to be managed as a National Park under the Parks Act. Amendments to the Parks Act will introduce cooperative management arrangements for Uluru National Park which will provide the Aboriginals with an effective voice in the management of the park and which will ensure the continuing protection of both the natural and cultural values of the park.

The granting of title to the traditional owners of Uluru and the leasing back to the government of that land in order to allow it to continue to operate as a national park is not a new concept. Honourable senators will be aware that the previous conservative government introduced a similar arrangement in the top end of the Northern Territory in respect of Kakadu National Park. In addition, the Northern Territory Government has itself granted freehold title to land to traditional aboriginal owners on the basis that it be used as a national park.

The amendments will enable Uluru to be both aboriginal land and a national park. In its latter capacity, it will be available to all who wish to view the grandeur of the rock and the surrounding areas. For traditional aboriginal people, grant of title to the land will be a recognition in law that it is their land, land which holds their spiritual roots and is to them an outward manifestation of their very being.
The lease-back arrangements agreed with the traditional Aboriginal owners of Uluru provide for:
The traditional owners to lease Uluru to the Director of National Parks and Wildlife for a period of 99 years, and

An annual rental of $75,000 plus 20 per cent of gross park entrance fees, to be paid by the Commonwealth. The rental will be reviewed whenever the plan of management is rewritten but, in any event, not less than every 5 years.

The Parks Bill provides for the establishment of a board for Uluru National Park or for any other park or reserve containing aboriginal land, as defined in the Parks Act, that may at some future time be declared by regulation to be a prescribed park or reserve as defined in the Bill. Before a board is established the Minister administering the Parks Act and the relevant Aboriginal Land Council agree on the name, composition and specific requirements for membership of the Board. The Minister then establishes the Board by notice in the Gazette. The functions of boards and procedures relating to boards are also set down in the Parks Bill.

The agreement reached for Uluru National Park provides for the establishment of an Uluru board of 11 members consisting of 6 Aboriginals nominated by the traditional owners; the Director of National Parks and Wildlife; one other Commonwealth official nominated by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment; a representative of the tourist industry nominated by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and two representatives of the Northern Territory.

It is significant in regard to the role of Aboriginals in managing Uluru National Park, that they will be in a majority on the Uluru Board and that there is a provision in the Parks Bill, that they should be in a majority at all meetings.

The Uluru board will have an important role in both the development and management of Uluru National Park and will advise the Minister on all aspects of these matters. I expect that, when the Board is appointed, it will begin immediately, in conjunction with the Director of National Parks and Wildlife, to draw up a new plan of management for the Park. The new plan will take effect when the present plan expires in 1987, or beforehand if the new plan is ready.

The amendments to the Parks Act provide for the resolution of disagreements between the director of National Parks and Wildlife and the Board during both the preparation of the plan of management and the implementation of the plan. The amendments provide firstly for a disagreement to be referred to the Minister administering the Parks Act for resolution. If the Minister is unable to resolve the disagreement, the Minister is required to appoint an arbitrator, suitably qualified to deal with the matter impartially and to report to the Minister. The Minister will determine the matter taking account of the arbitrator's findings.
I fully expect that, in practice, a spirit of co-operation will prevail and occasions on which the Minister will need to use these provisions will be very rare indeed.

The Government will meet the cost of the rental and certain administrative expenses related to the operation of the Board. The total cost is estimated to be $150,000 per annum. These costs are additional to on-going costs for the management of the park.

The payment of rental, which in 1985-86 is expected to amount to $100,000, together with opportunities for employment created by the park and associated tourist facilities, will add substantially to the economic base of the Aboriginal community and further enhance Aboriginal self-determination and self-management.

The arrangements being provided for Uluru National Park through amendments to the Parks Act are likely to set a pattern that could be followed, at any time in the future, for the management of other National Parks containing Aboriginal land.

I now refer to the minor amendments to the Parks Act which are included in the schedule to the Parks Bill. These amendments clarify the Act as it now stands and allow implementation of what I believe to be the original intention of the Act.

The Act, as it is presently written is unclear as to whether land can be added to an existing park, reserve or wilderness zone by varying an existing proclamation. Confusion over the meaning of the Act has prevented, for example, the amalgamation of Kakadu (stage 2) National Park with stage 1 of the park. The amendments remove this unintended barrier.
They also clarify the public comment requirement in regard to the declaration, amendment or revocation of a park, reserve or wilderness zone.

The Act, as it is now written, does not require public comment in regard to the declaration of a park or reserve within the ''region''. Region, as defined in the Act, includes stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu National Park, and by virtue of this Bill will include Uluru National Park, but excludes Arnhem Land and the Mount Bundy, Gimbat, Goodparla and Eva Valley pastoral leases. Amendments maintain this existing situation.

The amendments also provide that public comment is not required for an addition to a park, reserve or wilderness zone within the region, as defined, or the transfer of an area from one park, reserve or wilderness zone to another.

The amendments confirm, however, that any proposal to revoke a proclamation or to remove an area from a park, reserve or wilderness zone must be subject to public review and a report to the Governor-General in accordance with the Act. Honourable senators will agree that clarification of this issue is vital to the future security of our national parks and reserves.
I commend these Bills to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill continues the practice of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sittings of the Parliament to make a large number of non-contentious amendments.

The Bill amends some 65 Acts to remove obsolete provisions relating to the rights of Commonwealth public servants. Those provisions were made redundant by the repeal on 15 March 1981 of the Officers' Rights Declaration Act 1928. Officers' rights are now preserved by section 87TA of the Public Service Act 1922.

The Australian Citizenship Amendment Act 1984 which was passed by the Parliament in the Budget Sittings 1984 provided for the repeal of the definition of British subject status in the Australian Citizenship Act 1984 at a date to be proclaimed. Any reference in other Acts to ''British subject'' or to the status of British subject has meaning only by virtue of the definition of the expression in the Australian Citizenship Act. The amendments to 10 Acts remove references to British subject to ensure that the proposed proclamation of the repeal does not cause problems with interpretation of the expression.

Administrative changes to the Commonwealth Public Service were made following the elections last year. The changes included the renaming of departments, the creation of a new department and the transfer of functions. Amendments to 25 Acts have been included in the Bill as a consequence of these changes to the machinery of Government.

I propose, with the leave of the Senate, to have incorporated into Hansard the full text of the second reading Speech explaining in detail many of the changes to the various Acts which are to be made by this Bill.
Amendment of the Airports (Surface Traffic) Act 1960

The amendment of this Act allows proceedings to be taken against a person or persons carrying on a business when a vehicle is registered in that business name. This amendment overcomes doubts whether action can be taken against the owner of such vehicles in respect of an infringement of the Act involving the vehicle.
A number of formal and drafting amendments have been made to the Act in accordance with current drafting practice and administrative changes.
Amendment of the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980

Australia has a long standing policy of support for measures for the conservation of the Antarctic environment and the protection of its fauna and flora. The amendment of the Act enables the ratification of the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals. Australia has played an active role in drafting the Convention the aims of which include both the protection and study of Antarctic seals and the exchange of scientific data.
Amendment of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948

The amendment of this Act will enable the oath of allegiance or affirmation of allegiance to be taken before or after a certificate of Australian Citizenship is issued and will require that those persons who are empowered to administer the oath of allegiance or affirmation of allegiance are Australian citizens. A saving provision ensures that the grant of citizenship is effective even if the person administering the oath or affirmation is not an Australian citizen. The amendment also enables the Minister to administer the oath or affirmation.
Amendment of the Australian Institute of Marine Science Act 1972

The amendment to this Act will permit the making of standing acting appointments to the office of Director of the Australian Institute of Marine Science, thus obviating the need for Executive Council action to be taken in respect of every absence of the Director.
Amendment of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984
Sub-section 21 (1) of this Act could lend itself to an unintended interpretation as to the majority required for decisions taken by the Selection Committee without a formal meeting.

The amendment removes the possibility that this sub-section could be interpreted as permitting decisions to be taken with the support of fewer members than the number required for a quorum at meetings of the Committee.
Amendment of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979
The amendment to this Act is made in the light of a recommendation from the Security Appeals Tribunal.

The Tribunal reviews, on request, adverse or qualified security assessments furnished by ASIO to Commonwealth agencies in specified circumstances. the Act currently requires the Tribunal, subject to one qualification, to give copies of its findings to the applicant, to ASIO, and to the Commonwealth agency concerned. The Tribunal has recommended that it should have a discretion to furnish copies of its findings to the Attorney-General. The government accepts the spirit of the recommendation, but considers that the Attorney-General should be given a copy of the findings in every case because he is responsible for ASIO and for the administration of the Act and the amendment, accordingly, implements this provision.
Amendment of the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967

The amendment to this Act empowers the Commission to invest its funds, by making the Commission subject to Division 2 of Part XI of the Audit Act 1901, instead of Division 3 of Part XI as at present. This will enable the Commission to make the best possible use of any surplus funds which it may have available and will require it to keep its accounts in accordance with normal commercial practice.
Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984

The amendments to this Act permit adjustment levies imposed under this scheme to be recovered in the same way as if they were excise duties and enables the responsible Minister to notify proposed levy adjustment alterations when Parliament is not sitting.
Bounty (Electric Motors) Act 1984

The amendment to this Act will ensure that the value added figure applied to a bountiable motor includes the cost of any process or service (if provided by the manufacturer at registered premises) unless research, development or design costs apply. These latter costs, if incurred in Australia, attract a bounty irrespective of whether or not the work was undertaken on registered premises.
Amendment of the Bounty (Paper) Act 1979

The amendment to this Act substitutes a more precise and modern test for the determination of whether paper is to be regarded as uncoated. Since the introduction of the Act, the proposed test has been adopted by the industry as a more precise and accurate test method.
Amendment of the Cocos (Keeling) Island Act 1955

One of the amendments to this Act which deserves mention is the insertion of a new section which will enable Ordinances of the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands to be made. These will improve the operation of the Supreme Court of the Territory, and will make access to, and dealings with, the Supreme Court easier for members of the public.
Amendment of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904

The amendments to this Act relate to the financial accounting and reporting requirements under Part VIIIAA of the Act, for registered organisations and their branches. Organisations or branches whose annual incomes do not exceed $10,000 will be able to apply to the Industrial Registrar for a certificate of exemption from the existing financial and reporting requirements of Part VIIIAA. This amendment will enable the preparation of accounts to be less onerous and costly.

The other requirements of Part VIIIAA will continue to apply to organisations or branches with a certificate, including those dealing with rights of individual members to seek further information and the powers and duties of the Registrar to investigate and rectify deficiencies.
Amendment of the Defence Act 1903

Under the common law, members of the Defence Force cannot sue the Commonwealth for moneys owing to them in respect of their service. Section 12 of the Act varies this position to a limited extent by permitting members to sue after leaving the Defence Force. This situation is changed by extending to serving members of the Defence Force the right to sue. Because garnishee proceedings do not lie against the Crown, this procedure is not available to creditors of members of the Defence Force. The amendments create similar statutory rights and obligations regarding garnishee proceedings in relation to members of the Defence Force to those applying to other Commonwealth employees.
Amendment of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982

The provisions of this Act provide for the issue of summonses and warrants on the basis of sworn information or affidavit. The amendments empower authorised officers of the Defence Force to swear informations.

Under the Act a commanding officer may direct that a subordinate summary authority is not to deal with a particular charge against a person. The amendments will enable a commanding officer to direct that a subordinate summary authority is not to deal with a class of cases.

There is a requirement under the Act that legal officers, to whom convictions by summary authorities are referred for legal advice, should be authorised or appointed for this purpose. The amendments omit the requirement for such authorisation or appointment, as this would create an unjustifiable administrative burden.
Amendment of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976

Following consultation with the Northern Territory government, amendments to the Act will ensure that appeals from the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory will lie to the Northern Territory Court of Appeal instead of the Federal Court of Australia. The amendments are expressed to come into operation on a date to be fixed by Proclamation after appropriate consultation with the Northern Territory Government and the establishment of a Court of Appeal in the Northern Territory.
The amendments are consistent with the Northern Territory exercising responsibility for courts established under Northern Territory legislation.
Amendment of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981

The amendments to this Act enable the court to award costs to a successful appellant where there was no respondent in the appeal, or where the appeal was to the A.C.T. Supreme Court against a criminal conviction in the Court of Petty Sessions and a new trial was ordered.
Amendment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975

In conformity with the general practice in Commonwealth legislation, the Act is amended to apply those provisions of the Crimes Act 1914 relating to conspiracy or being an accessory to an offence committed under that Act, and to allow the court to dismiss a charge or discharge a person upon giving adequate security.

Under the present provisions of the Act, Regulations cannot apply to unzoned areas of the Marine Park if more than 2 years has elapsed since the area became part of the Marine Park. The Act is amended to extend this period from 2 years to 3 years, so that there will be some control over activities in areas declared part of the Marine Park in August 1983 and for which zoning plans are unlikely to be in force by August 1985. The Act is also amended to define the Authority's role as manager of the Marine Park and includes in that role the provision of educational, advisory and information services relating to the Marine Park and its management. Further amendments increase the penalty for unauthorised drilling or mining in the Marine Park from $1,000 a day to $50,000 for each day the offence continues.
Amendment of the Health Insurance Act 1973

A number of amendments to the Health Insurance Act are being made as a consequence of the replacement of the Capital Territory Health Commission by the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority which was effected by the Health Services Ordinance 1985.
Amendment of the Historic Shipwrecks Act 1976

The Act provides a good legislative example of Commonwealth-State co-operation. The Commonwealth is empowered to co-ordinate measures for the protection of the national maritime heritage with the States taking an active role in the survey, identification, protection, recovery, preservation and exhibition of historic shipwrecks and relics.
The Minister has consulted the relevant State Ministers on these proposed amendments and there has been general support.

There has been growing interest in historic material located beneath Australian waters. Because of its nature and situation this material is particularly vulnerable, and since the commencement of the Act experience has shown that the legislation requires clarification and strengthening.

Certain known shipwrecks of historical significance straddle the low-water line. At present only those remains, or articles associated with a ship, which lie below the low-water line can be the subject of a declaration for protection under section 5 of this Act. If part of a wreck situated above the low-water line is removed the historic value of the wreck is diminished. The amendments provide that the remains of wrecks and articles associated with them, including those above the low-water line, can be protected, provided a Minister of the State concerned has informed the Federal Minister in writing that the Government of that State has no objection.
The amendments also extend protection to articles washed up, as well as those removed from Australian waters.

In addition to the declaration of individual wrecks, the amendments allow a State (defined as including the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island) to seek a general declaration on all wrecks over 75 years old, including a general declaration to cover wrecks situated in waters adjacent to Commonwealth Territories. A power of revocation in respect of individual wrecks is included in the amendments, because detailed examination of a particular wreck could indicate that it did not warrant protection.

At present a provisional declaration is limited to one year. In practice this has been found an inadequate period for completion of site explorations, and it is proposed to increase this to five years.

The Act limits the area of a protected zone to 100 hectares. A protected zone of up to 200 hectares is necessary because shipwrecks can be widely scattered and 100 hectares is too small an area for accurate fixing by satelite navigation.

The Minister's powers under Section 11 are extended to obtain the custody of articles or historic relics for the purpose of placing in collections. This section relates to the power of the Minister to give directions in relation to the custody, preservation, and exhibition of historic shipwrecks and relics.
To provide an incentive to people to assist the protection of historic shipwrecks, the Minister's powers are extended to make monetary awards or make a gift of certain memorabilia.
The penalties under the Act are brought up to date.
Amendment to the Home Deposit Assistance Act 1982

The evidentiary provisions are unsatisfactory because the Secretary is the only officer of the Department who can attest to documentary evidence provided to the courts. The amendments will enable the Secretary to appoint other officers of the Department for this purpose.
Amendment of the Home Savings Grant Act 1964

The evidentiary provisions are unsatisfactory because the Secretary and Regional Directors are the only officers of the Department who can attest to documentary evidence provided to the courts. The amendments will enable the Secretary to appoint other officers of the Department for this purpose.
Amendment of the Home Savings Grant Act 1976

The evidentiary provisions are unsatisfactory because the Secretary and Regional Directors are the only officers of the Department who can attest to documentary evidence provided to the courts. The amendments will enable the Secretary to appoint other officers of the Department for this purpose.
Amendment of the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946

Under the Act the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is the guardian of minors entering Australia who do not accompany or join, a parent or relative over the age of 21 years who provides care for them.

The amendments will enable the Minister to provide guardianship to minors who have entered Australia with a supporting relative, when care arrangements have broken down. The consent of the supporting relative is required.

A person affected by a decision made under the amendment may, where the decision is made by a delegate of the Minister, seek reconsideration of the decision by the Minister and may then apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of the Minister's decision. Where the Minister makes the original decision a person affected by the decision may apply directly to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review.
Amendment of the Independent Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act 1969

The amendment to this Act requires the annual report to be based on a calendar year instead of a financial year. This change conforms with the annual reporting requirements of the other Acts administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission.
Amendment of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976
The amendment to this Act puts beyond doubt that public interest projects may be assisted where the projects relate to development in a field of science or technology, as well as industrial research.
Amendment of the Insurance Contracts Act 1984

The amendments overcome minor problems relating to the provision of information or advice to insurers and clarify the nature of the information or advice to be provided in particular instances. The amendments should facilitate the operation of the Act when it comes into operation later this year.
Amendment of the Judiciary Act 1903

The amendment to this Act is associated with an amendment to the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 which removes the right of appeal from the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory to the Federal Court of Australia.

The proposed amendment confers appellate jurisdiction on the High Court of Australia to hear and determine appeals from judgments of the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory. Appeals from the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory will lie to the High Court only by special leave of the High Court. The effect of the amendment is to put appeals from the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory on the same footing as appeals from State Supreme Courts. There is a transitional provision included, so that the amendment applies to judgments given or pronounced before or after this amendment, which will come into operation on the same day as the amendment to the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 comes into operation.
Amendment of the Life Insurance Act 1945

The amendments to this Act arise from the provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 dealing with the conversion of lump sum termination payments to annuities. Under the existing provisions of the Life Insurance Act 1945 the issue of such annuities would need to be transacted as part of the ordinary class of life insurance business of a life office. However, it is essential for a life office to be able to conduct this business as a part of its superannuation business, as both are now treated alike for taxation purposes.

The amendments provide the necessary flexibility for the Commissioner to approve this procedure where he is satisfied that it would be appropriate, and would generally assist in achieving the Government's broad objective of encouraging the greater use of annuities as a means for providing income in retirement.
Amendment of the Management and Investment Companies Act 1983

The principal amendments to this Act relate to an increase in the time limit allowed for the filing of annual returns by licensed management investment companies, and a consequential change in the expiry date for licences. The changes will allow management investment companies a more reasonable and realistic period of time within which to comply with these requirements.
Amendment of the National Gallery Act 1975

A number of amendments to the Act will provide, inter alia, for more efficient administration of the Gallery, give the Gallery additional functions and activities, provide for an Australian National Gallery Fund and give the Gallery a power of investment. The amendments are largely of an administrative and machinery nature and only the more important amendments are mentioned here.
The amendments to section 7 of the Act empower it to engage in a number of new activities including-
Commissioning works of art for the National Collection and for sale separately;
Professional advice and services to both Government and the public;
Selling original works of art not in the National Collection, and reproductions;
Hire of Gallery facilities and entry charges for special exhibitions and events.
Section 10 of the Act is amended to make it clear that exchanges are not limited to one-for-one transactions and provide for exchanges of works which are advantageous additions to the collection.
Amendments to section 22 enable the Council to delegate non-staff matters to members of the staff. The power of delegation by the Council may be exercised without Ministerial approval.
The position of Administrator has been established in place of Secretary and Manager. The statutory position of Director of the Gallery remains and the powers of an acting Director are specified.

The amendment gives the Gallery a general power of investment and establishes an Australian National Gallery Fund into which may be paid moneys received from private citizens and corporate sponsors. The Gallery is declared to be subject to Division 3 of Part XI of the Audit Act 1901.
Amendment of the National Health Act 1953

Some of the penalties set out in the Act have not been increased since it was first enacted in 1953 and, as such, have little deterrent value. Following a thorough review, all penalties in the Act are being amended to reflect the community's perceptions of the seriousness of the various offences and to bring them into line with current economic values.
A new definition of Secretary is to be inserted into the Act to reflect the joint administration of the Act by the Departments of Health and Community Services
Amendment of the Patents Act 1952

The amendments replace the words ''British subject'' with ''Australian citizen'', as a consequence of the amendment of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 by the Australian Citizenship Amendment Act 1984.
The proposed amendments ensure that an abstract of a patent specification will be published at, but not before, the date on which the patent application and specification are published.
Other amendments update the penalty provisions for offences under the Act, most of which have not been amended since the Act came into force.
Amendment of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980

The amendment to this Act corrects a technical inconsistency between one of the grounds for non-renewal of a franchise agreement and the resulting extension of the term of the franchise agreement when that ground is relied upon. The amendment to this Act shall be deemed to have come into operation immediately after the commencement date of section 16 of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Amendment Act 1984.
Amendment of the Public Works Committee Act 1969

The amendment to this Act increases the statutory limit, above which proposals for public works must be referred to the Public Works Committee, from $2m to $6m. The increase takes account of increases in costs since the statutory limit was last amended in 1973.
Amendment of the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983

The amendments to the Act give effect to minor technical amendments recently adopted by the Marine Environment Protection Committee of the International Maritime Organisation's International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973-78.
Amendment of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984
The amendment to this Act will enable ''class'' exemptions from the Act to be granted, in certain circumstances, to avoid a multiplicity of applications.
Amendment of the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975

The amendments to the Act overcome administrative problems which have arisen since the Act was extensively amended in 1978. The amendments have the general support of the National Labour Consultative Council.

These amendments abolish the present Australian Council for Union Training and the Authority's Executive Board replacing them with a new Australian Council for Union Training responsible for formulating TUTA's policy. A smaller Executive Committee, responsible for implementation of the Australian Council's policy, will be appointed from the Council. State Councils for Union Training will be re-named Regional Councils for Union Training and be given responsibility for ensuring that TUTA's training activities in their State or Territory accord with the policy of the Australian Council. In addition, the responsibilities of the Director of Studies will be made clear by requiring the occupant of that office, subject to the direction of the National Director, to be responsible for the planning, development and implementation of training in accordance with the policy of the Australian Council.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
By this Bill, the Government proposes to amend the National Health Act to effect two changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
The first of these changes relates to the occasional situation where the Minister for Health and the manufacturer of a drug are unable to agree upon the price of a drug.

Under the existing legislation, the Government is placed in an invidious situation when a manufacturer unilaterally increases the price of a drug. The Government may either continue to list that drug as a Pharmaceutical Benefit and meet the additional cost imposed by the manufacturer, or it may remove the drug from the list of Pharmaceutical Benefit Drugs. In the latter case, patients must either meet the full retail cost of the drug or forego the treatment recommended by their doctors.

Though bilateral agreements on drug prices are extremely desirable, there have been several occasions in the past when agreement could not be reached with a manufacturer. When such disagreements occur, the Government believes that patients should not be faced with a choice between meeting the full cost of drugs-no matter what effect that might have on their own financial resources-or foregoing recommended treatment.

I note a further deficiency in the operation of the existing legislation. When a new drug is recommended for listing as a Pharmaceutical Benefit there can be considerable delay in reaching agreement with the manufacturer as to the price of that drug. Under the existing provisions no government subsidy can be available until agreement is reached.

Accordingly, by the first of these amendments the Minister for Health will be allowed to determine a price upon which reimbursement to pharmacists is made in respect of those drugs where there is no agreement with a manufacturer. This will apply to drugs which, desirably should be listed as Pharmaceutical Benefits under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

The proposed amendment to Part seven of the National Health Act would also allow the Minister to determine a special patient contribution in respect of such a drug. The special contribution would amount to the difference between the total reimbursement that a pharmacist should receive, based upon the manufacturers' actual price, and that reimbursement that the pharmacist would have received if the price of the drug had been set at a level acceptable to the Minister. The patient concerned would be required to pay the special patient contribution in addition to the appropriate normal contribution. Concessional beneficiaries and pensioners would be required to pay the same special patient contribution as the rest of the community.

The effect would be that the drug would continue to be available as a pharmaceutical benefit and thus to be subsidised by the Commonwealth. Patients would then be able to obtain the drug at a charge less than the full price which would have applied if the drug had been removed from the list of pharmaceutical benefits.

The second of the changes is part of the package of measures announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 14 May. The general patient contribution for pharmaceutical benefits has been increased by one dollar with effect from 1 July 1985. This will bring the patient contribution to $5 from the existing level of $4.

This is the first increase in the price of pharmaceutical benefits in the two and a half years since 1 January 1983. Over that period the average cost of a general benefit prescription has increased from $6.03c to an estimated $7.38c, an overall increase of $1.35c. Despite this the Government has decided to limit the increase in the general patient contribution to $1; an action, I might say, in sharp contrast to the 167% increase in the general patient contribution during the seven years of the previous Government.
I emphasise that no change is being made in the cost for concessional beneficiaries which is to remain at $2, and pensioners will still be able to obtain pharmaceutical benefits free of charge.

For the first change, only a small number of drugs are involved in price disagreements between manufacturers and the Minister. The cost to the Government of the proposal to list drugs as pharmaceutical benefits where there are price disagreements will be insignificant. However, the economic benefits to individual patients who require a price disagreed drug will be considerable.
With the second change, the increase in the general patient contribution for pharmaceutical benefits will result in an estimated saving of $40.3m per annum. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

As part of its cost saving measures, announced by the Treasurer earlier this evening, the Government has decided to increase by a lesser amount than is currently provided for under the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976, personal income tax sharing grants payable to local government in 1985-86. The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the changes that are necessary to that Act. At present the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 provides for local government to receive every year 2 per cent of personal income tax collected in the previous year. Had this arrangement been continued, grants for local government in the states in 1985-86 would have increased by nearly 20 per cent or by some $97m. The Government considered that this increase was excessive in the current circumstances and that local government authorities should share in the expenditure restraint that will need to be exercised by other spheres of government in order to lay the foundation for sustained economic growth.

It is therefore proposing a special arrangement, for 1985-86 only, whereby local government will receive an amount equal to the grant in 1984-85 increased in real terms by 2 per cent. On the basis of available estimates it is anticipated that this new formula will result in local government receiving $531m in 1985-86, an increase of $45m on grants made available in 1984-85. This means that, as compared with a situation under which the present arrangements would have continued to apply, the saving to the Government will be $52m. It is important to note that this new arrangement will be applicable for 1985-86 only. The arrangements to apply after 1985-86 will be determined by the Government following its consideration of the report of the national inquiry into local government finance. This inquiry, which I announced in May last year, has been conducting hearings throughout the country and is undertaking a particularly thorough examination of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act and other aspects of local government finance. Its Chairman, Professor Peter Self, has indicated that he will present his report to the Government by the end of September. On this basis, I would expect the Government to have considered the report, considered the views of all interested parties on the report and introduced any necessary changes to the Act in time for them to be effective for the 1986-87 financial year. The arrangements that are to be introduced for 1985-86 adhere fairly closely to those which had previously applied.

The process will begin before the end of August when the Treasurer, at the time of his Budget announcements, will publish the estimated movement in the consumer price index in the year to the March quarter 1986. The States will be advised of this estimate together with an estimate of the grants they will receive for distribution to local government. As is the case at present, the States will then advise me of the proposed allocation of grants to local government together with an assurance that the allocations have been made in accordance with the Act. I will satisfy myself that the Act has been complied with and then advise the Treasurer of my views. The Treasurer immediately authorises payment to the State concerned.

The Bill provides that the payments made to the States for local government can be adjusted if the actual change in the consumer price index is different to that which was estimated in August. This adjustment would be made following the release of the consumer price index for the March quarter 1986. If the estimated increase in the consumer price index for the year exceeds the actual increase, the States will be required to repay to the Commonwealth the difference. If, on the other hand, the actual increase exceeds the estimated increase, the Commonwealth will be required to increase its payments to the States. If a State is required to repay the Commonwealth, the Bill permits this to be deducted from payments in future years. If a State is entitled to additional payments the Bill requires that they be distributed among local governing bodies in the same way as the first payment was distributed. The Act does not apply to payments the Commonwealth Government makes to the Northern Territory Government for the five local government authorities in that Territory. However the memorandum of understanding with the Northern Territory Government requires that those payments are to be made on a similar basis to those for local government elsewhere in Australia, and this will be reflected in payments to the Territory for local government in 1985-86.

In concluding I would like to emphasise that the grant that will be provided to local government in 1985-86 represents an increase of some $45m. It is the largest increase since 1982-83. It is also important to recall this Government's commitment to local government. In 1983 we established the first Ministry of Local Government. We strengthened its role under the revised administrative arrangements that were introduced last December by combining it with related functions of regional development and Commonwealth property. We have ensured that local government is represented in the highest economic forums of the land. We have supported the constitutional recognition of local government. We have introduced the local government development program to assist local authorities to strengthen their efficiency and capacity. We have expanded and introduced other programs involving local government, such as the Australian land transport program and community services programs.

Overall Federal Government grants, both tied and untied, to local government now total nearly $1 billion per annum. This represents a 50 per cent increase in the first two years of the Government on the last year of the Fraser Government.

These facts emphasise that the Government is firmly committed to raising the status and strengthening the capacity of local government throughout Australia. We have put in place the basis for a fuller national recognition of the importance of local government and are building upon it. Our commitment to local government is enduring. It is a commitment which the Government will continue to work towards.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate of the following resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives:

That the House of Representatives, recognising the desirability of a thorough review of the Australian Constitution in the light of experience since its establishment and of modern day requirements, agrees that the Commonwealth Parliament continue its participation in the Australian Constitutional Convention established to review the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution and accordingly resolves:
(1) That, for the purposes of the Convention-

(a) a delegation from the Commonwealth Parliament take part in the deliberations of the Convention, and comprise 12 members of the Parliament of whom 4 shall be members of the Senate and 8 shall be Members of the House of Representatives;
(b) the 8 Members of the House of Representatives comprise 4 members of the Australian Labor Party, 3 members of the Liberal Party of Australia and one member of the National Party of Australia.
(2) That-
(a) the Prime Minister and 3 other Members of the House of Representatives, being members of the Australian Labor Party, nominated by him;
(b) the Leader of the Opposition and 2 other Members of the House, being members of the Liberal Party of Australia, nominated by the Leader of that Party; and
(c) the Leader of the National Party of Australia or another Member of the House, being a member of the National Party of Australia, nominated by the Leader of that Party,
be members of the Delegation.
(3) That the Prime Minister or his nominee be the Leader of the Delegation, and the Leader of the Opposition or his nominee be the Deputy Leader.
(4) That a member of the Delegation cease to be such a member if-
(a) he ceases to be a member of the Commonwealth Parliament;
(b) the House of the Parliament of which he is a member terminates his appointment; or
(c) he resigns as a member of the Delegation by writing addressed to the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the case requires.

(5) That where, because of illness or any other cause, a member of the Delegation is not available to attend a meeting, or part of a meeting, of the Convention, the Leader or senior available member of that member's Party may nominate an alternative member and the member so nominated shall be a member of the Delegation for that meeting, or that part of that meeting.

(6) That, in the event of a member of the Delegation ceasing to be such a member, the Leader of that member's Party in the House from which that member was drawn may nominate another member (being a member of the House of which the first-mentioned member is or was a member) to replace the first-mentioned member.

(7) That the Leader of the Delegation from time to time make a report for presentation to each House of the Parliament on matters arising out of the convention, and that the Deputy Leader of the Delegation may make an accompanying Motion report.
Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Manager of Government Business (Senator Grimes) I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, recognising the desirability of a thorough review of the Australian Constitution in the light of experience since its establishment and of modern day requirements, agrees that the Commonwealth Parliament continue its participation in the Australian Constitutional Convention established to review the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution and accordingly resolves:
(1) That, for the purposes of the Convention-

(b) the 4 members of the Senate comprise 2 members of the Australian Labor Party, one member of the Opposition and one member of the Australian Democrats.
(2) That-

(b) one Senator being a member of the Opposition, nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and

be members of the Delegation.
(3) That the Prime Minister or his nominee be the Leader of the Delegation, and the Leader of the Opposition or his nominee be the Deputy Leader.
(4) That a member of the Delegation cease to be such a member if-
