(b) the House of Parliament of which he is a member terminates his appointment; or
(c) he resigns as a member of the Delegation by writing addressed to the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the case requires.

(5) That where, because of illness or any other cause, a member of the Delegation is not available to attend a meeting, or part of a meeting, of the Convention, the Leader or senior available member of that member's Party may nominate an alternative member and the member so nominated shall be a member of the Delegation for that meeting, or that part of that meeting.

(6) That, in the event of a member of the Delegation ceasing to be such a member, the Leader of that member's Party in the House from which that member was drawn may nominate another member (being a member of the House of which the first-mentioned member is or was a member) to replace the first-mentioned member.

(7) That the Leader of the Delegation from time to time make a report for presentation to each House of the Parliament on matters arising out of the Convention, and that the Deputy Leader of the Delegation may make an accompanying report.
(8) That a Message be sent to the House of Representatives acquainting it of the Resolution agreed to by the Senate.

Earlier this year the Executive Committee of the Australian Constitutional Convention decided that the Brisbane meeting should go ahead as planned from 29 July to 2 August, notwithstanding the failure of the 1984 referendums. Most of the Parliaments have now passed their resolutions and all have accepted the principle of equal government and non-government representation and a reduction in the size of the delegations. If the principle of equal representation is in fact carried through to fruition that should remove one of the major sources of dissension at the Adelaide conference and that state of affairs is much to be welcomed.

The resolutions of the Commonwealth Parliament also provide for equal government and non-government representation. As in 1983 they make provision for representation of the Australian Democrats. The Brisbane meeting will be the sixth meeting of the Convention and will be a smaller gathering than any of the previous meetings. Agreement has been reached to reduce the size of the Convention with a view to allowing individual delegates more opportunities to speak and generally improving the Convention's procedures. The Commonwealth delegation has been reduced from 16 to 12, each State delegation has been reduced from 12 to eight and each local government delegation has been reduced from three to two. Representation of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory remains at two each. The total size of the Convention has been reduced from 112 to 78.

So far as the composition of the Commonwealth 12 is concerned, the motion before us and that which has just been transmitted from the House of Representatives propose that there be eight delegates from the House of Representatives and four from the Senate, this formula being consistent, as I understand it, with discussions which took place between the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, and the shadow Attorney-General, Mr N. A. Brown, at the time of the executive committee meeting. On the basis of a six-six split between Government and Opposition the numbers would fall out for the Government as four delegates from the House of Representatives and two from the Senate. For the non-government six it would mean, as the motion sets out, four representatives from the House of Representatives, and two senators, one of whom would be from the Opposition and the other from the Australian Democrats.

The Opposition has now indicated that it would prefer that the non-government six were, in fact, divided three-three between the House of Representatives and the Senate, thus making it possible for there to be three Opposition delegates from the House of Representatives, two Opposition delegates from the Senate and still one Australian Democrat. I understand that Senator Durack will move an amendment to accomplish that state of affairs while leaving untouched the Government side of the delegation. The Government has no opposition whatsoever to that proposed course. We see it as entirely a matter for the non-government parties to sort out among themselves how they would like their part of the delegation to be comprised. We certainly will not stand in the way of this amendment.

I further add that provision is made for alternative delegates to be appointed in circumstances where a delegate is unavailable. However, the executive committee has recommended, again for the better operation of the Convention, that the number of alternates should be limited to six in the case of the Commonwealth and four in the case of each State. The Government believes that this recommendation should be observed by the Commonwealth and that Government and non-government leaders should exercise restraint by nominating only three alternates each.

The Government is hopeful that despite the reversal suffered by the Constitutional Convention in recent years the Brisbane meeting will prove to be a worthwhile exercise. Perhaps it is the last opportunity for the Constitutional Convention to prove its worth and we will all be hoping that something constructive will emerge from it. Much work of a constructive nature has been done, as I and other senators here can testify, in the Convention sub-committees since the Adelaide meeting and there is a full agenda for Brisbane. The modest achievement of three referendum successes in 1977 shows that progress is possible on a wide range of issues if a cross-party approach to constitutional reform can be developed and maintained. There is much I could say on this theme in the light of recent history but I do not think that the speedy passage of this motion would be facilitated by my doing so. I simply indicate that constitutional reform remains an important priority for this nation and I, on behalf of the Government, certainly look forward to cross-party co-operation in achieving it. I commend the motion, with Senator Durack's foreshadowed amendment, to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is, of course, entirely in support of the basic thrust of the motion that has been moved; namely, that this Commonwealth Parliament should participate in the Australian Constitutional Convention which is to be held at the end of July this year in Brisbane. This will be the first plenary session of that Convention since the Convention which was held in Adelaide at the end of April 1983, just over two years ago. At that time an offer was made by the Queensland Government to hold the next plenary session in Brisbane in 1985. Even though the Government seemed to have had a fit of pique after the failure of the referendums on 1 December, and at that stage was talking about abandoning the Convention, the Opposition is pleased that the Government decided in the end to continue its support for the Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal of work has been done by a number of committees which were established as a result of the Adelaide Convention. Very extensive valuable reports have been prepared and will be available for the next Convention. In my view, the forthcoming Convention in Brisbane will be better informed, by these reports, than previous Conventions have been, although I do concede that there have been valuable reports at previous Conventions. One of the achievements of the Adelaide Convention was the establishment of a number of special sub-committees to study various subjects. The support which has been given by governments, members of the Convention and members of those committees to that work has been an outstanding feature of this whole process of constitutional reform through the Convention; a process which this Opposition, both when it was in government and now in opposition, has supported.

The Minister for Energy and Resources, Senator Gareth Evans, has referred to the fact that amendments have been made to the Constitution as a result of these Conventions and that is always to be seen as a possible achievement for any Convention, but it does have a wider value than that. A number of steps can be taken by governments to improve the working of the Constitution short of actually having constitutional reform. Discussion about constitutional reforms is another valuable aspect of the Convention process, so there are good and sound reasons for continuing the Convention. I forbear from debating with Senator Gareth Evans why the Government failed last year with the referendums, but the mere fact that some referendums fail is no reason why the process should be abandoned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trust is alive and well in 1985.

—If Labor senators want to start a debate, I am very happy to have it. I will not stand here and be provoked by Labor senators who were largely responsible for the miserable performance of the Government on constitutional reform because of the backing and filling that went on in the Government last year. I am happy to call it quits on that. I warn Labor senators that any more interjections or comments on that matter will provoke me to a lengthy speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The commitment of the Government to the Convention is not as strong as its rhetoric might have led us to hope. The way in which this motion is being dealt with is a good example of that. The Opposition supports the Government's commendable restraint in negotiating for smaller delegations for this Convention. I think it will help the process of the Convention to have fewer people present, and it is also a sensible financial saving.

Apparently, all participating governments have agreed with this proposal. The Commonwealth delegation, which at previous conventions amounted to 16, is to be reduced to 12. The Opposition supports that. The Opposition believes that as the Australian Democrats were represented at the last Convention in Adelaide they should also be represented at this Convention.

Our only problem lies in the proposed division of the 12 members of the delegation between the two Houses. The Government waited until right at the death knock of this session to bring forward this motion or even to give notice of it. It was introduced in both chambers at a late hour on Monday night. Of the 12 delegates, it provided that eight should come from the House of Representatives and only four from the Senate whereas, under the previous arrangement, of a delegation of 16, 10 came from the House of Representatives and six from the Senate. This proposal has created a disproportion between the proposed representation and that which the Senate enjoyed in the past.

Although the Executive Committee resolved some months ago that there would be fewer members on the delegation, the Government managed to get around to putting this proposal to the Parliament in the last week of the sittings of the House of Representatives. It did this at a late hour on Monday night and then expected the Opposition to deal with the matter yesterday. Unfortunately the Government insisted on proceeding with this matter in the House of Representatives and passed the resolution in the form to which the Opposition objects. I appreciate Senator Gareth Evans's co-operation in having the matter deferred in the Senate until it could be resolved. We have achieved that now. The Opposition has proposed that the membership break up between the two Houses will be seven from the House of Representatives and five from the Senate. So the Opposition will have one less representative from the House of Representatives and one more from the Senate. That is the purpose of the amendments that I propose to move. They have been circulated. I do not propose to read them out, but that is their effect.

In the light of the message we have just received from the House of Representatives, after the final paragraph of the motion moved by Senator Gareth Evans dealing with the transmission of a message to the House of Representatives, we should add the words 'and requesting the House to reconsider the resolution transmitted to the Senate by message No. 111'. This message has recently been read to the Senate by the President. For the reasons that I have outlined, I seek leave to move four amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Paragraph (1) (a), leave out '4', insert '5', leave out '8', insert '7'.
(2) Paragraph (1) (b), leave out '4', insert '5', leave out 'one member', insert '2 members'.
(3) Paragraph (2) (b), leave out 'one Senator being a member', insert '2 Senators being members'.
(4) Paragraph (8), at end of paragraph, add 'and requesting that the House reconsider the resolution transmitted to the Senate by Message No. 111'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Democrats support the motion moved by the Government. We agree with the rearrangement that the Opposition proposes regarding the composition of its representation on the delegation to the Australian Constitutional Convention. I believe that the decision of the Executive Committee, of which I am a member, almost two months ago to reduce the numbers on the delegation will facilitate the operations of the Convention. I must admit that I am nowhere near as sanguine as Senator Gareth Evans or Senator Durack as to the possible outcome of that Convention. Having in mind the operation of the Adelaide Convention, I think one must approach the Convention in Brisbane with a great deal of fear and trepidation lest, by holding such a convention, we put back the cause of constitutional reform rather than advance it.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that this time around people will be more reasonable and more sensible in terms of what goes on and also that they will actually adhere to the resolutions once they are passed rather than proceed to campaign against them. That type of exercise not only brings the Convention into disrepute but also brings political life in Australia into disrepute. It is little wonder that following such exercises the people of Australia vote against any type of referendum that comes up on the basis that the whole thing looks like a cynical exercise in power manipulation. I would hope that if there is a sensible debate in the Convention and if certain resolutions are supported by the majority of people there, those who have voted for them on the floor of the Convention will actually proceed to convince their own parties to support those resolutions out in the electorate. Ultimately that will be the only way in which any exercise in constitutional reform in this country will be able to take place.

There is a fair amount of unease that the Convention as it is currently structured, made up entirely of politicians from parties that themselves have vested interests not only in regard to constitutional change but also in regard to election matters, probably will be unable ultimately to come up with a satisfactory resolution of the types of constitutional problems that Australia faces. So some type of restructuring of the Convention is probably in order. It is interesting to see that the Government itself has moved from the position it took while in opposition to one which is more accommodating of viewpoints other than political viewpoints put forward at Constitutional Conventions.

The Brisbane Constitutional Convention will probably be the make or break of any activity in this area. If the performance of Adelaide is repeated in Brisbane there will probably not be another Constitutional Convention held during the lifetime of anyone here. I say that for one very good reason: To further perpetuate that cynical exercise would do untold damage to the aspirations of the Australian people to bring their Constitution constantly up to date when new problems are met. Unfortunately we have built up in Australia the view that the Constitution must be left entirely alone. I believe that that is totally unsatisfactory. The Constitution was written before the types of communications and transport system that we all know so well and accept as ordinary parts of our lives-I refer to the advent of radio and television as mass media, the supply of telephones to every home and the use of aeroplanes-had come into operation. In other words, we have a totally different type of society now to the one we had when our Constitution was drawn up. With all respect to the people who did draw it up-it has served this country well-there are things that they were not at that stage able to take into account. For example, the Governor-General, whilst having control over the army and the navy, in fact does not have control over the air force simply because there was not an air force at the time the Constitution was drawn up. The country moves on, history moves on, and because of that it is necessary for the Constitution to change to take account of that.

Some unfortunate situations have arisen. For example, in Adelaide there was another excellent debate on the operation of laws governing the custody and control of children and the breakup of marriages. That related particularly to the custody of children following a marriage breakup. We had innumerable lists of decisions of the High Court of Australia, the Federal Court of Australia and lower courts indicating that the law in this area is an absolute mess, that people's lives are being dragged through one jurisdiction after another with no regard to the individuals concerned and certainly with no regard to the children who have been massively disadvantaged by our inability to agree about who has jurisdiction in certain areas. Whilst there was an excellent debate, absolutely no action was taken and nothing was followed through because it seemed that if any follow-through were to take place it would have been actively opposed in the context of an election campaign.

I presume that the Government has learnt its lesson at least on one thing-it will never again hold a referendum in conjunction with an election. I suppose if we can put down the enormous cost of the campaign and say we have learnt something from it, that at least is useful. I sincerely hope that the Convention in Brisbane will be a genuine attempt by the people going there to bring about some agreed position in this area, but I must say that in my heart of hearts I have little hope at all of that occurring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage it is obviously game, set and match so far as the Constitutional Convention is concerned. The Opposition has agreed with the Government, and the Australian Democrats are happy with their one person on the Convention and we will now go along with this with a whistling of hope which Senator Macklin has given us. I think, honestly, that he has also given us reasons for a great deal of doubt about whether it will happen.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a few comments about this matter, even though it appears to be too late, because we are here concerned with a motion which will reduce the Commonwealth contribution to 12 people instead of 16-which should be no great cause for cheering in the streets-and even that is to be split up 7:5 between the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Opposition has agreed to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The State delegations have been reduced too.
—Yes, but not, I think, to the same degree.
—Yes, the same degree.

—The same degree. Well, we have fewer people looking at the whole question of constitutional change, and therefore there will be a smaller variety of views among the people considering this matter. I do not regard that as a reduction of any value. If it were a reduction which allowed people to be elected to the Convention so that there were worthwhile representatives, from outside the parliaments, it would be worth reducing it. But that is not happening. In fact, it will be just a more cosy gathering of State and Federal members getting together and chloroforming the problem of constitutional reform. That is what I think it will do.
—We could not convince your Government and we have not been able to convince this Government.

—No, I know that we have not been able to convince them, and I intend to plug on trying to convince the people of this country that we need at least an elected component of people who are elected because they are interested primarily in constitutional reform and not just interested because they are members of parliament and are able to have a weekend away every two or three years to discuss these matters. Therefore, I look on the record which the Constitutional Convention has had as being very dismal.

SPEECH.PARA: On the last occasion on which we passed a resolution in regard to the exchange of powers, it was regarded as an innocuous one, but it was one which the Government completely ruined by bringing it on with an election campaign and using it as a foil for another proposal which was not nearly as popular. That has meant that the resolutions unanimously carried by the last Convention in Adelaide have been totally ignored by the people. So how one can proceed with a Convention of the same type but now with fewer members and expect it to be a success, I do not understand.

In my view, the cause of constitutional reform is at a very low ebb, and it is likely to get lower if, as Senator Macklin fears, this Constitutional Convention in Brisbane is unsuccessful. Therefore, I make a plea to the people of Australia to think about having a Constitutional Convention which includes an elected component, which is not just made up of a few members of parliament-and mostly State members at that-and which distorts the idea of representation throughout this country. Little is to be gained by this Convention.

So far as the amendment is concerned, apparently a deal has been done whereby the ratio is to be 7:5 between the representatives and the senators. I cannot see why there is not equality of representation between the House of Representatives and the Senate, because the Senate, if anything, has taken a more intelligent view on constitutional matters than has the House of Representatives. I am not claiming that there should be more Senate representatives than there are from the House of Representatives, but I think that there ought to be at least the same number. However, the Opposition has achieved some success in reducing that disproportionate number of 8:4 to 7:5, and I suppose that we must be thankful for small mercies.

I certainly do not oppose the amendment or the motion to carry on this Convention in the way that is proposed, but I express the view that this is really a sham in our dealing with constitutional change and that we are not achieving the effect that we might have. It is true that coming from the Convention have been reports of committees which involve excellent work. If that alone were the reason for having the Constitutional Convention, that would be some justification for having it meet every three years, because in the meanwhile its sub-committees are doing some good. But I think it is a very small and inadequate reason. The day must come when constitutional change is looked at sensibly instead of in the stupid way it has been looked at by this Parliament in the last couple of years, over which one must despair. I therefore take the view that we are going ahead with a new convention, having learned nothing for the experience of the last two years. I fear the consequences for constitutional reform in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposal for the Australian Constitutional Convention and the amendments which have been moved by my colleague Senator Durack. I have greater faith in constitutional review than have other senators who have spoken. I believe it is something which of necessity is slow. It ought to be slow. It ought to be the subject matter of very deep consideration and lengthy debate by those who are concerned to motivate change in the Constitution and to achieve understanding by the general populace of what is likely to be the result of any change proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The fate of so many of the earlier proposals for change has been determined by one of two things: Either there has been inadequate prior public debate on the proposals or the proposals have been openly and cynically party political or political in terms of the achievement of political objectives by the executive of the day. The public, God bless them, have had sufficient sense to realise that there have been reasons for concern and reasons for saying: 'No. Let's wait and hear a little more about this proposal'. I believe we have succeeded, in a short period, in having a greater number of amendments made to the Constitution than has been the record previously over the period since Federation, that is, a greater number since the Constitutional Convention came into being. We could have achieved more if we had spent less time on some of the controversial political issues and on the political issues which would have had advantage to an executive, to one House, to one parliament or to one section of government.

There is a large cross-section of areas for review. As my colleague Senator Missen has said, the committees of the Constitutional Convention have done a great deal of very valuable work during the periods between the holding of convention. That forms part of the ongoing consideration and debate which I regard as so essential an aspect of constitutional review. I do not adopt the term used, for instance, by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, when he talks about constitutional reform being necessary. I regard constitutional review as necessary. What is necessary within our total populace, within our democracy, is that we keep our Constitution under review and that the public be aware of those areas where some change may be needed, where there is debate as to whether change should take place. That should be distilled, as a result of the process of public debate, into a consensus view whereby a majority of people in a majority of States are prepared to support the change.

History has shown that it is possible to have sensible and desirable change take place. A number of constitutional amendments could be put up at this stage which would effect improvements to the Constitution and which would be carried without any difficulty. The proposals that do not get carried are those that are cynical. When a proposal for an amendment is put before the people of this country which has the history of, for instance, the proposal which has been the most controversial and which has been put backwards and forwards by various parties for what may be seen to be the advantage of the executive of the day, it is no wonder that the public of Australia have expressed their concern and their querulousness about it.

I simply wish to support warmly the desirability of the ongoing constitutional review process. I hope that it does not falter. I hope that people who are anxious to see a speedy change do not lose heart and, because we have not been able to achieve a magical reform either by 1988 or some other time, pack up and go home and leave the process altogether. It is desirable that the Constitution be reviewed. It is desirable that the review take place after full public consideration and full public debate and upon the basis of what is seen clearly to be a desirable change. So that we can identify these matters, it is desirable that the Constitutional Convention provide a focus and forum for that review on an ongoing basis. I warmly support the continuation of the Constitutional Convention.
Amendments agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1985CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1985 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1985. These Bills propose to amend the Excise Tariff Act and the Customs Tariff Act. I will deal, firstly, with the amendments to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. The Opposition is entirely in support of the proposals in this Bill. It proposes a number of alterations to the Excise Tariff Act, the principal one being the introduction of a new intermediate excise duty scale for crude oil. It also alters the rate of excise duty payable on liquefied petroleum gas and on fortified spirit. These alterations, particularly the latter one, give effect to earlier Budget decisions. I do not propose to take up the time of the Senate today going over that ground again. However, the introduction of the new intermediate excise scale for crude oil is important. The crude oil levy has been a major aspect of the import parity pricing policy which was introduced by the Fraser Government and has been continued by the present Government. It has been a major source of revenue for governments for some years.

SPEECH.PARA: The crude oil levy was originally introduced when the import parity pricing policy was adopted, to prevent the windfall profits which would have been received by the oil companies. These profits were creamed off and taken in the form of revenue by the Government. The method by which that was done was the crude oil levy. At the time of the introduction of the import parity pricing policy there was a very large discrepancy between the price that had been received by Australian crude oil producers and the world price of oil because of the oil shocks in 1973 and 1979. In order to correct the major windfall in profits that would have been received the excise duty was struck at a very high rate. I think the highest rate is about 87 per cent. The result was the very large revenues which governments have been receiving and are still receiving. Indeed, in the current year the crude oil levy will return about $3,700m to the Government. This is a very sizable share of revenue. As a result, a number of oil fields were subjected to that very high rate of levy. Pools of oil which had been discovered and which were subjected to that tax were simply not economic to develop. They were just left lying there and were being wasted because of the excessive nature of the levy.

This particular proposal introduces what is called the intermediate rate which is a significantly lower rate, although it varies in scale. The maximum level is 55c a barrel. This has already resulted in the major oil producers of Bass Strait investing heavily in the development of a number of these pools of oil which were not commercial propositions under the previous scale. They plan to invest a total of nearly $2 billion in the development of those pools. This will greatly increase Government revenues as well, but it is also a very profitable transaction for the oil producers. This is a satisfactory policy and one which the Opposition certainly supports.

I take the opportunity of mentioning that at the time that this was evolved the Government also abandoned the previous Government's policy of applying no excise or levy on new oil discoveries. That had been a very important feature of the import parity pricing policy of the Fraser Government in that although a high levy was struck on oil that had already been discovered, there was to be no levy on new discoveries or what is called new oil, both off-shore or on-shore. Because of that policy we had the very high level of exploration for oil both off-shore and on-shore in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Australia's self-sufficiency in oil was forecast to run out in the mid-1980s. Back in the late 1970s it was assumed that our self-sufficiency would last only until the mid-1980s. That has been extended into the early 1990s.

The introduction of a new oil levy takes some of the shine off the incentive to explore for new oil. The Opposition is very concerned that the Government introduced that levy. It did that by separate legislation; it is not part of this Bill. I mention it because although we are welcoming this provision in this Bill we are not happy at all with the Government's approach to the exploration for oil. Another example of that approach this session was the Government's proposal for cash bonus bidding for new oil exploration or new oil leases to be granted in the future in some areas. The Government was apparently banking on that as a revenue raising measure. It will raise another $40m or $50m from that levy. We are still awaiting the full details of the Government's resource rent tax proposals which were announced a year or so ago. They created a good deal of concern and uncertainty in the industry and are having only a negative effect on the exploration for oil. Although we support this measure we certainly express our opposition to and concern about other aspects of the Government's oil industry policy.

I turn to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. The amendments to the Customs Tariff Act are very extensive but the Opposition will support most of them. In summary, changes include giving effect to recent reports by the Industries Assistance Commission on separate articles direction No. 1; Government policies in relation to textiles, clothing and footwear; the motor vehicle plan and the steel plan. There are also a number of administrative amendments, the implementation phasing duties under the closer economic relations policy with New Zealand and some tariff simplification and the updating of the names of certain countries that are accorded preferential treatment in the Customs Tariff Act. There is one segment of the Bill dealing with certain consumer electronic equipment with which the Opposition has some concern. We believe this should be referred to a Senate committee for further investigation. In relation to most of these proposals, the Bill will result in a reduction of protection and a simplification of the tariff. Without going into details, the Opposition, for those good reasons, will support it.

The Government has decided to remove the 2 per cent revenue duty on components for use in ship repair and construction, which is subject to bounty provisions. This could be beneficial to the shipbuilding industry, which has been declining over a number of years. The Fraser Government introduced a bounty for that industry but under the bounty the expected rationalisation did not occur. There has been amended bounty legislation which it is hoped might alleviate this problem. The removal of the 2 per cent revenue duty will reduce the industry's costs and should help to make it more competitive.

I do not propose to debate again the textile, clothing and footwear policies which are implemented by this provision, the motor vehicle plan or the steel industry, except to say that the Opposition supports the provision that have been made in this Bill.

I turn to those provisions with which the Opposition is not happy-indeed it is concerned sufficiently to suggest that they need further consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade. We believe that there should be a report by that Committee in respect of colour televisions sets, which are dealt with in these provisions. Again, this has been the subject of an IAC report and the Government has endorsed the thrust of the IAC recommendations for most of the goods that were under reference. However, it rejected a specific recommendation on colour television sets. The Government decided to increase duty on colour television sets from 35 per cent to 50 per cent for one year and then phase it down to 20 per cent after three years; to introduce a quota of 50,000 on colour television sets measuring 47 centimetres or more when measured diagonally across the face of the picture tube; to introduce a concessional rate of duty of 30 per cent on quota imports; and for colour television sets less than 47 centimetres, to introduce a 25 per cent duty on implementation, phased down to 20 per cent after three years.

The overall effect of the Government's decision is the reduction of protection for all goods that are the subject of this category, but in the case of colour television sets of 47 centimetres or more, this reduction in protection will occur only after an initial increase in tariffs plus the quota. The imposition of the quota is designed to ease possible adjustment effects following the cessation of licensing agreements and a voluntary export restraint agreement with Japan. Although the industry generally supports the Government's decision, there is concern that the measurement criterion of the 47 centimetres diagonally across the face of the picture tube for quota purposes is not in accordance with international standards, which measure screen sizes according to viewable screen diagonal. So the effect of this definition will mean that 18-inch colour television sets will now come under quota whereas they were excluded under the previous voluntary export restraint agreement to which I have already referred. From the evidence available to the Opposition it appears there is a case for an alteration in the definition of the measurement. We are concerned about the effect of this and so is the industry. We think it is suitable for a reference to and quick report from the Senate Committee, which should investigate the facts of this matter. For those reasons the Opposition will move an amendment to the second reading motion in the terms that have been circulated. That amendment will have the effect of referring the Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note what Senator Durack has said about the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill and I do not think there is much that I can add, except to say that our sentiments are probably different. Nevertheless, I thank him for the Opposition's general support of that Bill. It may be appropriate for me to wait until the foreshadowed amendment to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill is moved before I deal with it. I understand that the Opposition otherwise supports the Bill.
—The Minister may speak to that now if he wishes. Both Bills are before the Chair.
—As long as the Opposition spokesman regards himself as having dealt with the amendment.
—Yes.
—The only matter remaining for Senator Durack is, as I understand it, to formally move the amendment.

—The Opposition has indicated that it generally accepts and supports the provisions of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. The question of the so-called capture of 18-inch colour television sets in the tariff quota has been the subject of a specific amendment. I wish to make it clear at the outset that the Government does not accept that amendment. This issue has been very carefully examined by the Government. I think Senator Durack said in a moment of inadvertence that the industry supported his amendment. I am not sure whether that is correct.
—I said that it was concerned with that provision in your Bill.

—I am concerned about what Senator Durack means by 'the industry'. I concede that perhaps one or two companies may have expressed concern but I do not think that that means the industry is concerned. In fact, I think the industry is well satisfied with the provisions of the legislation. Any alteration of the quota arrangements at this stage would not be in the best interests of and acceptable to importers and the industry generally, as distinct from perhaps one or two particular complainants.

SPEECH.PARA: The referral of this question to a Senate committee would resolve absolutely nothing. I do not know whether there is any point in my explaining the technical matters associated with the statistical key which is used in the Customs tariff to determine quota arrangements. However, let me make one or two points. There is no formal definition of an 18-inch set. The term is generic and refers to the approximate diagonal measurement of the tube. Importation of sets having a tube of greater than 47 centimetres was arguably outside Australia's understanding of the application of the voluntary restraint arrangement with Japan. For many years importers have knowingly or unknowingly classified their sets to the wrong statistical key.

I make the more important point that any reference to a Senate committee and a changing of the definition of the set subject to the quota would cause up to three months delay in informing importers of their advised allocation of quota and would subject importers and the whole of the manufacturing industry in Australia to unnecessary costs and uncertainty during this period. As the penalty rate of imports outside quota is being drastically reduced, the problem has to be seen in that perspective. The very fact that the quota arrangements have a relatively low penalty rate of duty for import outside quota provides considerable flexibility to individual importers. I make the point that this reference to a Senate committee is suggested in the context of the fact that the quota arrangements expire in October this year anyway. So at the end of May one would have a reference to a Senate committee in respect of a matter which is highly technical, which is not in the interests of the industry as a whole and which would lead perhaps to some deliberation and conclusion by a Senate committee in the Budget session which would not be relevant, in any event, from October when the quota arrangements expire.

There is a wide range of other reasons which make this proposed amendment inappropriate. However, the suggestion that a highly technical matter such as this should be referred to a Senate committee is wrong. It is wrong in the implications it would have for industry. It would be highly disruptive. It is wrong because of its timing in terms of the expiry of the quota in October this year. For those reasons the proposed amendment will not be accepted by the Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1985SALES TAX (No. 5) AMENDMENT BILL 1985SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL (No. 10) 1985SALES TAX BILL (No. 10A) 1985SALES TAX BILL (No. 10B) 1985SALES TAX BILL (No. 10C) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports part of this package of Bills, consisting of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill and related Bills, and is concerned about other parts of it. In summary, we believe that there are parts which were foreshadowed by the former Treasurer in the previous Government more than two and a half years ago and which this Government has been somewhat lethargic in taking up, and that there are other parts which are entirely new, the ramifications of which certainly concern a significant section of a significant industry in Australia. We are concerned to see that those parts are properly studied and that the industry has a proper opportunity for consultation before the Bills are passed by this House and brought into effect. We therefore propose a measure which I will outline in detail a little later, by means of which the House could pass the whole of the legislation. We propose that the legislation be divided into those parts upon which we are agreed-those which would overcome fraud and avoidance of existing sales tax requirements and which would come into force immediately-and those parts which would introduce new laws and for which we believe an opportunity for consideration should be given.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is just to say that after this Government's lethargy in relation to sales tax over nearly two and a half years there is now a rush to introduce new sections in what I regard as almost indecent haste. I find it in passing curious that the Government is prepared, through the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Mr Hurford, on behalf of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to see at I think 4.30 this afternoon sections of the industry concerned. He has an appointment to see them to discuss the problems in relation to the proposals, yet the Government wants these Bills to go through before the industry has had a chance to make its representations to the Government in relation to the problems it sees, which I will explain in a moment.

Let me go through the package of Bills and give an overall explanation of them as I understand them. They will curtail certain sales tax evasion practices that have developed by the misuse of sales tax certificate numbers allowing people who should not be able to purchase goods tax free to do so. This evasion practice is presently estimated to cost up to $200m annually. The Opposition supports the measures which are proposed to prevent that from taking place. There is no question about it, we wholeheartedly support that. The Bill will close off a practice whereby wholesalers who technically become retailers under an agency of a similar retail selling plan and avoid paying sales tax on their wholesale profit margin and any royalties payable-that is, pay sales tax on their purchase prices, not their selling prices and thus pay less sales tax than they should. These are measures which aim to ensure that the wholesalers pay a fair wholesale market value on goods sold under such arrangements known as agency schemes and floor-plan arrangements. It is estimated that this practice also involves revenue losses of the order of $200m annually.

The measures also will implement a number of reforms to the sales tax system which the former Treasurer foreshadowed in August 1981. They include enabling the Commissioner of Taxation to recover up to $1m in sales tax avoided by manufacturers who, since that date, have sought to take advantage of a weakness in the present definition of the word 'manufacture' and putting an end to certain avoidance schemes where royalties payable are excluded from the sale value of goods and tax is not paid on them. The cost to revenue has been estimated at approximately $25m and the legislation will prevent further losses.

I do not think I need to take up the time of the chamber in dealing with the misuse of sales tax certificates, but let me summarise by saying that the Australian Taxation Office claims that more often than not the vendors turn a blind eye to the false quotations which are given. The measures in this Bill to prevent this include: The level of security for compliance with the conditions of registration is to be increased to a maximum of $25,000 from the present level of $2,000, which was set some 55 years ago; the Commissioner will be able to call for security if he thinks revenue is at risk; the Commissioner will be given the power to refuse or revoke a sales tax registration where the information is false or misleading or where security is not provided when required; the Commissioner will be able to withdraw permission to quote if he believes the procedure has been abused by the person in the past; the Commissioner will be able to publish a list of those who have had their certificates revoked, et cetera; and the vendor will need to be satisfied that the purchaser is a registered person, that the quotation is authorised by law, that the quotation is not false or misleading and that the Commissioner has not notified that the certificate number has been revoked, and if the vendor sells the goods tax free despite having reasonable grounds to believe that any of the above grounds were not met the vendor will be liable to pay the tax. In relation to this there may be some practical difficulties with regard to the onus of proof and other matters. I believe that at the Committee stage we need to pay some attention to certain aspects of the way in which notification will be available to people so that they can obtain the information which they are required to have to ensure that they do not place themselves in a position of being liable to pay tax.

I now refer to sales tax minimisation by indirect marketing methods. The sales tax law is structured so that the sale to the retailer-that is the taxable sale-is for a price that includes all the costs incurred by and the profit margins of each party in the distribution chain up to, but not including, the retailer. Indirect marketing arrangements seek to eliminate the wholesaler's profit margin from the sale value of the goods. One arrangement-an agency arrangement-moves back the point in the marketing chain at which the taxable sale takes place. This arrangement eliminates the wholesaler's profit margin from the sale value of the goods sold by retail and the sales tax payable is, accordingly, that much lower.

In another equally artificial retail marketing arrangement the wholesaler could acquire an interest in a section of a traditional retail store from which goods might be sold direct to the public. Again, the wholesaler technically acquires the mantle of a retailer and the wholesaler's profit margin is not subject to sales tax, as it should be. In practice, indirect marketing arrangements mean that goods can be sold to the public at considerable savings in sales tax. Those who engage in these arrangements can therefore achieve an unfair competitive advantage in the market-place, to the detriment of the revenue and those taxpayers who, on principle, choose not to be a party to such arrangements.

On the other hand, some businesses have, for many years and for genuine commercial reasons, sold their goods to the public through indirect marketing arrangements, such as agency arrangements. Although sales tax reduction is not a motive for these agency sales, the revenue is affected in precisely the same manner and to the same extent. The Bill proposes to counter these practices by inserting a new definition of the words 'wholesale merchant' which includes as wholesalers those who sell goods by retail under an indirect marketing plan. In this way a deemed fair wholesale mark-up in such cases will be included. Other measures are the measures to tighten up to which I have referred.

The main area of concern which we have about this large and complex package is that a considerable section of the industry involved believes that it has reasonable grounds for concern as to the impact which the legislation will have on legitimate business. Whilst cleaning up business which, it is agreed by everybody, pursues undesirable practices and tax avoidance measures, the legislation could also have a major impact on direct selling-one of the major growth areas in the retail marketing sector. That is not, possibly, the intended impact, but it could put out of business a number of major sectors of industry to which I will refer in a moment. So, the problem is the practical implementation of the measures. We express our concern that not sufficient opportunity has been given to legitimate business to express its concern to the Government and other people involved in the consideration of this legislation, including the Opposition, the other non-government party-the Australian Democrats-and the Independent senator.

One expression of very considerable concern comes from within the recording industry. Basically, that industry, representing the record and tape manufacturing interests, believes not only that the whole industry, employing some 2,500 people in the manufacturing and marketing sector, is in jeopardy but also that significant sections of it could fold completely if this legislation is implemented in its present form. That industry's concern has been expressed in telegrams, telexes and written representations which have been made in the past few days. As I mentioned earlier, only later this afternoon will it be given by the Government a chance to put its case to the Government. By that time, if the Government's program is achieved, these Bills will have been through the Senate and they will already be law.

Further representations have been made by the Direct Selling Association of Australia, which has expressed its extreme concern. It says that, whilst it does not hold with fraud and the fraudulent misuse of the sales tax provisions, it believes that the present method of implementation will destroy the direct selling industry in the process. I will quote briefly from today's Australian to give some idea of what we are talking about. On page 14 an article headed 'Direct Marketing. Age of sophisticated sales' states:
Direct marketing across the world is outgrowing and, in many instances, out-performing traditional methods of promoting corporate products and services in the marketplace. . . .
A growth rate of 25 per cent is expected to be attained this year through established clients expanding their budgets and also those which have been lured by direct marketing.

Manufacturers and people in the industry are gearing up for a major expansion of a new and vital part of the retail sector. They believe that they will be adversely affected very seriously as a result of the way in which these measures are being implemented.

A paper which I believe summarises the situation extremely well-because it has been well considered I will read it rather than summarising the situation myself-has been prepared by Arthur Young and Co. It is headed 'Indirect Taxes Bulletin' and dated 10 May 1985. It summarises the major sales tax changes. Under the sub-heading 'Indirect Marketing Arrangements' it states:
The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1985 introduces a new concept of 'indirect marketing arrangement'.

Essentially, the relevant amendments are designed to impose a new sales tax on the retail sale of goods sold through such an arrangement. This legislation will take effect from the date of Royal Assent.

Although the Treasurer has identified two arrangements on which the legislation will impact, that is 'agency' arrangements and what he refers to as 'floor plan' arrangements, the new law will impact on many retailers not currently liable to sales tax and is clearly designed to significantly boost the revenue.

The new legislation extends the definition of 'wholesale merchant' to 'a person who sells goods under an indirect marketing arrangement'. A new sub-section 3 (4A) in Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) will define an indirect marketing arrangement in the following way:-

'A reference in this Act to a person selling goods under an indirect marketing arrangement is a reference to a person (in this sub-section referred to as the 'vendor'), who is not the manufacturer of the goods, selling goods by retail-

(a) under an arrangement that provides, directly or indirectly, for the sale of goods (whether ascertained or not) by the vendor through another person acting for and on behalf of the vendor, whether in the name of the vendor or in any other name, but not being an employee of the vendor; or
(b) from premises that-
(i) are used principally for the sale of goods by retail by any other person or persons; and
(ii) are held out to be premises of, or used by, the other person or persons.'

A person who is a wholesale merchant by virtue of selling goods under an indirect marketing arrangement will be required to be registered for sales tax purposes and to pay sales tax in respect of retail sales on a sale value determined as the amount which would be the fair market value of those goods if sold by him by wholesale.
The amending legislation, as presented by the Treasurer, is incomplete and requires complementary amendments to the Sales Tax Regulations, as foreshadowed in the Explanatory Memorandum.

The impact of this legislation is, again, very broad. Every retailer who sells goods through agents or independent representatives (not being employees) may be required to be registered and to pay sales tax in respect of his retail sales. Similarly, a person who sells his own goods by retail from another person's retail premises may be deemed to be a wholesale merchant and required to pay sales tax on his retail sales.

Mr Keating has introduced this new sales tax on retail sales under the general banner of anti-sales tax avoidance legislation, but it is clearly intended to impose a new tax on many commercial transactions not previously taxed and which were never intended to fall within the ambit of the sales tax legislation.

That quote from the paper by Arthur Young and Co. sets out the situation in fairly precise terms. What it boils down to is that we have a situation in which people such as Avon ladies will be adversely affected. In fact, it is claimed-and I am not in a position to make an assessment of the accuracy or otherwise of the claim-that it will put them out of business. It is claimed that Tupperware parties, a well known feature of Australian society and Australian marketing, will become a thing of the past. This will have unfortunate implications for both our social arrangements and the marketing which is able to take place through that method. They are just two examples of the sorts of problems that it is believed will arise. I have here a telegram from the Corporate Affairs Manager of Amway of Australia Pty Ltd. It reads:

The proposed Sales Tax Amendment Bill 1985 has recently been brought to our attention together with the fact that the Bill is scheduled to be reviewed in the Senate tomorrow Wednesday May 22nd. As provisions in the Bill would force upon this company an excessive tax burden which would necessarily result in a substantial increase in the price of our products, jeopardise the occupations of tens of thousands of Amway distributors and threaten the jobs of about 200 permanent employees, we urgently request that you seek reference of the Bill to a Senate Committee for detailed review so that the full impact of its provisions can be properly assessed.

That sets out Amway's concern. I do not propose to go through all of the representations that have been made, but just to give some examples. I am informed that overall the direct selling industry has some 120,000 distributors in Australia. There has also been a large investment by people who have tooled up factories to produce goods and staffed offices under the development to which I referred and which is referred to in the Australian today. This major expansion has taken place in this area of retailing in Australia.
The records industry has also made representations. I read a telex which I received from the Executive Director of the Australian Record Industry Association. It states:

The Australian record industry urgently requests your support in opposing passage of this Bill in the Senate until opportunity to consult with record industry regarding seriously damaging effects of legislation on our industry and ancillary industries.
Legislation as drafted will create destructive long and short term problems for the industry including:
1. immediate increase in price to consumer of up to 25%.
2. irreparable harm to TV record companies . . . and direct mail companies . . . budget record companies and record clubs.
3. legislation will inevitably lead to loss of employment in the record manufacturing industry and ancillary industries.
4. damage to the industry would severely jeopardise the development opportunities of local recording artists and composers.

Given the damaging effects of this legislation the record industry is dismayed at the absence of Government-industry consultation which could reasonably have been expected to precede such legislation.

ARIA has consistently adopted the view that sound recordings as 'culture carriers' should not be levied at the luxury level of 32.5% for the purposes of sales tax. In levying this amount the Government discriminates in its treatment of sound recordings when compared to other cultural items such as books, sheet music, musical scores and films.

Given complete lack of consultation by the Government on this damaging legislation, the record industry urgently requests that representatives of the industry be given the opportunity to discuss the legislation with you before it is enacted.

I indicate, as I have indicated before and will indicate again, that I do not believe that we are in a position to assess accurately and in detail, with the notice we have had, whether the claims are valid, or the significance and ramifications of what has been put forward to us. These are matters which the Government, had it been more diligent, could have introduced in time for the industry to be consulted and to make representations. I read from a telex from the Record Retailers Association, which states:
On behalf of Australia's 2,500 record retailers, we wish to register our deepest concern regarding the introduction of the above legislation.
That is, the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 10). It continues:

If it is passed not only are our members livelihoods affected but also the very existence of the entire music industry including record companies, manufacturers, recording artists, publishers, printers, and writers. The total music industry employing tens of thousands of people is in jeopardy.
We request you meet representatives of the music business to discuss the drastic repercussions from such a Bill.
I give one other example from a different section of the industry, and that is a telex from the General Manager of Jafra Cosmetics, which states:
Am amazed firstly at the direction and secondly at the speed with which the Government is proceeding regarding the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1985.
As a company which provides income for technically untrained people from all walks of life we respectfully ask that you consider the serious implications to these people's livelihoods.
Representation will be made through the Direct Selling Association of Australia. Please grant them a hearing before taking further action.

That is what the sections of the industry which are affected have been asking us all: Can they be heard before these Bills proceed? The answer from the Government is yes, they can be heard, but after the Bills have proceeded. The Opposition does not believe that is good enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet you don't believe all those claims you have just read out.

—I am not expressing a personal view of acceptance or otherwise of every claim that has been made. What I am objecting to is that I have not had the opportunity to consult and find out whether I should accept all of the representations that have been made, or parts of them, or none of them at all. I believe we have within this Parliament a system whereby in such instances we can permit people who are genuinely concerned about the ramifications of legislation which comes before the Parliament to have an opportunity to be heard and to put their case. That is what the Senate committee system is for. That is why we have a legislative and general purpose standing committee system; so that we can refer Bills to committees to be considered and reported upon by people who have had the opportunity to consider the ramifications. I find it a matter of great concern that this industry, significant as it obviously is, employing large numbers of people in Australia, which has very large investments and very significant implications for various aspects of other socio-economic activities in the country, will not be heard before the Government proceeds with the Bills. We have attempted to provide a solution.

SPEECH.PARA: I foreshadow that in the Committee stage I will move amendments firstly, to enable the whole of the legislation to be passed and secondly, to differentiate between the commencement dates of the legislation. That is not something novel which I propose. There are already within this legislation differentiations between the commencement dates of various portions of it. We propose that those parts which deal with the avoidance, as to which notice has been given, should commence as proposed; retrospectively, either from the date of the announcement or the date of the passage or proclamation. The other parts, on which concern is expressed in relation to the ramifications, which I have not dealt with at any length because I do not have time-that is, the royalties aspects and indirect or direct selling aspects-should come into force by Act of Parliament. The Bill will be passed but the coming into force of those parts on a certain date will require a further Act. In other words, what we are proposing is rather different from a sunset clause; it is a sunrise clause. We propose that the legislation be considered after it has been approved and that the date on which it will come into force be subject to the approval of both Houses of Parliament. That would enable those parts of the Bill which have caused concern to be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade for consideration and report. If the Opposition amendments are supported, I propose to move a motion which I foreshadow, that the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry and Trade:

The provisions of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1985 relating to sales tax on royalties and on goods sold through indirect marketing schemes, and the provisions of the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 10) 1985, the Sales Tax Bill (No. 10A) 1985, the Sales Tax Bill (No. 10B) 1985 and the Sales Tax Bill (No. 10C) 1985.

The notice of motion which was circulated in my name erroneously refers to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and should not do so. I take the opportunity to make it clear that I propose that the matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry and Trade.

The Opposition supports measures to cut out fraud and the avoidance of sales tax. We support the steps which were proposed by us when we were in government. We criticise the Government for being somewhat lethargic in implementing our proposals. We also criticise the Government for proceeding with somewhat indecent haste with the new sales tax measures. Their full ramifications have caused concern to a very significant section of the industry and the possible implications are not necessarily those which were intended by the Government when introducing the legislation. We believe that an opportunity should be given for such matters to be considered after the legislation has been passed but before it comes into effect so that the Parliament will have a report from the Senate Committee to consider before the legislation becomes fully operative. On that basis, the Opposition will support the second reading of the Bill but will move amendments at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I should go into the details of Senator Peter Rae's proposed amendments and the Government's response to them at the second reading stage or the Committee stage. There are basically two objectives in the sales tax Bills: Firstly, to end the straight-out sales tax evasion practices through false quotation of numbers, which has the Opposition's unqualified support; and, secondly, to put a stop to the variety of avoidance measures which have recently been detected. The revenue effects if the Bills are passed would be an increase of $200m.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition seeks to defer the implementation of the measures relating to tax avoidance until the Standing Committee on Industry and Trade has had a chance to hear representations from the industry. There has been a good deal of misunderstanding about the way in which the relevant amendments in the Bill would operate. There is, I presume, an inadvertent error in the amendments forecast and circulated by Senator Peter Rae. I do not know whether I should go into this matter now or later on but the effect of the proposed amendments would be to erode entirely, until such time as the legislation was proclaimed, the taxation base for royalties and similar payments. That is because the royalty provisions in sub-section 3 (3) of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) are being repealed by paragraph (d) of sub-clause 4 (1), which I think is on page 3 of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill. The Opposition amendments leave the repeal of the existing provision unaffected but defer the enactment of the replacement and tightened up provisions. I assume that that was not the intention, but that, I am advised, will be the effect. Even from a fairly superficial examination and to an untrained eye, it seems to me that that would certainly be the case. That is the most substantial matter. On those grounds alone the proposed amendments would not be acceptable to the Government. Even without that inadvertent effect, the amendments proposed by the Opposition are still not acceptable.

Essentially, the tax avoidance practices which have been operating in recent years relate to transfer pricing. Companies not truly at arm's length arrange that the recorded wholesale sales price on which the tax is levied is not in fact the true arm's length price, and the profits are effectively transferred from the wholesale section of a company or a related group of companies into the retail section.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we support cutting that out.

—Senator Rae has acknowledged that the Opposition supports that principle. There are businesses that quite genuinely operate wholesale and retail components in an integrated way without any intention necessarily of avoiding tax in the process. That seems to have been the substantial point raised in the letters from Arthur Young and from others that Senator Rae quoted. The alarmist predictions of the effect of this legislation, even if it were to operate in the way that Arthur Young and others apparently believe it will, cannot be taken seriously. Those predictions are not endorsed by Senator Rae, who has said that he will reserve his judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: The alarmist tone of the letters from which Senator Rae quoted reminds me of the alarmist tones of representations which were received by and read out in the Senate about eight months ago when the Government introduced a 10 per cent wholesale tax on wine. The predictions of doom and disaster about the effect of the wine tax on the wine industry have not been realised any more than the predictions of doom and disaster for Amway of Australia and others, and for whole industries, will be realised if the Bill presently before the Senate has the effect that people who sent those letters to Senator Rae believe it will have. The point is that the Bill will not have that effect.

Where there is a genuinely integrated wholesale and retail component within a business, it has long been a matter for the discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation to deem a wholesale price upon which tax will be levied. People may raise doubts about resorting to that means of enforcing the sales tax laws, but it seems to me that there is no alternative other than to give the Commissioner the discretion to deem a fair and reasonable wholesale price. By definition it is entirely an in-house transaction and the only other alternative would be to deem that what is intended to be a wholesale sales tax be levied on the retail price. It appears that Arthur Young and the other people who have sent letters to Senator Rae believe that that will happen, but it will not. The sales tax will be levied not on the retail price but on what the Commissioner deems to be a fair and reasonable wholesale price under those circumstances. To go back to the wine industry precedent, precisely that was done for wineries, which are both wholesalers and retailers and in many cases original producers as well. The Commissioner deemed a wholesale price which I understand is generally in the order of 60 per cent to 70 per cent of the retail price.

Most of the objections to the immediate implementation of this legislation have been based on the false premise that in the case of a genuinely integrated business the tax will be levied on the retail price. If the enforcement of these provisions is delayed in the way Senator Rae intends them to be delayed, the revenue loss will be of the order of $550,000 a day, based on an estimated total cost of these sorts of avoidance practices of $200m a year. If the unintended effect of Senator Rae's proposed amendments is to wipe out the whole tax base for royalties and similar payments, the revenue leakage will very very much greater than that.

It might be possible for Senator Rae to fix up technically the unintended effect of his proposed amendments, but the fact remains that there is an estimated leakage of $550,000 for every day that the proclamation of the amendments in this Bill is delayed. If there were sufficiently sound reasons for taking the action he recommends the Government might contemplate it, but the reasons advanced so far, as far as I can tell, are based entirely upon the false premise that a sales tax will be levied, at whatever the appropriate rate is, on the retail figure instead of the deemed wholesale figure in the case of a genuinely integrated business.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has before it six Bills. Amendments have been distributed in connection with the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1985 and the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 10) 1985. Would it suit the convenience of the Committee if these Bills were considered first? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1985, page 32, Schedule, before the amendment of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 insert the following amendment: Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 Schedule 1-
Omit from paragraph (e)-
''Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) 1930
Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 2) 1930
Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 3) 1930
Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 4) 1930
Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 5) 1930
Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 6) 1930
Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 7) 1930
Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 8) 1930
Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 9) 1930''
Substitute-
''Acts providing for the assessment of sales tax''.'.
Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 10) 1985, page 2, clause 3, lines 1 to 4, leave out the definition of 'goods', insert the following definition: ' ''goods'' includes-
(a) commodities; and
(b) goods or commodities which have gone into use or consumption in Australia,

but does not include goods or commodities in respect of which a person has become liable to pay tax before 10 May 1985 (whether or not the tax has become due and payable before that date) under an Act providing for the assessment of sales tax;'.
The amendments are understood, so I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard speeches on the amendments to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1985 and the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 10) 1985.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1985
This amendment is of a technical nature.
The Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 10) 1985 (together with the 3 complementary Taxing Bills) will counter certain sales tax avoidance practices concerning the payment of royalties.

The proposed new Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 10) 1985 necessitates a number of consequential amendments of other Commonwealth Statutes that refer to the existing nine Sales Tax Assessments Acts. Clause 61 of the Bill effects these amendments.

Under Schedule 1 to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 decisions under certain acts, including certain decisions under taxation acts, are precluded from review through the system of review provided for by that Act.

Decisions under the new Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 10) are also to be excluded from the purview of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, consistent with the position that prevails in relation to decisions under other taxation laws.

However, a person liable for sales tax on a royalty who is dissatisfied with an assessment or decision by the Commissioner affecting the sale value of the royalty will have available full rights of objection and appeal ultimately, if the matter warrants it, to the Federal and High Courts.

Other taxation laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation that provide similar rights to contest liability are also excluded from review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.
However, the relevant provision of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 was inadvertently not included in Clause 61 of the Bill and this amendment will correct that oversight.
I commend the amendment to the Committee.
SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL (No. 10) 1985

The Bill as introduced will ensure that royalties paid in connection with the manufacture, sale or lease of goods, but under arrangements that have the effect of excluding such royalties from the taxable sale value of the goods, will not escape the payment of sales tax.

The measures contained in the Bill are intended to apply to royalty payments made after 9 May 1985, that being the date the measures were announced when the treasurer introduced the Bill into the Parliament.
It has been drawn to the Government's attention that the Bill could have a potentially retrospective operation in cases where royalties are paid in arrears.

To the extent that a royalty, paid on or after 10 May 1985, is paid in respect of goods sold before that date, the tax payable on the royalty would not have been recovered as part of the price for which the goods were sold. It is fundamental to the concept of the sales tax that it is 'passed on' to the ultimate purchaser as part of the purchase price. In the situation I have just mentioned the tax on the royalty would, because it was not recovered in the selling price of the goods, have to be borne by the person paying the royalty.
It was always intended by the government that these particular measures would operate on a wholly prospective basis.

The amendment will, therefore, remove any possible element of retrospectivity. The amendment will mean that the proposed tax on royalties paid in respect of goods will only apply to royalties paid on or after 10 May 1985, where the goods on which the royalties are payable pass the taxing point on or after that date.
I commend the amendment to the Committee.
