TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1985 contains a package of a variety of taxation measures which I shall briefly outline. It includes a measure to abolish the 30:20 rule which requires life assurance companies and two categories of superannuation funds to hold at least 30 per cent of their assets in public securities, including at least 20 per cent in Commonwealth securities, in order to be eligible for special tax concessions; the proposal to abolish that was announced in September last year. The Bill contains a measure to counter further tax avoidance schemes of the expenditure recoupment type. It contains a measure to phase in personal income tax and to introduce full company tax and the Medicare levy on Christmas Island from the commencement of the 1985-86 income year, which decision was announced on 10 April 1985. It includes a measure to permit the Commissioner of Taxation to make available to the Australian Statistician for statistical purposes certain information in respect of business taxpayers and a measure to achieve consistency between the provisions of the pay as you earn and the prescribed payments systems by extending the objection and appeal rights available in relation to certain PPS penalties to corresponding penalties under the PAYE provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, it corrects a drafting error in the provisions extending eligibility for the dependent spouse rebate to de facto couples, which had the unintended effect of denying a part-year entitlement to a daughter-housekeeper rebate where the taxpayer contributes to the maintenance of a spouse, whether legal or de facto, during some other part of the year of income.

An inadvertent amendment to the taxation legislation had an effect of disqualifying a section from something that was intended. Without casting aspersions reflecting on the vote of the Senate, I refer to the debate we have just had on the sales tax amendments. I express the hope that we do not find that the same sort of inadvertence has the effect that we have to bring in legislation at a later stage to try to patch it up. Also included in the package are measures to exclude payments of social security family income supplement from the separate net income of a dependant for concessional rebate purposes and to make a number of formal amendments to reflect changes in the machinery of government to effect some minor drafting changes and to repeal redundant provisions relating to Commonwealth and State public servants appointed to Taxation Boards of Review. The position is that the Opposition either supports these measures or does not oppose them. In other words, we will not be voting against the Bill, whilst we have some reservations on some aspects. We say it is a matter for the Government.

There are other aspects which we warmly support. Let me deal with them. First, the abolition of the 30:20 rule is very near and dear to my heart, having advocated this for very many years. I believe the justification for the 30:20 rule which required a quid pro quo for the taxation concession which was given for the purpose of encouraging savings and encouraging people to make life assurance provision for their families should be subject to a taxation incentive; that is, a taxation expenditure for the Government and the taxpayer and a taxation benefit for the person who was benefiting from the rule. The quid pro quo was that some of the funds had to be lent back to the Government to ensure that in a capital short country-as we were and still are, but to a much lesser extent-there was a flow of this form of personal savings back into the market where it would be available for the purposes of loans to government. That, I believe, was an eminently sensible provision at the time it was introduced. However, things have changed. It was interesting to note that the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, in its final report at page 335, referred to the 30:20 requirement. Paragraph 20.33 states:

It has been argued that, to a degree, the 30/20 requirement may have helped maintain the quality of the assets held by some life insurance companies, particularly the smaller ones. If a policy with a twenty-year run to maturity is matched by government securities of similar maturity, it is suggested that fluctuations in the market price during the time to maturity are immaterial.
Paragraph 20.34 states:

The Committee does not accept this view. The matching of assets and liabilities by term would be of little comfort if, in times of high interest rates, large numbers of policy holders sought to surrender policies backed by government securities issued in the past at low interest rates. It should also be recognised that, by forcing life offices to accept something less than a market rate on a substantial proportion of their investments, the 30/20 requirement has impacted adversely on the competitive position of life offices in financial markets. This may, in at least some instances, have led them to undertake more risky but higher yielding investments.

The comments I made a moment ago I believe are particularly apposite to that reference. What was a very thin capital market is still a relatively thin market. It is developing and the measures which were recommended, the implementation of which had commenced under the previous Government-I compliment the present Government for having continued with the measures for deregulation of our financial markets-are a reflection of the increased depth and the increased sophistication of our markets. Australia has reached a stage where it can avoid the sorts of restrictions and special channelling of funds and the imposition of relatively restricted lower interest rate earnings with regard to these funds which were reflected in the requirements of the 30:20 rule.

I have not taken as long as I would have liked to talk about the implications of the 30:20 rule and the capital market, but perhaps we ought to be paying a little more attention than we have in the past to some other areas of the market such as the unit trust area, which has some considerable difficulties which need attention, rather than to the life and superannuation funds area. This is basically covered by fairly clear regulatory systems-a prudential system of sufficient validity to enable the Campbell Committee and the Opposition to recommend the abolition of the 30:20 rule and to enable the Government to put forward this measure, which we happily support.

I refer to measures to counter expenditure recoupment schemes of tax avoidance. The former Treasurer on 24 September 1978 announced the crackdown on various types of tax avoidance schemes involving round robins and the artificial creation of losses. The general thread of these schemes was for a taxpayer or associate to be compensated in a non-taxable way for loss or outgoing sought to be deducted. These schemes have become known as expenditure recoupment schemes. The announcement of 24 September 1978 was as follows:
. . . further schemes emerge that feature elements common to the schemes covered by this statement . . . further legislation will be introduced . . . effective as from today.

This warning has been acted upon since that date at least once by the former Liberal-National Party coalition Government. The announcement that was made in September 1978 was part of the crackdown by the former coalition Government on tax avoidance which led the Commissioner of Taxation to say in his report for the year 1983-84 that one of the great success stories of the last decade has been the elimination of the artificialities of the tax avoidance industry. I believe the coalition Government can be justly proud as it started to identify the avoidance measures. There was a range of talent of very considerable magnitude against Government. It became a major industry which employed some of the best brains in the country in devising schemes for tax avoidance. The government of the day was determined that action would be taken to crack down on this, as was said by the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, in September 1978. Measures were steadily taken to crack down. As the Commissioner of Taxation said in 1983, at the start of the new Government, the great success story over the past decade was the crack-down that had been achieved by the former Government.

The Bill acts on the warning which was given by the former Treasurer on 24 September 1978 to catch variants of the scheme that have recently come to light. The amendments apply to agreements entered into after 24 September 1978 and before the introduction of Part IVA of the Act on 27 May 1981. The amendments are consistent with our approach to retrospective taxation as they apply only after the date of an appropriate warning announcement. The potential revenue from this measure is estimated to be $25m. I emphasise that the Opposition is opposed to retrospective legislation where people have no reasonable basis for knowing what the law was or would be. Where a clear warning has been given that it is the intention to legislate with respect to certain matters, it is fair to date the legislation from the date of the warning being given. The warning was clear and unequivocal, so we support this particular provision.

We do not oppose the introduction of income tax on Christmas Island. At present the residents of the Territories of Christmas, Norfolk and Cocos (Keeling) Islands are exempt from income tax on income derived from sources outside mainland Australia. This includes income of companies or trusts, as long as they are incorporated, owned and controlled by Territory residents. In practical terms, genuine residents of the Territories are subject to tax only on income earned in mainland Australia. After this Bill has been passed, Christmas Island residents, including companies and trusts, will be treated like residents of mainland Australia for tax purposes as from the current income year, 1985-86. Income tax will be phased in over three years but company tax and the Medicare levy will apply in full as from the end of 1985-86. The amendments will not affect the residents of Norfolk Island or Cocos (Keeling) Islands in respect of incomes from those two Territories or sources outside mainland Australia, but it will mean that any income they earn from sources in Christmas Island will be taxable.

These amendments are part of a package to integrate Christmas Island with the rest of Australia. Revenue from these changes is estimated to be $1m in the first year, rising to $4.4m and then to $6m in 1988-89 when the three-year phasing-in period is completed. This will be offset by other aspects of the island integration package. The package is well known and the general proposals in relation to the integration of Christmas Island with mainland Australia have been debated in the Senate recently. Of course it is understood and expected that, as part of the package, Christmas Islanders would be treated as are other Australians for taxation purposes.

The next measure concerns disclosure of information to the Australian Statistician. I do not wish to say anything in detail on that matter other than that there will be a significant additional administrative cost, estimated at some $400,000 in a full year. In not opposing that, we would hope that there will be benefits obtained as a result of the provision of information which will offset and justify in any cost-benefit analysis the extra cost involved.

The amendment on the matter of objection and appeal rights in relation to certain penalties is reasonably straightforward. The amendment is designed to correct an oversight which has existed. It will not extend the objection and appeal rights to the remission decisions in relation to the 20 per cent per annum late payment penalties imposed for breaches of either PAYE or the prescribed payments provisions of the law. It is arguable that they should be extended in this way and that all decisions of the Commissioner to remit or not remit penalties should be subject to objection and appeal. I raise that matter but I do not intend to press the point by way of amendment. I draw it to the Government's attention because it is a matter which should certainly be taken into account. Whilst we do not oppose the measure, we point that out.

The provisions on interest on refunded prescribed payments or PAYE penalties will include those prescribed payments and PAYE penalties that are to be made subject to objection and appeal procedures by other parts of the Bill in categories of taxes where interest is payable by the Commissioner of Taxation and where refunds are made available following a successful objection or appeal. That is obvious and of course we support it.

The amendment on rebates for dependants is a measure to correct a drafting error in one of the provisions of the Income Tax Amendment Act of last year. I will not detain the Senate to discuss that in detail other than to point out that it is a correction of something that was unintended. There are also changes concerning the family income supplement. As the law now stands the supplement, which is an income tested allowance payable to low income families with children and which is exempt from tax in the hands of the recipient, is not excluded from the separate net income test for purposes of dependant rebates. This would result in an unintended reduction in the amount of rebate that would otherwise be allowable to a taxpayer for a dependent spouse compared with the situation that existed previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. In light of the uncertainty and confusion surrounding the pensions assets test, has Cabinet yet decided on changes to remove at least some of the anomalies and inequities in the test? If so, can the Minister tell the Senate what those changes will be? Does the Government intend to bring amending legislation into the Parliament before the winter recess?

—As I intimated the other day, Cabinet has considered some modifications to the assets test as it affects rural pensioners. Some changes have already been made. The speed and effectiveness of valuations are increasing. Changes are being made to the hardship provisions. The matter has not been finalised, as I understand it, by the Minister for Social Security. Any changes will be announced by him. I am not sure of the exact date. There is no need for legislation to bring about such changes.

—Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that Press reports of his recent statements to the Australian Institute of Petroleum have caused concern among petroleum refinery workers who fear that their refineries might be closed as a result of the imminent deregulation of the petroleum industry? What are the long term prospects for the job security of Australian refinery workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, of course, aware of Press comments stemming from my recent address to the Australian Institute of Petroleum, particularly with regard to the possible further rationalisation of the Australian refining industry in the event of the introduction of a free market for crude oil. Let me stress at the outset that the Government has not made any decisions on this matter as to whether a free market should be introduced and, if so, in what form and when. It will do so only in light of the responses we receive to the discussion paper which I released canvassing all the relevant issues in detail following that address to the Institute of Petroleum. That discussion paper of a couple of weeks ago identified numerous issues that will have to be resolved before the Government considers a decision on a modified free market. One of those issues is, of course, the effect on the Australian refining industry.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say that views differ greatly about what the likely effect of the free market would be on the refining industry. Some hold the view that there would be increased pressure on refineries such as those in Brisbane and Perth from product imports in particular, because those cities are furthest from Bass Strait, our major oil-producing area, and equally are closest to import supply lines. However, others within the oil industry argue strongly that both Perth and Brisbane refineries would continue to be perfectly viable in a free market situation.

The Government has not made up its mind. We have asked as to the merits of these competing arguments. We have not had enough information before us to be able to do so. What we have done is to ask people with an interest in this matter to make submissions to us, not only the refiners and producers but also the State governments and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

My comments to the AIP were in the context of that discussion paper, designed quite deliberately to stimulate discussion and response on this very difficult and sensitive issue. I certainly make no apology for them. The employment effects of this whole question will undoubtedly have to be considered very closely in light of the comments we receive from interested parties and, in particular, from the ACTU.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. In light of the confusion and uncertainty surrounding the Government's plans to change the taxation system, confusion which was added to by his answer to me yesterday on income splitting, I ask: Is the Minister aware that, at about the same time he was refusing to tell the Senate whether the question of income splitting would be covered in the White Paper on taxation, the Prime Minister was telling the House of Representatives that the pros and cons of the proposal would be canvassed in the White Paper? As the Minister spent so much time yesterday on the cons of income splitting, we will now give the Senate a rundown on the pros?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refuse to disclose the contents of the White Paper. Apparently, the Prime Minister disclosed some of its contents. I suppose that is one of the prerogatives of being Prime Minister. I do not feel particularly embarrassed by it and there is no reason why the Government should be embarrassed by it.

ANSWER.PARA: If Senator Parer wants me to say a bit more about income splitting, I shall. Income splitting means different things to different people. It meant at least three different things to three members of the Opposition when it was proposed before the last election. As proposed by Mr Howard, if I remember it correctly, it allowed a maximum transfer from one income to the other of some $9,000. As proposed by Mr Sinclair, it meant allowing anybody at all, no matter what his income, to transfer up to 50 per cent of it to a spouse. Mr Peacock's view as usual was somewhere in between the two. He did not know where he was and probably did not understand the issue.

However, as seriously proposed by Mr Howard, the so-called benefits of income splitting would be very limited to households on low incomes because, in splitting the income, the dependent spouse rebate would be wiped out. As each dollar of income is transferred, after $282 the dependent spouse rebate would be wiped out at a rate of 25 per cent, which is very close to the marginal tax rate paid by someone on a median income. So the advantages of a transfer of up to $9,000 or thereabouts in that sort of household, that is, a household on a median income of around $17,000, are negligible.

The advantages, however, for a household on, say, a $50,000 income are quite substantial, particularly if the spouse already has some income which has thereby disqualified the other taxpayer from claiming a dependent spouse rebate. For example, let us assume that one taxpayer has a $50,000 income and his spouse has an income of $5,000, thereby disqualifying the taxpayer from claiming any dependent spouse rebate. If $9,000 of income were transferred under the existing Schedule there would be a gain of the difference between the two marginal rates, that is, above $5,000 and above $40,000. The marginal rate in the latter case is 60c in the dollar. The marginal rate in the former case is 25c in the dollar for almost the entire range of the original $5,000. It rises for almost the entire extra $9,000 split, to 30c in the dollar.

A quick calculation from that example shows that the gain to that sort of taxpayer from that sort of income splitting would be of the order of $3,000, whereas the gain to a median and single income household would be negligible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has Mr Pacifico Castro, the Acting Foreign Minister of the Philippines, criticised the provision of Australian aid to the Philippines as fostering 'rather uncomfortable feelings of dependence' and described Australian missionaries as 'trained political agitators'? Will the Australian Government take steps to relieve the Philippines Government of this discomfiture immediately in the case of military aid, running at several millions of dollars per year? Does the Australian Government accept Mr Castro's description of Australian missionaries as trained political agitators? Does it consider them, therefore, to be in any danger, given his regime's tolerance of torture and death squads used against those perceived as being political dissidents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of comments about activities of Australian missionaries in the Philippines purported to have been made by Mr Castro, the Acting Foreign Minister of the Philippines, in an interview with the Australian Financial Review. The Government of the Philippines has, however, never officially complained about the activities of Australian missionaries in the Philippines. We are simply not in a position to comment on the accusations contained in the article in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government takes the view that a healthy trading relationship between the Philippines and Australia is desirable and is endeavouring to encourage it. We also wish to assist in the promotion of development in the Philippines and the Philippines Government has welcomed this assistance.

Part of Australia's development assistance effort is in the Northern Samar integrated rural development project. There has been criticism of that Northern Samar project from various sources, including Australian Catholic groups. The members of the insurgent group, the New People's Army, who contacted project personnel on 12 April were aware of this criticism, but their objection to the project appears to have stemmed somewhat from their own wider ideological aims. There was no threat to project personnel. The Northern Samar project is designed to do something effective for a needy area of the Philippines. Its emphasis is on raising agricultural output, which is the source of livelihood for the bulk of the population, and community development.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the uncertainty and confusion which surrounds the Government's wages policy and the recent evidence of that when the Minister, two days ago, said that the Government had not yet decided whether to argue for discounting at the time of the September national wage case and would not make that decision until much closer to the hearing. I further remind him that last Thursday the Minister for Finance said that the Government would not argue for discounting in September and Senator Walsh confirmed that answer in the Senate only yesterday. Does the Minister agree that it is not possible for both him and Senator Walsh to be telling the truth? Will he clear up the confusion by telling the Senate whether or not the Government has made a decision to argue for discounting in September and, if it has made a decision, what that decision is?

—On the day in question I did not say that the Government had not yet decided. I said that the Government was cool about the issue. If Senator Chaney wants to place that interpretation on what I said, no doubt he will do so. What I did draw attention to in the answer I gave to the question was the Government's view, which has been often repeated, that the effects of devaluation will not be at all marked in the September quarter and will not be particularly relevant in the context of the September 1985 wage case. What I did leave open quite explicitly was what could happen in the March quarter for 1986, when the Government anticipates the full effects of the devaluation will have flowed on to the consumer price index. It was, of course, said by way of interjection at the time I gave that answer, I think by Senator Chaney-
—Senator Durack.
—Senator Durack interjected that we had not made up our minds yet, or something like that.
—No; he just said that you were confused.

—He said I was confused. Well, that is very helpful. Having drawn attention to erroneous information in the question, I will now deal with it. As I said on the previous occasion, the Government does not anticipate any significant impact on the CPI relevant to the September 1985 wage case. We will look at that question of the effects of the devaluation at the time but, as has already been said, it is not considered that it will be appropriate at that time to discount in the way which has been suggested by some commentators.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Let me quote the exact words from the two Ministers to counter Senator Button's blurring of this issue. Senator Button said to the Senate:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we will examine the position with regard to that hearing at that time.
He was referring to the September hearing. On the other hand, Senator Walsh said:
. . . the Government will not argue for discounting of the devaluation induced consumer price index effect in the March and June quarters . . .

I again ask the Minister: Is he saying that a decision has been made by the Government with respect to what will be argued, or is he saying that that is a matter that will be decided in September or closer to the September hearing?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's clear disposition is not to discount the effects of the devaluation at the September quarter hearing. If, on the other hand, we are wrong about the impact on the CPI by September, of course we will have to examine that question at that time. What we have said on numerous occasions is that we do not see any likelihood of its being important that we do it in the September wages case; we do see the strong possibility that it will be important in the March case of 1986. If I have to go on playing verbal tootsies on this issue, let me say-
—Perhaps you could tell us what your disposition will be in regard to March next year.

—All the Commonwealth can do is to put a position to the wages case this year and to put a position again next year. If Senator Durack is trying to strap us up to saying a long way in advance of every national wage case what the Government's submission to it will be we will not accommodate him, and he would not accommodate us in such a situation either.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, concerns the production of and demand for uranium. I understand that Canada is now considered to have the largest and richest deposits of uranium in the Western World. In fact, a recent discovery appears to be the greatest concentration of uranium ever found. What effect, if any, is this having upon the sale of Australian uranium and what effect is it likely to have in the future? What is the present price received for Australian uranium compared with that received in each of the last three years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the honourable senator is referring to the Cigar Lake project in northern Saskatchewan. Reserves of 110,000 tonnes of contained uranium at a grade of 12 per cent uranium have been reported. A western extension of the ore body is believed to contain reserves of 39,000 tonnes of uranium at a grade of 3.9 per cent uranium, making Cigar Lake the richest deposit of this size in the world. For comparative purposes, Ranger has approximately 110,000 tonnes of contained uranium at an ore grade of 0.25 per cent. However, Australia has the largest low cost ore reserves in the Western World, with reasonably assured resources of 463,000 tonnes of uranium recoverable at a cost of less than $US80 per kilogram, while Canada has only 176,000 tonnes in the same category.

ANSWER.PARA: The Canadian figure that I mentioned does not include Cigar Lake, as this is not a low cost reserve. It cannot be mined using existing technology. If this 400m deep deposit is to be developed at all, new remotely controlled mining equipment will be needed as a consequence of the radiological hazards presented by the richness of the ore, and we consequently do not expect output from Cigar Lake to appear on world markets before the middle 1990s at the earliest. I am not aware that the discovery at Cigar Lake has had any discernible impact on the sale of Australian uranium, nor is it likely to in the absence of a firm commitment to development. It may be, of course, that the mere discovery of such a deposit has added to the general level of long term consumer supply assurance, especially in the current market, which is characterised by excess supply, surplus inventories and depressed prices.

As to the last part of Senator Hearn's question about prices, official trade statistics published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics note that the average value of Australian uranium exported in 1984 was $A42.79 a pound of U308, compared with $A41.02 in 1983, $A34.48 in 1982 and $A33.50 in 1981. I will not attempt to forecast the future movements of the price of this commodity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In light of the confusion and uncertainty surrounding the Government's plans for changes to the taxation system, I ask: Has the Government yet decided whether the tax White Paper will contain a preferred position? If so, what is that position?
—The tax White Paper will, I believe, be publicly available within a week. I suggest the honourable senator take time to read it when it is made available to him.

—My question, which is addressed to the Acting Foreign Minister, follows on from the question asked earlier by Senator Tate. Is the Minister aware of the recent arrest of five human rights lawyers in the Philippines, all members of the Free Legal Assistance Group which defends clients against government and the military in that country? Is it a fact that the lawyers were arrested and detained by the military without applying to civilian authorities such as the law courts? Has it also been claimed that this action is part of the Marcos approach to intimidate human rights lawyers and frighten opponents within the Philippines? Can the Minister say whether the Australian Government is taking any action to register its disapproval of this form of action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware that five lawyers affiliated with the Free Legal Assistance Group, FLAG, in the Philippines, have been arrested. Two of those lawyers, Romeo Astudillo and Alberto Benesa, were arrested by presidential detention action orders in Abra in northern Luzon at the end of April. On 10 May two more lawyers, Laurente Ilagan and Antonio Arellano, were arrested in Davao City in Mindanao, reportedly under mission orders signed by the Minister for Defence. A fifth lawyer, Marcos Resonar, was arrested too in Davao City on 13 May, reportedly under a mission order signed by the regional military commander.

ANSWER.PARA: National lawyers' organisations have filed a petition of habeas corpus for the three lawyers most recently detained in Davao City and have claimed that the arrests were illegal. We understand, however, that the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus remains suspended in that region. The Australian Government has on many occasions reaffirmed its commitment to the international protection and promotion of human rights and takes a very close interest in aspects of human rights in the Philippines. The Australian Embassy maintains continuing contact with human rights and civil liberties groups in the Philippines. I have asked the Embassy to provide further information on those arrested, and the circumstances of their arrest, and to follow developments affecting the lawyers in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In light of the confusion and uncertainty which surrounds the Government's policy on Aboriginal land rights-confusion which has been worsened by the Prime Minister's meeting yesterday with Aboriginal representatives in Canberra-I ask: Has the Government decided not to bring in national land rights legislation this year? Is it true, as claimed by some of the Aborigines who met Mr Hawke yesterday, that the Prime Minister is reconsidering his opposition to an Aboriginal mining veto?

—I do not have a briefing following the meeting of the Prime Minister with Aboriginal representatives yesterday so I cannot answer specifically. But I repeat to Senator Kilgariff what I have said to him many times in this chamber; that is, our Government is committed to achieving land rights for Aboriginal people. Available for comment and consultation at this stage is a model which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Clyde Holding, has developed as a result of many discussions with Aboriginal people, other parties and interest groups. That model is available for discussion and negotiation. Some spokespersons for Aboriginal organisations have expressed disappointment in the model; others are prepared to discuss and negotiate it. Obviously, a period of further discussion is necessary before the matter is settled but I can only repeat--
—This year, next year, some time, never.

—It is very interesting that Senator Chaney should choose to interject in this smart-Alick fashion when it was his Party, the Liberal Party in Western Australia, which carried out the most scurrilous anti-land rights campaign that this country has ever seen. The Liberal Party in Western Australia published racist booklets, full of inaccuracies and designed to cause prejudice within the Western Australian community. Unfortunately, those booklets have had an effect on the electorate in Western Australia. The performance of the Liberals in Western Australia in relation to land rights has been absolutely disgraceful. Every Aboriginal in Australia would agree with me, on that point at least. In contrast to the provocative and racist behaviour of the Liberal Party in Senator Chaney's State, our Government, ever since taking office, has discussed how we can achieve, nationally, land rights which incorporate the principles which have been set out throughout Australia. It is a complex matter on which progress has been disappointingly slow. Nonetheless, our commitment to uniform land rights throughout Australia remains. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Clyde Holding, the Prime Minister and the Government generally will continue to pursue that objective until we achieve it.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. We are fully aware of the preferred model, and the situation until yesterday. As the Minister has not been briefed by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, will she obtain a briefing as to what the Prime Minister has said to the Aboriginal people and what assurances he has given them? Will she bring that information back to the Senate?
—I am very interested to know the outcome of discussions that were held yesterday. If there is any development in terms of policy I will inform the Senate of it as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the 'Electronics in Agriculture' report that claims great potential in the development and export of high technology agricultural equipment? Is the Government likely to respond to the report and initiate industry interest in what appears to be a very lucrative area?
—I am not the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. The question contains two elements, one relating to electronics and one relating to agriculture.
—Besides, he has got the brief.

—Senator Walsh says that I have the answer and he does not. Firstly, I am aware of the report 'Electronics in Agriculture' recently released by the New South Wales Minister for Technology. An officer of my Department recently attended a conference on this report held in Armidale in New South Wales. The Government has already been participating in the promotion of electronics in agriculture through the research and development support provided by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and other generally available assistance programs. I expect that this report will be an important on-going aid to the Government and this country in the development of policies for the encouragement of increased use of electronics in agricultural industries.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of Mr Hawke's trenchant criticism of the United States intervention in Grenada in October 1983 I ask the Minister: Has the Government noted the results of the recent democratic elections in Grenada? Is it a fact that 95 per cent of Grenadians voted for politicians of political parties who supported President Reagan's intervention with only 5 per cent voting for the pro-Cuban revolutionaries who ran the country before the marines went in? Does this not underline the absurdity of the Hawke Government's critical stand at the time of the intervention?

—The results of the recent election in Grenada have been noted by the Government. They do not underline anything in terms of the absurd proposition that Senator Walters put to me in the question she has just asked.

—What information can the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services provide on the new Commonwealth office centre to be constructed at Port Pirie in South Australia? What is the timetable for the development of this project, which is of significance to the local building industry? Will attention be paid to Australian heritage questions in the development of the project?

—The Port Pirie project was approved by the Government as part of a nationwide office construction program aimed at stimulating the building industry, generating employment and reducing the Commonwealth's annual rent bill. The project will provide 800 square metres of space to meet the immediate needs of the Australian Customs Service and the Department of Social Security. The site is being purchased from the State Government by the Commonwealth for $21,000. As the building will be located within a heritage precinct the selected design meets the requirements of the Australian Heritage Commission and the Port Pirie Council. The final contract and price negotiations are in progress with the developer and it is anticipated that the construction will begin by mid-1985.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. It concerns the participation and equity program described by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Education in times past as 'the centre piece' of Labor's policy to youth. I remind the Minister of the mini-Budget decision to cut this program in half in 1986 and of the Government's statement that the cuts which were presented to Parliament represent Labor's priorities. I ask the Minister: Does this expression of Labor's priorities envisage cutting out parts of the participation and equity program directed towards disadvantaged schools, or do Labor priorities envisage the ending of programs for the long term unemployed youth, the handicapped, the isolated and the non-English speaking students who presently use the technical and further education component of the PEP?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case, as Senator Baume's question pointed out, that the Government has decided to slow down the participation and equity program. In fact, the funds appropriated for 1986 will be halved and those funds will be available in 1987. Regrettable as this is, this decision was brought about as a result of the necessity faced by the Government to achieve some savings off the Forward Estimates. Although I regret that the program has had to be affected in this way, I should make it quite clear that the decision does not mean that the Government is resiling from its objective of increased participation, nor from its concern that participation in education be extended to previously disadvantaged groups.

ANSWER.PARA: The effect of the decision will be this: The amount of money allocated to the program for 1986 will be halved and that will affect in proportion the TAFE and schools components. They will each be slowed down the to extent of losing for 1986 half of the funds that had been appropriated. However, the program will continue into 1987, so that it will be a four-year program instead of a three-year program. The effect of this will be to spread out the program and some projects under the program will start up more slowly, but it will not mean an overall loss to the program of any financial support.

I will not pretend that I was anything other than reluctant about this decision, but having admitted that, frankly, I will say that the slowing down of the program will have some benefits. It will enable the Government, the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Tertiary Education Commission to assess how far the program has already met its objectives and whether the procedure of targeting schools for involvement in the program is meeting the objectives. It will give us time to review the operation of the State committees-and I admit that there have been some administrative problems stemming from the State committees. The program will operate more slowly and new projects will be taken up more slowly, but I hope that the money will be better targeted and the outcomes-which are, after all, what we are interested in-will continue to be very effective.

I say in conclusion that the Government considers that the participation objective has already been successful. If Senator Baume turns his attention to the statistics, which I am sure he has already done, relating to participation rates in upper secondary schools in all States and Territories of Australia, he will see that already there has been considerable improvement. Similarly, the participation in TAFE by disadvantaged groups has shown a marked improvement. I believe both of those trends of improvement will continue with a very clear direction of funds and the most efficient possible use of resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy to the recent comments by Professor Derrick Sewell, a world expert on river systems. During the launching of Professor Sewell's publication Who Owns the Murray? he suggested that the Australian Federal Government could do much to facilitate negotiations on the management of the River Murray by imitating the Canadian central Government and acting to bring interested parties together. I ask the Minister: Does the Federal Government see itself in the role of co-ordinator and mediator and does the Minister agree that such an arrangement might be of benefit to South Australia which, although it does not have as much power as the up-river States, stands to suffer most from the problems resulting from salinity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports of Professor Sewell's remarks about the desirability of better co-operation on water matters and his suggestion that the Commonwealth could do much to facilitate negotiations on the management of the River Murray by imitating the Canadian central Government and acting to bring interested parties together. I think that perhaps Professor Sewell in making those remarks was not fully aware of the provisions of the existing River Murray Waters Agreement, which, in the Government's view, fully meet his objectives. The Government believes that the River Murray Waters Agreement is the appropriate mechanism for Commonwealth-State collaboration in River Murray matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the new agreement the River Murray Commission is empowered to take account of water quality, which is South Australia's overriding concern, and it is now preparing a long term river management plan. In preparing this plan the Commission is having regard to public comment on its recent discussion paper dealing specifically with River Murray salinity problems. The Government believes that the passage of some time is necessary before a reasonable conclusion can be reached as to whether the new agreement is effective in improving water quality in the Murray. If deficiencies are identified which impair the objective of the new agreement, I can assure Senator Foreman that the Government will consider appropriate courses of action, including that flagged by the professor to whom Senator Foreman referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of members of a parliamentary delegation from the Bundestag of the Federal Republic of Germany, led by Mr Richard Stuecklen, who are on an official visit to Australia. On behalf of all senators I extend to our guests from the Federal Republic of Germany a warm welcome to Australia, to Canberra and to the Senate.

—My question is addressed to Senator Button in his dual capacities as Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer Senator Button to his answer yesterday to Senator Chaney's question, which followed on from my question of 7 May, as to whether the forthcoming White Paper on taxation will address the issue of business tax reform. In his answer yesterday the Minister said that it would. I now ask the Minister whether he is in a position to answer the second part of my question of 7 May; namely, whether the issue of business taxation will also be considered at the July tax summit? If so, I ask whether he, as the Minister responsible for industry policy, of which business taxation is an essential element, has had negotiations with the business sector over the handling of business taxation issues at the summit, in the same way as the Government has been engaging in constant negotiations with the tax negotiating committee of the Australian Council of Trade Unions over the taxation issues of concern to the trade union movement?

—I am asked essentially whether the question of business taxation will be considered at the July taxation summit. I am not on the agenda committee for the July taxation summit but there will be, of course, substantial representations from the business community at that summit and I think that they will wish to raise issues of business taxation. Therefore, my answer to the question as to whether it will be on the agenda is probably yes, because I would anticipate that a significant group of participants at the summit would so wish it. I am asked also whether I have had negotiations with the business community in the same way as Senator Short suggests the Government has had negotiations with the ACTU regarding issues more associated, I believe, with the direct taxation system. The answer is that I have not had any publicised negotiations with the business community. I have had numerous discussions from time to time, as I always try to do, with representatives of the business community about business taxation issues. In due course, if they request, I will be quite happy to meet with them on the agenda for the summit, if that proves necessary or desirable.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister's answer mean that his understanding is that the business taxation issues at the summit, for which there has already been much planning, will be treated in a different context and dealt with in a different manner from other taxation issues?
—No, it does not mean that at all.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Does the Government have a policy of giving preference in purchasing to goods made in Australia? If so, what guidelines are issued to government departments to ensure that such a policy is implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, a 20 per cent margin of preference for locally produced goods is applied to all Commonwealth purchases. Preference does not apply to services purchased separately from goods, since naturally in the great majority of cases these services are automatically performed or provided in Australia. Where the 20 per cent general margin would result in an additional cost to the Commonwealth of $200,000 or more, the preference ceases to be applied automatically at that point and such cases are then determined by the responsible Minister. Ministers also review all purchases valued at over $100,000 where application of preference is insufficient to give the contractor a suitable offer of higher Australian content. In that situation, a group of departments advises Ministers whether a margin of preference of more than 20 per cent is warranted.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say that there are a number of supplementary matters that are relevant to these preference arrangements. For example, purchasing procedures also provide that government specifications may not exclude suitable or adaptable Australian made products, alternative solutions offered by Australian manufacturers must be considered, as far as practicable ordering patterns must be scaled to the minimum economic order requirements of Australian industry and briefings must be made available to unsuccessful tenderers on the reasons why they failed to win orders.

The operation of the purchasing arrangements is kept under review. Aspects currently under examination include payment of duty on Commonwealth imports. At present, duties apply only on a notional basis, usually the 2 per cent revenue duty. Exemptions from the preference arrangements are also under consideration. Some statutory authorities are currently exempt as a result of provisions in their own enabling legislation. The general answer to the question is: Yes, the margin is a 20 per cent margin and there are a number of sub-plots, if I may call them that, involved in working out a system of the kind that I have indicated in my answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to comments made by an Australian Council of Trade Unions industrial officer, Mr Ian Court, who is the co-ordinator of illegal blockades of Queensland, that the ACTU was about to renege on its agreement with the Hawke Government to lift the blockade of services and transport to Queensland in exchange for the Government introducing the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill 1985 and reimpose the blockade. In the light of this somersault and clear breach of promise, which a more realistic government would have expected, will the Government withdraw its proposed Bill?

—Did Mr Court really say that? If he did, we will look at his statements and decide what we will then do. The blockade has been lifted. It has been the intention and the wish of this Government all along that the blockade be lifted. That result has been achieved, unpalatable as it may be to some of those people associated with the Queensland Government. The blockade has been lifted, and this Government will do all that it can to see that there is a sensible industrial situation, both now and in the future, in the State of Queensland. If we do not do that, the level of industrial disputes in Queensland will continue to be the brightest jewel in the crown of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's State. The level of industrial disputation in that State is something like five times the level in the rest of the Commonwealth. We want to help to avoid that situation in Queensland, and this Government will take every step it can to see that that happens.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Communications had drawn to his attention the decision in the High Court of Australia which upheld an appeal by television stations against the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's perceived right to ensure that children's television programs fitted in with the guidelines as laid down by the Tribunal before those programs went to air? Is it a fact that the Government made great play of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal having that power to ensure the standards of programs for children on all Australian television stations? What action does the Government propose? Does it propose to introduce legislation to enable the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal legally to ensure that its program standards are observed before programs go to air?
—I do not know anything about that matter. I will see what the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, has to say.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS: REPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister representing the Attorney-General of a report by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the reversal of the onus of proof that was tabled in the Senate some two or three years ago. In my view, it was quite a compelling and persuasive document and had some notable authors. When might we expect to receive a response from the Government on that document, particularly as many questions on this subject have been raised in recent times at meetings of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The vigour and intelligence which Senator Crichton-Browne contributed to writing the report, regrettably, was not carried through in his reading of Hansard last year because he would have noticed that not only had the Government given interim responses on 2 June 1983 and 15 December 1983 but also on 22 October last year a more substantial response was given by the Government. The points made in that response are still applicable. First, Mr Justice Watson is presently reviewing the aspects of the criminal law of the Commonwealth and is examining the Committee's report with a view to improving the onus of proof and the averment provisions in line with the Committee's recommendations. Secondly, the Attorney-General's Department, conscious as it is of the existence of the report, whenever an onus of proof issue arises, as it often does in the drafting and preparing of legislation, draws that report to the attention of departments administering statutes which may give rise to these problems and applies the principles in the report in endeavouring to redress them. As was said in the Government statement last year:

ANSWER.PARA: The Committee's recommendations, and the principles underlying them, have already proved influential in resolving problems on a case-by-case basis, and no doubt will continue to do so in the future.

It is believed by the present Attorney that the measures that I have outlined are an adequate response to the report in the light of other competing priorities. It is acknowledged by the Government that it would be desirable to have a full scale review of all existing legislation in the way in which it treats onus of proof issues. Basically, we will be relying upon the report of Mr Justice Watson to do that for us and to lay a foundation for further action in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Inasmuch as Senator Gareth Evans cannot answer a question without being impertinent, no matter who the questioner is--
—Order! The honourable senator will ask his supplementary question.

—Does the Minister accept and acknowledge that it is an inordinate time since that report was first tabled and that we still do not have an absolute and definitive response from the Government but rather an ad hoc application by the Government to various parts of the report?

—It is just that Senator Crichton-Browne brings out the beast in me. I will do my best to respond, as always sensibly and unflappably, to his question. I do not believe there was excessive delay in the Government's response to that report, given the enormous difficulty and complexity of the issues involved. I believe that the Government has gone as far as it reasonably can to pick up the threads of what was a very significant contribution to jurisprudence by Senator Crichton-Browne and others and I am sure history will remain indebted to him for his efforts.

—I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to an article in yesterday's Melbourne Herald in which it was claimed that the United States Naval Research Laboratory had information that there were significantly high levels of radioactivity in the thyroid glands of Victorian and Tasmanian sheep soon after the explosion of a South African-Israeli nuclear device in 1979. Did the article also state that the Australian Radiation Laboratories did not pick up such information? How efficient are monitoring systems such as the one at Cape Grim in Tasmania? Can the Minister say what action the Government will take in order to ascertain the truth of the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is relevant to me both in my own portfolio capacity and as Acting Foreign Minister, and I will give as good an answer as I can wearing both those hats.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of Press reports originating from Washington concerning the release of additional information on the event, registered by a United States Vela satellite on 22 September 1979, which has led to speculation that South Africa may have detonated a nuclear explosive device. I have sought additional information on those reports but it has not yet come to hand.

Reports of high iodine levels registered in the thyroid glands of sheep slaughtered in the Melbourne area in October and November 1979 are not new. Reports to this effect, citing the results of tests conducted by Dr L. Van Middlesworth of the University of Tennessee, were carried, as aficionados of Brian Toohey's contributions to freedom of information will be pleased to record, in the National Times of 2 November 1984.

The Government understands that Dr Van Middlesworth regarded his analysis of sheep thyroids as interesting but inconclusive-an entirely plausible response. The prior history of the sheep was not known-I draw attention to the fact that these were Melbourne sheep and not Tasmanian sheep, so some of the guffaws we hear are misplaced-and there were problems in the analysis process as a result of cross-contamination, equipment instability and lack of sensitivity.

Australian experts examined the issues in 1981 and considered that the evidence was insufficient to enable a firm conclusion to be reached. For example, separate air and water samplings conducted at the time by the Australian Radiation Laboratories in Melbourne did not provide a basis to conclude that a nuclear explosion had taken place on 22 September. A panel of non-government scientists convened by the science adviser to President Carter to conduct an inquiry into the event concluded in 1980 that it was probably not a nuclear explosion. The panel judged that it was more likely to have been caused by the impact of a small meteoroid on the Vela satellite. A United Nations expert panel reached similar conclusions.

The Government knows of no evidence to support claims of Israeli collaboration with South Africa in the event, if there was such an event, of 22 November 1979. It would be of the utmost concern if in fact South Africa or any other country had contributed to the spread of nuclear weapons by exploding a nuclear device. Such action by any additional state would obviously endanger regional and international security and stability.

Senator Devlin asked me another question about the efficiency of monitoring systems such as the one at Cape Grim in Tasmania, and about the performance of the ARL. I will have to take those parts of the question on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the papers quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—Will the Minister table the papers? The papers are tabled.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I ask whether the Government proposes to act on this recommendation of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australia's Industrial Relations Law and Systems to facilitate an arrangement whereby:

QUESTION.PARA: Parties who wish to make their own arrangements for the prevention and settlement of disputes by conciliation and arbitration may do so.

Does the Minister agree that many small businesses would be able to provide more long term jobs if they could reach agreement with their employees on awards and conditions of work outside the centralised arbitration system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have a note here on the matter Senator Evans raised. The Government does acknowledge the increased flexibility that such a provision could bring to the system. It should be noted that the report doubts whether in practice the proportion of the labour force that would be covered by such agreements would be large, and the recommendations stand somewhat at odds with the overall thrust of the Committee's recommendations which favour a strengthening of public interest in economic considerations in the deliberations of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: I will refer the question to Mr Willis to see whether he has a more definite response. I understand that he made a quite detailed response to the report in the House of Representatives on Monday. I do not know whether Senator Evans knew that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. As honourable senators did not have the opportunity to respond to the statement presented by Mr Willis I ask the Minister: Do his reply and Mr Willis's statement in the House of Representatives mean that the Government will now support the Australian Democrats' Bill on collective agreements which meets the recommendations of the Hancock report on collective bargaining?
—Frankly, I do not know. I will seek an answer from Mr Willis.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Australia's trading relationship with South Africa having been used by Australian cricketers to justify their rejection of the principles of the Gleneagles Agreement, can the Acting Minister give any indication of Australia's intentions should there be any resolution calling for mandatory economic sanctions against South Africa at the United Nations Security Council in the foreseeable future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Successive Australian governments have expressed strong opposition to the apartheid policies of successive South African governments. Australian governments have not always been followed by their troops, in relation to the opposition, but the record has been long and consistent so far as governments are concerned. The present Australian Government maintains this consistent and total opposition to apartheid while maintaining nonetheless correct diplomatic relations with South Africa.

ANSWER.PARA: In keeping with the Government's strong stand against apartheid and its wish to give effect to measures that would strengthen pressure on South Africa to dismantle apartheid, Australia would support and vote in favour of mandatory economic sanctions in the United Nations Security Council. In the absence of such sanctions the Government's policy is to permit normal commercial relations with South Africa to continue, but without avoidable official assistance. Consistent with this policy there is no governmental promotion of Australian trade with or investment in South Africa.

In line with this policy the Government has recently introduced, as people will be well aware, a draft code of conduct for Australian companies with interests in South Africa. Such codes of conduct have broad international acceptance. The Government does not consider that unilateral action by Australia would be an effective means of increasing economic pressure on South Africa.

We are sometimes asked why the boycott on sporting contacts is not also applied in the trade area. The short answer is that the Government gives full support to the Gleneagles declaration on apartheid in sport and the Brisbane code of conduct. The obligations arising from these documents are similarly endorsed by Commonwealth countries and members of the international community. There are not as yet similar international obligations in the trade and economic area which are observed and implemented by South Africa's major trading partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is there a higher than usual rate of issuing of income tax assessments this month compared with those issued in the month of May in previous years? Is this enthusiasm on the part of the Australian Taxation Office designed to maximise revenue collections to ensure that the Government meets its trilogy commitments to the electorate? Is the Minister aware of reports of a high element of inaccuracy in many of these assessments?

—I do not know whether a higher number of assessments is being issued this May than is normally the case. However, it would not surprise me if there were, because the sabotage campaign run during late January and February delayed the collection of tax. I would have expected that it would also have delayed the issuing of assessments. Indeed, there is some expectation that more assessments are being issued now than normally. But I will check the facts and have them sent to Senator Watson or report in some other way. Secondly, there is no manipulation by the Government about the number of assessments that are being issued. That matter is left to the Commissioner of Taxation and determined by the resources available to him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick asked me a question about anti-ballistic missile research by the Soviet Union, in relation to my answer of 15 May to an earlier question by him on this subject. I have a substantial supplementary answer which I would be happy to read, Mr President, but I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard, if that is acceptable.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The supplementary answer read as follows-

First, the Government has never said that the Soviet Union is well advanced in SDI-type research; it has simply said, as I did on 15 May, that it is conducting such research. In recent testimony to the Disarmament and Arms control Sub-Committee of the Parliamentary JFADC, the Department of Foreign Affairs has, I understand, commented in further detail on the matter and the record of that testimony when available may be of interest.

Secondly, the fact that Australia endorsed neither SDI nor its Soviet counterpart was made clear to both superpowers during the recent separate bilateral disarmament discussions with the United States and the Soviet Union. While I cannot of course go into detail of what were confidential discussions I refer Senator Sir John Carrick to the text of a summarised on-the-record briefing by the Department of Foreign Affairs to the Australian media of the Australia-Soviet bilateral talks on disarmament which was given on 22 March and reproduced in issue No. 9, dated 29 March 1985, of the Department of Foreign Affairs disarmament newsletter. Page 14 of the newsletter contains the following extract: 'We have confirmed for our part that there is no Australian endorsement of SDI or its Soviet counterpart'.

Thirdly, I repeat what I said on 15 May, namely that the ABM system deployed around Moscow and the improvements being made to it, including the new phased array radar at Pushkino, are within the limits established by the 1972 anti ballistic missile treaty and its 1974 protocol. Senator Carrick's reference in his question to the nature and direction of the radar system indicates he may have in mind the large phased array radar under construction near the city of Krasnoyarsk, some thousands of kilometres to the east of Moscow. The United States has charged that by its siting, orientation and capability the Krasnoyarsk radar is prohibited by the ABM treaty. The Government is concerned about this and will continue to examine this and other US allegations of Soviet non-compliance with arms control agreements. There appears to be a case to answer and the Government hopes that the Soviet Union will take appropriate steps to respond to western concerns and demonstrate its compliance with all these important agreements.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON AUSTRALIA'S SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I table the final reports of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave, Mr President, to make a statement on the reports, to incorporate the text of the statement in Hansard and to move 'That the Senate take note of the statement'.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
INTRODUCTION

On 17 May 1983 the Government appointed a Royal Commission, conducted by Mr Justice Hope, to undertake a major review of Australia's security and intelligence agencies. Having reported to the Government on the Combe/Ivanov affair in December 1983 and the Sheraton Hotel incident in February 1984, the Royal Commission presented its final Reports to the Government in December 1984. I now table certain of those Reports in edited form.

Before commenting on the Reports, I should like, on behalf of the Government, to express my sincere thanks to Mr Justice Hope for having completed with distinction a very difficult task. His Honour is no stranger to the intelligence and security community having previously inquired into and reported on it in a series of major reports in 1976 and 1977. Those reports led, amongst other things, to the enactment of a new Act governing ASIO, a Security Appeals Tribunal, the establishment by legislation of the Office of National Assessments, the public acknowledgement of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and Defence Signals Directorate, and the creation of a Cabinet Committee and supporting Committee of Departmental Secretaries to oversight the activities of the intelligence community.
I should also like to thank the New South Wales Government for releasing Mr Justice Hope from his duties as a Judge of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales.
THE REPORTS

On 21 December 1984 the Royal Commission presented the Government with a General Report, individual Reports on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO), the Australian Secret Intelligence Service (ASIS), and the Defence Signals Directorate (DSD), and a combined Report on the Office of National Assessments (ONA) and Joint Intelligence Organization (JIO).

While the nature of the subject matter of these Reports rules out, on the grounds of national security, publication of some material, the Government has decided to publish as much as is possible of the Reports within these constraints. It has taken account of the views about possible publication expressed by His Honour in each of the Reports, and has consulted with him further in reaching a decision on publication.

As suggested by Mr Justice Hope, the Government is tabling edited versions of the General, ASIO, and ONA/JIO Reports. As also recommended by His Honour, the ASIS and DSD Reports are not being published, but some general comments about the legality, propriety, effectiveness and efficiency of each are to be found in the published General Report and I will have something further to say about each in this statement.
I mention also that in accordance with established practice on intelligence and security matters, the Leader of the Opposition has been provided with copies of unexpurgated reports.

The Government in this statement responds in broad terms to the principal recommendations raised in the published Reports. It has not yet reached a final position on all of the hundreds of recommendations and suggestions made: many raise complex issues; many are intertwined; many, if adopted, will require the introduction or amendment of legislation. Detailed examination of all the recommendations has commenced and will continue over future months.
MAJOR FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
Evaluation of the Performance of the Agencies

Mr Justice Hope has reiterated his views, formed during his earlier review, that Australia needs intelligence of quality, timeliness and relevance, and for this purpose requires a highly professional system of intelligence and security services (Gen., 2.43). He has concluded that Governments should continue to ensure that the intelligence community is able to fulfil its important role in helping to advise on and protect Australia's national interests (Gen., 2.44).
This Government endorses those views.

The inquiry by Mr Justice Hope has been a most comprehensive review of Australia's security and intelligence agencies. It has also examined a number of complaints. It has exposed deficiencies in some agencies. But while noting that there will always be room for improvement, His Honour concludes that the agencies are generally performing effectively and efficiently. He finds that:

In ASIO, much work has been done, and is continuing, to restructure and revitalise the Organization, making it a service more responsive to predetermined policies (Gen., 2.21). ASIO has been concerned to ensure that its operations and actions are within its charter, and has been substantially successful in this (Gen., 2.5). Its record as to legality and propriety is good (Gen., 2.6). However, His Honour has pointed to a number of areas, particularly in management and administration, where improvement in performance is necessary.

ONA, although a relatively small body, has established its independence and authority by the quality of the work it produces, and is held in high regard (Gen., 2.34, 2.36). Its national assessments have been of high quality and it also produces valuable reports on matters of current significance (Gen., 2.36).

JI0 is a competent and professional agency (ONA/JI0, 4.9). It fulfils an important role in providing the Defence organisation and other areas of Government with a range of data and assessed intelligence on international, military and defence related developments (ONA/JI0, 2.18). It handles a vast amount of intelligence, and issues assessments and reports, many of which are of a high standard. Its product is well regarded by those who receive it (Gen., 2.40).

ASIS has achieved success over the last decade in organising and reorganising to achieve its goals (Gen., 2.26); its effectiveness and efficiency, and its contribution to Australia's intelligence, will continue to grow as a consequence of the closer relationship with other areas of Government which it now has (Gen., 2.28). The Sheraton Hotel incident was not representative of the quality or professionalism exhibited by ASIS in performing its principal tasks (Gen., 2.28), and firm and clear steps have been taken to ensure that there will be no repetition of such an incident (Gen., 2.15).

Just to expand on this point (as Mr Justice Hope suggests the Government might), the Report on ASIS recommends that ASIS's Directive be amended to exclude ASIS from carrying out covert action in the form of either special operations or special political action, and from undertaking training for such action. Special operations can be defined roughly as unorthodox, possibly paramilitary, activity in foreign countries designed to be used in case of war or some other crisis. Special political action is clandestine action against another country designed to further the foreign policy aims of a government, also in time of war or crisis. The development in ASIS of such a covert action capability had been accorded a priority well below that given to the development of ASIS's main intelligence gathering function, and had in practice consumed only a very small proportion of the organisation's manpower and resources. Development of this capability (as a contingency planning measure) had not proceeded very far at the time of the Sheraton incident, and-apart from such training-any action at all of this nature, either special operations or special political action, would have required prior Ministerial approval.
The Report also recommends that the use by ASIS of weapons be terminated and that ASIS's stocks of weapons, including explosives, be disposed of.
The Government has accepted and acted upon these recommendations. ASIS will not hold weapons and will not maintain a capability for special operations or special political action.

Returning to the evaluation of agencies' performance, Mr Justice Hope finds that DSD is impressive (Gen., 2.30). Its activities have expanded since 1974, and its skills and technology have thus far substantially kept up with this expansion (Gen., 2.32). It complies with the obligations which law imposes upon it (Gen., 2.17). The Government has accepted and welcomes these generally reassuring findings in relation to the agencies.

The Reports naturally contain recommendations aimed at further improving the performance of the agencies and at ensuring that they continue to act with legality and propriety. Other recommendations are directed to making the agencies more accountable.
The Government endorses most of these and is pleased to note the ready support of the agencies for the additional measures which I will now outline.
General Oversight and Accountability
Principal responsibility for oversight and accountability will, naturally, continue to rest with Ministers.

The Prime Minister, the Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Defence, and the Attorney-General-each of whom has direct Ministerial responsibility for one or more of the agencies-together with the Special Minister of State and Minister for Resources and Energy constitute the Security Committee of Cabinet. The Security Committee was established in recognition that there should be a small number of Ministers collectively tasked with developing policies for, and oversighting the performance of, the security and intelligence community. During the course of the Royal Commission the Committee deliberately, and properly, refrained from taking initiatives which would in any way have cut across His Honour's inquiry or anticipated his findings. Now, with the material contained in comprehensive reports before it and with other matters held in abeyance for the period of the Royal Commission, the Committee confronts a significant and challenging workload.

The Government has responded with a number of initiatives.
