It has instituted a regular program of meetings for the Security Committee which will bring to the security and intelligence community a more rigorous oversight than ever before in this country. The Government believes that the agencies must benefit from having the clear guidance and directions on Government policy which will emanate from these regular programmed meetings of the Committee.

To ensure that material comes before the Committee in a regular and orderly fashion, a suitably staffed, full-time Secretariat will be established in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. To strengthen its ability to advise the Security Committee on security matters, the Secretaries Committee on Intelligence and Security (S.C.I.S.) has been expanded to include the Secretaries of the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of the Special Minister of State. The Government has also affirmed the mandate of the S.C.I.S., its individual members, and other relevant agency heads for ensuring that the Committee of Ministers is kept regularly and fully informed of all relevant matters.
Mr Justice Hope has made a number of recommendations also aimed at assisting Ministers in the discharge of these functions. I now wish to set out the Government's reaction to these recommendations.

As the principal recommendation in the General Report, Mr Justice Hope recommends that there be created an Office of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security which would perform the role of independent watchdog assisting Ministers in looking after the public interest in the proper functioning of the security and intelligence agencies.

The Government accepts the recommendation, believing the proposed Office-covering as it does most of the functions of the Security Commissioner, including in particular the audit function, proposed in the ALP Submission to Mr Justice Hope-to be a valuable addition to the existing machinery. While the details will need to be finalised in legislation, the Government agrees with the thrust of what is proposed for the Office in the General Report (3.19-26) and ASIO Report (16.76-102). Basically, the Office will comprise an Inspector-General of appropriate standing, appointed after consultation with the Leader of the Opposition, and a small staff. For administrative purposes the office will be attached to the Prime Minister's portfolio.

In relation to ASIO, the Inspector-General will be able to act on his or her own initiative, or at the request of the Attorney-General, or in response to a complaint, and will report his or her findings to the Attorney. The Inspector-General's functions and powers will also include:

enquiring into and reporting to the Attorney-General on ASIO's compliance with the law and propriety; and, if required by the Attorney-General, on the appropriateness and effectiveness of particular internal procedures;
having full access to ASIO's files and other materials and power to require answers to questions; and
reviewing ASIO'S performance in opening, maintaining and culling files.
In respect of the other agencies, the Inspector-General's functions will include:
checking, as occasion requires, the legality and propriety of the activities of ASIS and DSD;
Investigating and reporting upon matters referred by the Prime Minister and Minister for Defence in respect of ONA and J10 respectively;
investigating the appropriateness and effectiveness of particular internal procedures of any agency if so required by the relevant Minister.

The Inspector-General will produce an Annual Report which will be made available to the Parliament with such editing only as would be consistent with national security, privacy and other public interest considerations, and in an unexpurgated form to the Leader of the Opposition.
Parliamentary Committee

Mr Justice Hope has also given consideration to the need for a Parliamentary Committee and has concluded that it is neither necessary nor appropriate that a special Parliamentary Committee be established to improve accountability (Gen, 3.28, ASIO, 17.34). He does, however, emphasise that this is ultimately a matter for Parliament to decide.

The Government has given a great deal of consideration to the question. It has weighed His Honour's comments about the adequacy of existing oversight and accountability measures-particularly when supplemented by the new office of Inspector-General. The Government accepts that these measures will be improved by the creation of the Office of Inspector-General. Nevertheless, it believes a further improvement can be obtained by directly involving the Parliament-on both sides and in both Houses-in imposing the discipline of an external scrutiny of the intelligence and security agencies quite independent of the Executive. While the Government has been conscious also of the need to carefully protect intelligence and security information, it believes that appropriate arrangements can be made to ensure that a small but informed Parliamentary Committee would operate effectively in the public interest. It notes, in this regard, relevant overseas experience of Parliamentary scrutiny of intelligence and security agencies.

Although the Government will be consulting on the details of the Committee's operation, it would propose to establish the Committee by amendment to the ASIO Act, to oversight prescribed activities of ASIO relating to domestic security. The Committee would not act as a grievance mechanism-that role being given to the proposed Inspector-General-and appropriate safeguards for national security classified material would, of course, have to apply.

In relation to ASIO this Joint Parliamentary Committee would supplement, not replace, the arrangements already in place for official briefings on national intelligence and security matters, on a personal and confidential basis, to nominated members of the Opposition (an approach which Mr Justice Hope has endorsed).
Impact of Archives Act
There is one final matter affecting the general accountability of the security and intelligence agencies which requires comment.

In June 1984, this Government brought into operation the Archives Act to govern public access to Commonwealth records. Mr Justice Hope, in his General Report, has made recommendations relating to the impact of the Archives Act on the intelligence and security agencies. His Honour has raised a concern that the 30-year time limit which is applied to records under the Archives Act may be insufficient for many intelligence community records because release even after that lapse of time could still reveal sources, modus operandi and other security-sensitive information. His recommendation is that consideration be given to legislative amendments to remove operational records of security and intelligence agencies from the mandatory requirements of handover to Archives and public access after 30 years, leaving discretion with agency heads to hand over records when appropriate.

The intelligence community has strongly supported Mr Justice Hope's recommendations and has raised with the Government its concerns about the adequacy of, and feasibility of applying, the safeguards in the Act against compromising the large volume of sensitive documents held, many of which have been provided in confidence by overseas sources. At the same time, the community acknowledges both that its records contain documents of major historical significance, and the Government's commitment to ensuring that these records are preserved and, where possible, made available for public access.

The Government takes very seriously its duty to protect the confidentiality of intelligence, its sources and the means by which it is obtained. However, it believes that safeguards in the Archives Act have been appropriately designed and have not been shown to be deficient: the provisions of Section 29 of the Archives Act were developed to have the effect of exempting the intelligence agencies from the 'mandatory transfer' provision referred to by His Honour (Gen., 4.31); and beyond this, in the event of a request for access, the Act provides a range of exemption provisions and for conclusive Ministerial certificates to protect security sensitive information.
The Government will ensure, however, that the intelligence community's concern and experiences are specifically addressed in the review of the Archives Act which is scheduled for 1987.
ASIO Report

Turning now to the Report on ASIO, I primarily wish to address four main groups of recommendations: those directed at strengthening Ministerial control; those relating to amendment of the ASIO Act to redefine ASIO's jurisdiction; those affecting the role of the Security Appeals Tribunal; and those proposing the gathering together of a range of protective security measures under the Special Minister of State.
Strengthening of Ministerial
Control

Mr Justice Hope has recommended that the Attorney-General's control over ASIO be significantly expanded and his Department be given a larger role in support of him. He has proposed that the Director-General of Security, in the performance of his functions, be subject to the direction of the advice he should give (ASIO, 16.46). The proposal includes appropriate control mechanisms. The Government endorses his recommendations.

His Honour has also recommended that the Attorney-General be given power to issue guidelines relating to a number of areas of ASIO activity. The guidelines will have the status of administrative directions; where appropriate will be tabled in Parliament; and will be given to the Leader of the Opposition. The areas to be covered will include intelligence collection, targetting, review of file holdings, and the extent of ASIO involvement in investigating activities which might involve the hindering of the Defence Force function (ASIO, 16.52). The Government endorses these recommendations, and has also decided that the Security Committee will approve the guidelines to be issued by the Attorney-General.
Amendments to ASIO Act

His Honour has recommended significant changes to the definition of 'security' contained in the ASIO Act. The effect of the changes proposed is to allow ASIO's functions and activities to be more carefully defined and limited (ASIO, Chapters 3, 4, 5).

The Government accepts the main thrust of these recommendations. I don't intend repeating all of the details-I invite honourable Senators to give them careful study in the lead up to the future introduction of amendments to the ASIO Act. I will comment that the Government is particularly pleased that the general direction of the changes would:
give full recognition to the policy that ASIO should not be concerned with the activities of persons which involve only lawful protest or dissent (ASIO, 4.91 (H));

see the term 'subversion' deleted from the definition of 'security' (ASIO, 5.54 (B)) in favour of a concept of 'politically motivated violence' which covers a much narrower definition of the contentious notion of 'subversion';
make separate provision dealing with activities directed to promoting violence between different communal groups (ASIO, 4.91(F));and

delete the term 'active measures of foreign intervention' from the definition of 'security' and substitute a more tightly defined definition of 'acts of foreign interference' along the lines suggested by His Honour. Concern has been expressed in some quarters about the ambiguities and potential dangers inherent in the term 'agent of influence'. By changing the emphasis in the concept of 'foreign interference' from activities designed to advance the interests of a foreign country to activities that will have a result detrimental for Australia, this recommendation should allay those concerns.

The Government also accepts Mr Justice Hope's recommendation that there should be separate provision dealing with activities directed to obstructing, hindering or interfering with the performance by the Defence Force of its Activities (ASIO, 4.91 (D)). The Government proposes to add to this provision as proposed by Mr Justice Hope a further requirement that the acts concerned be not only intended to, but likely to, obstruct, hinder or interfere. I reiterate that these provisions will be subject to the policy on lawful dissent.

Another significant amendment of the ASIO Act would result from Mr Justice Hope's proposal that ASIO, under warrant, collect foreign intelligence in Australia-that is, information concerning the capabilities, policies and activities of foreign powers or bodies (ASIO, 6.82, 6.84, 6.87).

His Honour concludes, and the Government agrees, that it would be highly advantageous for Australia to provide for the collection of such intelligence (ASIO, 6.80). The Government also agrees that if this is to be done it must be regulated by legislation (as is the case in the United States and Canada and as is being introduced in the United Kingdom), and any such legislation would need to ensure, as His Honour recognises, that no Australian person or corporation would be the target of operations involving such collection (ASIO, 6.84). We will be giving further consideration to the complex issues raised by this recommendation.
Security Appeals Tribunal

Mr Justice Hope recommends a number of procedural and jurisdictional changes for the Security Appeals Tribunal (S.A.T.). These stem from the requirement to report on whether there is adequate provision for effective redress for persons who may be unjustifiably disadvantaged by action of the agencies. With an exception I will now address, these recommendations will be the subject of a further Submission by the Attorney-General.
As already mentioned, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security will be empowered, as part of improved redress procedures, to investigate complaints by individuals.

Beyond this, Mr Justice Hope has recommended that in any case where a report by ASIO may result in action adverse to the interests of an individual, and where the individual does not already have a right to review of that report, the Attorney-General may refer the matter to the S.A.T. for advice on the appropriate procedures to be followed by the Government having regard to the interests of the person who is exposed to possible prejudice (ASIO, 17.58). It is suggested that the Tribunal could be asked to consider whether the person should be given notice and an opportunity of testing the ASIO information on which the Government is proposing to act or has taken interim action (ASIO, 17.58).

The Government accepts the desirability of being able to draw on independent advice in the circumstances outlined. However, it is concerned that the recommendation may place the S.A.T., a quasi-judicial body, in the position of giving advice to Government on aspects of the handling of a developing security matter.
The Government intends, therefore, to incorporate this advisory role in the functions of the proposed Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security.
Protective Security

Chapters 9-12 of the ASIO Report deal with protective security matters. Key recommendations set out at Chapter 12, paragraphs 77-79, are that the Special Minister of State be given responsibility for protective security policy and co-ordination, and that a high level committee be convened by the Department of the Special Minister of State to co-ordinate protective security measures, with representation from ASIO and other agencies with specialist security expertise, and from the major user departments.

The Government recognises that under existing arrangements responsibility for protective security policy is vested in a number of departments and agencies. There is, therefore, some attraction to the idea of bringing protective security policy under one department and developing the machinery for co-ordination. Such a rationalisation inevitably carries with it resource and cost implications. Accordingly, the Government is carefully examining whether the benefits of centralisation outweigh these costs.
ONA/JIO Report
ONA

After making his favourable findings about ONA, to which I referred earlier and which the Government endorses, Mr Justice Hope went on to suggest that there was scope for ONA more actively to encourage departments to recognise and use its analytical skills and to co-operate with it in its work (ONA/JIO, 3.163). To this end he suggested the establishment of a National Intelligence Committee, or N.I.C. (Gen., 2.38, ONA/JIO, 3.169-170, 5.47), chaired by ONA and including senior representatives of policy departments and JIO, with representatives of the intelligence collection agencies present as observers.

The Government agrees with His Honour, and accordingly accepts the recommendations of paragraphs 3.169 (A) and (B) of the Report on ONA and JIO. Appropriate administrative action is being taken to give effect to that decision.
Mr Justice Hope suggests four functions for the N.I.C., involving it in:
the development of ONA's work program;
monitoring ONA's product;
advising ONA on intelligence needs and priorities; and
considering all ONA's assessments.

The Government agrees with the first three suggested functions for the N.I.C. Policy departments are already drawn into these things in a variety of ways, but it would be a useful improvement to have them done more formally, and in a multilateral way, in an N.I.C.

The Government does not accept that the N.I.C. should be given the fourth recommended function-that of considering all ONA's assessments. In the Government's view this would result in a most unwieldy system, would greatly reduce ONA's output, would make very difficult the preservation of ONA's independence, and could quite easily lead to the introduction of departmental policy preferences into ONA's assessments.
JIO

As with his recommendations on ONA, Mr Justice Hope's main recommendations in respect of JIO are directed towards improving the process of consultation between JIO and its main customers. He also makes suggestions for improving JIO's organisation, manning, training, and some aspects of its co-ordination and forward planning.
The Minister for Defence will be advising the Government on what action to take in response to the detailed recommendations and suggestions on the JIO.
DSD Report
As I have said, the DSD Report is not being published but it is appropriate at this stage to make some comment about the DSD charter.
Following consideration of the reports of the earlier Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security, the then Prime Minister in 1977 broadly outlined the role and functions of DSD.

Mr Justice Hope has now recommended that the Government consider making public the DSD Directive with amendments where necessary for security reasons. This Government has issued DSD with a new Directive which differs only slightly, and not in matters of substance, from the previous Directive under which DSD operated. We agree with Mr Justice Hope that publication on the Directive will allow the Australian public to obtain a clearer appreciation of DSD's role and functions and may allay misconceptions about the organisation.
Concluding Remarks

As I have indicated in this statement, the Government has accepted and welcomed His Honour's findings, and has accepted most of his principal recommendations. More work remains to be done in responding to his other recommendations and in the area of implementation. The Government will ensure that there is no delay to this work, and that its results will be made known as appropriate.

When all is finished, I have no doubt that Australia's intelligence and security services will be more efficient and effective than they now are, that they will be run with even greater regard for legality and propriety, and that their accountability and oversight will be further strengthened. These will be worthwhile gains-to the Australian people, to the Australian Government, and to the Australian security and intelligence community itself.
Defence Signals Directorate Directive

1. The Commonwealth Government requires the maintenance of a capability to collect, produce and disseminate foreign signal intelligence and to advise the Government on all matters pertaining to the security of signal communications and related equipments.
2. The capability will be located in:
a. the organisation in the Department of Defence known as the ''Defence Signals Directorate'' (DSD); and
b. specialist units of the Defence Force.
FUNCTIONS
3. In respect of signal intelligence, the functions of DSD and the specialist units of the Defence Force referred to in paragraph 2 above shall be:
a. to develop and maintain a capability to provide signal intelligence in support of the Defence Force; and
b. to collect, produce and disseminate foreign signal intelligence to meet the national requirements of the Commonwealth Government.
4. In respect of communications security, the functions of DSD shall be:

a. to provide materials, advice and assistance to Commonwealth Government departments and authorities and the Defence Force on matters relevant to the security of their communications and electronic and related activities; and
b. through the Secretary to the Department of Defence, to keep the Secretaries' Committee on Intelligence and Security generally informed on the state of communications security.
Organisational Principles

5. Policy control and managerial oversight over the national intelligence community, external and internal, is exercised by the Security Committee of Cabinet in respect of targets, priorities, activities, organisational requirements, broad allocation of resources, performance and co-ordination and inter-relationships of the various agencies. In the performance of its functions DSD, as a component of the national intelligence community, shall accept the guidance on targets and priorities issued from time to time by the Security Committee of Cabinet.

6. The Australian capability in signal intelligence shall be maintained in DSD and the Defence Force for national purposes generally. DSD shall be the national communications security advisory authority and as such shall maintain the expertise required to carry out those functions detailed in paragraph 4 above.
7. DSD shall be an outrider organisation in the Department of Defence. The Director, DSD shall control DSD and shall be responsible to the Secretary to the Department of Defence.

8. Specialist units of the Defence Force, and Defence Force personnel engaged in signal intelligence and communications security tasks, shall be subject to the command arrangements made by or under the authority of the Chief of the Defence Force. Members of the Defence Force may be loaned or seconded for service with DSD.
Operating Guidelines
9. DSD and units of the Defence Force engaged in signal intelligence and communications security functions shall operate in conformity with Australian law.
10. DSD shall maintain direct contact with appropriate Commonwealth Government departments and authorities and the Defence Force as regards signal intelligence and communications security matters.

11. DSD shall be the Australian national authority on signal intelligence and communications security matters. DSD shall conduct liaison on signal intelligence and communications security matters on behalf of the Australian Government as appropriate with counterpart agencies or authorities in other countries and shall maintain overseas technical representation as is necessary.

12. The Director, DSD shall furnish to the Secretary to the Department of Defence and to the Chief of the Defence Force an Annual Report which shall include an account of the performance of DSD in relation to the functions stated in paragraphs 3 and 4 above.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the tabling of the report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies by Mr Justice Hope, in discharge of his commission to investigate Australia's security and intelligence agencies. The report, of course, not only deals with a most important subject but also is delivered by a man of very high authority on that subject who has, in these reports, again demonstrated his deep understanding of the problems of intelligence and security and the need for such organisations and his ability to make valuable contributions about their work and role and about the legislation governing them.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Justice Hope was first appointed a royal commissioner for the Royal Commission into Intelligence and Security in 1974. His final reports to the Fraser Government in 1976 and 1977 were a thoroughgoing review of Australia's intelligence and security bodies which made a large number of recommendations about them and about legislation in respect of them, which were largely implemented by the Fraser Government in succeeding years, particularly with the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act in 1979 and the establishment of the Office of National Assessments, known as ONA.

It was certainly always the view of the former Government that from time to time there should be a judicial audit, namely, an external review by a judicial officer, of the way the organisations were working. That was made clear when the present Director-General of Security, Mr Barnett, was appointed in 1981. Therefore, when this Government decided to appoint Mr Justice Hope as a royal commissioner on Australia's security and intelligence agencies in May 1983, that decision was welcomed and supported by the Opposition, despite the fact that his appointment was somewhat accelerated and a lot of his early period as the royal commissioner was taken up with investigating the Combe-Ivanov affair.

This exercise has now culminated in these reports, which were made to the Government in December last and which are now tabled in this Parliament together with a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which has been tabled and incorporated in Hansard by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). This completes the work of a general review of Australia's security and intelligence agencies and, as I have said, it makes a large number of important and interesting recommendations. Of course, they will have to be the subject of a great deal of attention by the Government and the Opposition and by this Parliament in due course. No doubt, legislation will be brought forward and will be debated in this chamber. Also, numerous recommendations can be given effect to by administrative action. No doubt the Government and the intelligence agencies will be directing their minds to those matters.

The overwhelming matter which emerges from this report is the very favourable bill of health that Mr Justice Hope gives to intelligence agencies in Australia. Of course, these include not only the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation but also the Australia Secret Intelligence Service, the Office of National Assessments, the Joint Intelligence Organisation and the Defence Signals Directorate. In the time available, I will concentrate my remarks on ASIO, but it is important to recognise that the findings of Mr Justice Hope were made in relation to all the intelligence and security agencies. In his general report, under the heading 'Value of intelligence services', Mr Justice Hope says, referring to the Royal Commission into Intelligence and Security-that was his earlier inquiry:

. . . I reported that Australia needs intelligence of quality, timeliness and relevance, and that for this purpose it requires to have a highly professional system of intelligence and security services. These needs are as important now as they were a decade ago, and indeed the matters in respect of which Australia requires intelligence have expanded considerably.

The product of Australia's intelligence services is of great value to the nation. No doubt there will always be room for improvement, and no doubt their need for resources will always have to be measured against the proper claims of other national interests. I am satisfied, however--
this is Mr Justice Hope's final conclusion-

that Australia's investment in its intelligence services is well justified, and that governments should continue to ensure that they are able to fulfil the important roles they play in helping to advise and protect Australia's national interests.

That finding by Mr Justice Hope after his second inquiry into Australia's intelligence services and agencies, that conclusion by a man of his experience and proven record, is of the utmost importance. Of course, it is in great contrast to the sort of rubbish that is constantly expressed in the media and in this Parliament including, I am sad to say, in this Senate from time to time, about Australia's intelligence agencies, and to the muck-raking, cynicism, abuse and snide remarks that so frequently emanate particularly from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party and sections of the media about these vitally important bodies.

It is very valuable, sobering and important that we should have a contribution of this kind from a man such as Mr Justice Hope. I and the Opposition greatly welcome the way in which he has expressed his conclusions and emphasised the importance of the work of these agencies and the need for them. It is very interesting, for instance, that, after so much unfavourable publicity in recent times about ASIS, the statement that the Leader of the Government has put down refers to ASIS as having achieved success over the last decade. In referring to Mr Justice Hope's conclusions, it states:

ASIS has achieved success over the last decade in organising and reorganising to achieve its goals . . . its effectiveness and efficiency, and its contribution to Australia's intelligence, will continue to grow as a consequence of the closer relationship with other areas of government . . .
I particularly wish to quote this part:
The Sheraton Hotel incident was not representative of the quality or professionalism exhibited by ASIS in performing its principal tasks.

As I have said, the intelligence agencies, particularly ASIO and ASIS, are always good for a headline when something goes wrong or extravagant claims are made about them. Unfortunately, the public is always served with criticism, and often quite extravagant criticism, of these agencies. Yet here we have a report, following close investigation of these agencies over a period of 18 months, by a man of the highest authority, in which he puts into perspective the true position of these agencies and explains the true value of their work. It is very heartening to read conclusions of that kind. As I said, the Sheraton Hotel incident was not representative of the quality of the work of ASIS.

I wish to turn now to deal particularly with the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, which certainly figures in the major report that has been tabled. There are confidential reports about the other agencies but the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the body on which the most information has been made available and which seems, sadly, always to attract the greatest attention and suffer the greatest misrepresentation, is the subject of a very substantial report that has been tabled today. Mr Justice Hope has made some very interesting and important remarks and has drawn conclusions about ASIO which we welcome and which I think put ASIO in a proper perspective. He makes the point, and this is a very important point, that he investigated ASIO in 1974-75 and reported upon it in 1976. He returned to look at it again in 1983-84. Of course, in that time so much of his earlier recommendations have been implemented and the Organisation has changed considerably. He recognises this when he states:
The ASIO that I have reviewed is very different from the ASIO that I got to know during the RCIS.
that was his earlier royal commission--

It has broken away from the rather unthinking pursuit of old targets, and the laxity of standards that characterised the Organisation then. ASIO as it operates now under the present Act is more focussed in its activities and much more conscious of the sensitivities pertaining to, and the proper limits of, its activities.
Later in the report he states:
My overall view is that ASIO has properly served the interests of the Australian people and Government in recent years and that it has done so with a fair degree of effectiveness.

Those are very welcome conclusions. It is very welcome to have the work of such an important body as ASIO put into this proper perspective by a man with the authority to do so. I hope that this will go a long way to providing ASIO with a much more responsible Press than it has received in the past, and that it will go a long way to eliminating the sort of unthinking criticism which has been directed at the organisation, particularly in the last couple of years. Unfortunately, we cannot escape the conclusion that ASIO has suffered by this constant attack which it is unable to answer. In Mr Justice Hope's general report he states:

Morale is an important factor in achieving effectiveness and efficiency. ASIO's morale is not high at the present time. There are several reasons for this. One of the more important reasons is the battering (in my opinion quite unjustified, except in relation to a limited number of mistakes which it made in its reports of facts) which it took from the media at the time of the inquiry into the Ivanov-Combe affair. Time will heal that scar, but it is incumbent on those responsible for leading the organisation to restore the firm belief which its officers must have in ASIO's purpose, and in the importance of that purpose to the nation.

It is a worrying finding that morale in the Organisation is not high at present. There may be reasons for it. Undoubtedly, that comes not only from the battering to which Mr Justice Hope refers but also, as I have said, from the constant snide remarks, cynicism, extravagant complaints and claims that have been made about it and have been fuelled by the media. These have led ultimately to this loss of morale. This report by Mr Justice Hope will, if properly reported and properly understood by the critics of ASIO, go a long way to restoring morale.

As I have said, since Mr Justice Hope's previous report, a great deal of work has been done since to build up the Organisation, to give it better leadership and better resources and thereby to increase its morale and effectiveness. That was certainly being achieved and had been largely successful until the events of a couple of years ago. I hope that, by the Government acting on Mr Justice Hope's expressions of concern about these matters and maintaining the Organisation's resources, that problem will be overcome. It is interesting to note Mr Justice Hope's summary of the increased resources, both financial and staff, that were made available to the Organisation over the years following his previous report, principally during the term of the Fraser Government. This is mentioned in his report on ASIO, in which he states:
Its expenditure grew from $7.8m in 1976-77 to $27.176m in 1983-84 . . .

In real terms there has been an increase of 122% over this period. This represents a significant increase in resources. Staff numbers have increased by 42% between 1 July 1977 and 1 July 1984. During the period, ASIO improved its recruitment processes and attracted large numbers of young graduates for whom it devised a 'generalist intelligence officer' career program, involving training and experience throughout the organisation. This recruitment process has given ASIO staffing a noticeable 'new look'.

That summarises, in a very practical way, the changes that have been made to ASIO in recent years and the very great increase in its professionalism. Elsewhere in Mr Justice Hope's report he recognises-I would like to add my own comment in support of this recognition-the leadership that was given to the organisation by Mr Justice Woodward during his term as the Director-General of Security. This work has been carried on successfully-this is also recognised by Mr Justice Hope-by the present Director-General of Security, Mr Harvey Barnett.

I turn from the discussion of the general findings about ASIO and the changes that have been made to the Organisation and the professional standing it has been able to achieve despite various batterings that it has received, to some of the more specific recommendations that Mr Justice Hope has made. Clearly, one of the major problems for a secret intelligence organisation is the way in which it can defend itself or it can be defended in public and at the same time not be compromised in its very nature as a secret intelligence organisation. The problem has been that extravagant complaints and criticisms are made which mostly cannot be answered. We are all familiar in this chamber with the rule that successive governments have adopted of not commenting on matters relating to security where some of the most extravagant and untrue allegations are made. This puts a strain on the Organisation and does add to the problems of morale. Mr Justice Hope recommends that this policy should be continued. He states:

I have concluded that the interests of Australia would be best served by an adherence to the traditional practice except in very special circumstances, whether the allegations are correct or incorrect.

The only question I raise is whether there should ever be any exceptions to that rule because once exceptions are made the question will always be asked, if the Government has made a statement in respect of one particular allegation and refuses to make one on another, whether it is perhaps thereby indirectly admitting that such an allegation was correct. It is a very awkward problem. A much greater understanding is required by members of parliament, who should be exhibiting a great degree of responsibility in regard to these questions.

Mr Justice Hope has tackled some of the major issues. His recommendations cannot be gone into now because time does not permit it. But he has faced up to the very sensitive questions of the accountability and relationship of ASIO to the Minister responsible for it and the government of the day. He has faced up to the questions of the nature of its charter, problems relating to definitions of subversion and matters of that kind. There are recommendations on all these matters. He has recommended the creation of a new body or office of Inspector General of Intelligence and Security. That recommendation is in lieu of the sort of regular judicial audit which he has conducted on this occasion. He suggests that there should be the appointment of an office of this kind and that that should be an ongoing process-an ombudsman for the security and intelligence agencies. I think that is one of the major recommendations that he has made.

The recommendation is certainly one that the Opposition can understand and it has merit. We will give great consideration to it. The concern we have, as Mr Justice Hope appreciates, is whether a body of that kind would interfere with the important relationship between the Director-General of Security and the Attorney-General who is in charge of the Organisation. It sometimes involves the Prime Minister. That constant line of communication and that very important responsibility must be preserved and the creation of a new office of Inspector General of Security could cause problems in that regard and, therefore, it will have to be given closer consideration.

Mr Justice Hope, however, rejects the proposal for an external review by a parliamentary committee. In that respect the Opposition will certainly welcome Mr Justice Hope's recommendation. We would be opposed to the Government's rejection of that recommendation. In the ministerial statement the Government has rejected Mr Justice Hope's recommendation that there should not be a parliamentary committee. It has done so obviously because of the ideological pressures that have been brought to bear by the very elements in the Australian Labor Party which have done so much to create the sorts of problems for ASIO which I have been dealing with, which are set out in Mr Justice Hope's report.

In relation to the discharge of ministerial responsibility in relation to ASIO, Mr Justice Hope recognises the fact that there must be some limits on ministerial control. As I understand it, the Labor Party's submission to Mr Justice Hope was to give unlimited ministerial control over ASIO. Mr Justice Hope has rejected that and has made other suggestions, all of which are very valuable and must be given further consideration. He recognises this great danger that unlimited, unfettered ministerial control of ASIO could lead to the misuse of ministerial power, for political reasons, by the Minister or the government of the day. That is one of the sensitive areas of the present Act, which provides mechanisms to prevent that occurring and to prevent a Minister being able to demand information about an individual or to order inquiries to be made in relation to an individual. I think that is a very important protection of individual rights. It is a protection for the Minister who is responsible for ASIO and a protection for the Organisation itself against a Minister who may be tempted to use it for improper purposes. Very great care must be taken in how that relationship is defined. Mr Justice Hope is well aware of that problem and his recommendations for making some further changes in the Act in that respect, as in many other areas, deserve close and sympathetic consideration.

In conclusion, these are most valuable and important reports which deserve a great deal more study and attention by the Government and by members of this chamber and the other place. The legislation which no doubt will be brought in will be another opportunity to debate them here. The Opposition is very relieved indeed by the findings of the report in relation to the way in which these organisations have performed and their importance. I hope that a number of the comments and findings that Mr Justice Hope has made, particularly where he reports the investigations that he made of complaints he received, will be noted. He shows how little substance-in fact, in most cases no substance-there seems to have been in almost all of the complaints that he received. The only thing that surprises me is that he did not receive more complaints in view of the sort of misrepresentation and the extravagant comments that are made so much of in the media about these organisations. Mr Justice Hope has gone to great lengths to investigate these complaints and to lay to rest the concerns that have been created in many people's minds because of them. This is very satisfactory and I think we can all take great satisfaction in the findings that he has made, the very sober reports that he has given us and the very strong support that he has given to the need to have well resourced and effective intelligence and security organisations. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my comments today by commending the work of Mr Justice Hope in producing the report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies and by welcoming the contents of the documents that we have before us. In general I must say on behalf of the Australian Democrats that we are favourably disposed to many of the recommendations contained in the documents, but I must stress that it is important that time be given for detailed evaluation. We have been given some four hours between the receipt of these reports and the debate coming on today and that is hardly time enough for any political party or any senator to come to definitive conclusions and make definitive statements.
—Don't be so modest, I think you can handle it.

—Thank you, Senator. I am not so sure that that confidence is justified. Nevertheless, I repeat that it is important that time be given for detailed evaluation so that we do not rush into decisions that could be seen as purely political, particularly if they run contrary to recommendations made by Mr Justice Hope in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The most significant features of the documents before us today undoubtedly include the appointment of the Inspector-General as a sort of ombudsman, the disarming, so to speak, of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, after the unfortunate Sheraton incident, the whole question of whether there should be a joint parliamentary committee to oversee the operations of our security organisations-a committee that presumably would operate in a similar fashion to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority-the change to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation requiring a more clearly defined attitude to lawful political dissent, the tightening of the concepts of 'agent of influence' arising of course out of the Combe-Ivanov affair, and finally, the removal of the covert operations capability of ASIS. It is unquestionable that if the work that Mr Justice Hope has done is brought to fruition through government action and if the majority of the recommendations are taken into account the result must be a better intelligence operations system in Australia.

The Hope Royal Commission was established, as has already been indicated by Senator Durack, in May 1983 to undertake a major review of Australia's security and intelligence services. It reported in December of that year on the Combe-Ivanov affair. It reported again in February 1984 on the Sheraton Hotel incident and its final report of December last year is the report that has been tabled today.

It speaks volumes for the experience and ability of Mr Justice Hope that so much has been achieved by him in such a relatively short time. These final reports comprise a general report and individual reports on ASIO, ASIS and the Defence Signals Directorate and a combined report on the Office of National Assessments and the Joint Intelligence Organisation. I understand the Government consulted with Mr Justice Hope about the publication of these reports and it is tabling an edited version of the general, ASIO and combined ONA-JIO reports but not the ASIS or the DSD reports. The Government has not yet reached a final position on the hundreds of recommendations and suggestions that have been made, and nor should it in view of the comments that I made a few moments ago. But it has responded to the major findings and recommendations and these have been outlined in the statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) today on the final report of the Hope Royal Commission.

As the Minister has already said, Mr Justice Hope reiterated in the report his view that Australia needs intelligence of quality, timeliness and relevance and requires a highly professional system of intelligence and security services. That is something which I suspect a lot of people thought we lacked, as a result of that Mickey Mouse incident some months back. The Government endorses this view, as do the Australian Democrats and, I suggest, as do most reasonable people. Mr Justice Hope concluded that, while there are deficiencies in some agencies-and I suspect that our previous Attorney-General who had to field questions over this last year would endorse that-generally they are performing efficiently and effectively. According to him, ASIO has improved its structure, making it more responsive to pre-determined policies and ensuring that it operates within its charter. He has, however, called for improvement in its management and administration.

Among other things, Mr Justice Hope notes that ONA is held in high regard by other intelligence agencies-although I am not sure whether that says a great deal sometimes-and produces valuable intelligence reports. He notes that the JIO is competent and professional and produces work of a high standard and that ASIS has achieved success in its reorganisation. He asserts that the Sheraton Hotel incident was not representative and that firm steps have been taken to ensure that there will be no repetition of the incident. It is worth noting that Mr Justice Hope recommends that the ASIS directive be amended to exclude covert actions in the form either of special operations or special political action and the undertaking of training for such action. Development of this capability had not proceeded very far at the time of the Sheraton incident for which, one presumes, we must be all duly thankful. Mr Justice Hope also recommends that the use of weapons by ASIS be terminated and that current stocks be disposed of. The Government, not unreasonably, has accepted this suggestion. Mr Justice Hope also notes that DSD is impressive and that it complies with its legal obligations. Again, I am sure that all people listening will be pleased about that.

Turning to the detail of the report, Mr Justice Hope acknowledges that the principal responsibility for general oversight and accountability will continue to rest with Ministers, as indeed it should. I understand that the national security committee of cabinet is to look at the recommendations, that a full time secretariat is to be established and that the secretaries' committee on intelligence and security will be expanded. The principal recommendation in the general report concerns the creation of an Office of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security to act as an independent watchdog. We support this recommendation, as does the Government.

Mr Justice Hope concluded that a special parliamentary committee was not necessary or appropriate. However, apparently the Government believes that a joint parliamentary committee of the sort which was established in tandem with the National Crime Authority is desirable. This is far too important an issue for us to comment on at the moment. It is impossible to evaluate whether a joint parliamentary committee is desirable or whether it would be effective without proper and serious considerations. I trust that the Government is not going to rush into any action on this matter without taking the proper amount of time over it and without giving other members of parliament and organisations the opportunity to give it the same sort of consideration.

On the question of public access to Commonwealth records via the Archives Act, Mr Justice Hope considers that the 30-year time limit may be insufficient as far as intelligence community records are concerned. On the other hand, the Government appears to believe that the safeguards in the Act are adequate as far as exemption provisions with regard to sensitive material and so on are concerned. Again, I say that further considerations are needed before action is taken. I cannot stress enough that precipitate political action in security areas such as this can only do more harm than good.

As far as ASIO is concerned, there are four main groups of recommendations within the reports. These are the strengthening of ministerial control, with which the Government concurs; amendments to the ASIO Act to define more carefully its functions, again the Government agrees with this; and that procedural and jurisdictional changes to the Security Appeals Tribunal be implemented. I gather that these are to be the subject of a further submission by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). There is a separate recommendation with regard to the advisory role of the SAT. I understand that the Government believes that this role should be given to the proposed Inspector-General. Again, I suggest that some time be taken before a decision is made. The fourth group of recommendations concerns the responsibility for protective security which is to go to the Department of the Special Minister of State and that a committee be convened. The Government is still considering this recommendation.

As far as the joint ONA-JIO report is concerned, Mr Justice Hope suggests the establishment of a national intelligence committee, chaired by ONA and including senior representatives of policy departments and JIO, with representatives of the intelligence collection agencies as observers. The Government agrees with three out of four of the suggested functions of the NIC but not with the fourth recommendation, namely, that of considering all ONA's assessments. In regard to JIO, Mr Justice Hope's suggestions are directed towards improving the process of consultation between that organisation and its main customers. I understand that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is in the process of advising the Government with regard to this matter. To this stage the Defence Signals Directorate report has not been published. Mr Justice Hope has recommended making the DSD directive public, with amendments where necessary for security reasons. I gather that the Government will do so.

In conclusion, for the time being I endorse the Government's expression of thanks to Mr Justice Hope for having completed what was undoubtedly a very difficult task, with distinction. As I said a moment ago, no doubt as a result of his work and the implementation of all or some of his recommendations, Australia will have better, more efficient intelligence organisations at work. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the Senate that Mr President has received a letter from the Acting Auditor-General responding to comments in the reports of Estimates Committee A and Estimates Committee B on the timing of the presentation of the Auditor-General's report on audits completed at 31 December 1984. I table a copy of the letter for the information of honourable senators. I indicate that Mr President has forwarded copies to the Chairmen of all Estimates committees and to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Haines proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Commonwealth Government to fund programs to counteract the increasing social problem of violence against women and children.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is rather ironic that I have just finished speaking on Australia's security and intelligence agencies and now am about to launch into a discussion about the lack of security and very limited intelligence that we have on behaviour, particularly violent behaviour, towards women and children. I do not think it is excessive to say that one of the more disturbing elements of modern society is unquestionably the matter of violence towards women and children and the fact that in some 80 per cent of those incidents of violence the perpetrator is a close relative or friend. This is not to say that violence against women and children has been unknown in the past, because that is not so.

SPEECH.PARA: What is so disturbing about the incidents of assault, sexual assault, rape and incest, as well as various forms of psychological and emotional trauma visited on women and children by the men closest to them, is the fact that we are allegedly living in a civilised society where men and women are supposedly equal and where the vulnerability of children should be recognised. Yet we are currently faced with a situation in which the majority of victims in cases of domestic murder are women. An estimated 30,000 to 100,000 cases of incest occur in Australia every year. In fact a total of 1,578 sexual assaults on children were reported to a single agency last year, namely, the Department of Youth and Community Services child protection hotline in New South Wales. An article in Police Life of March this year in Victoria said that 83 per cent of sexual abuse cases were committed by a trusted friend or family member, and there is still a deplorable tendency for some sections in the community to pretend that a lot of this does not happen, but that if it does the victims themselves were largely responsible because of some form of inappropriate behaviour on their part.

I acknowledge that the extent of violence against women is very hard to assess. Inadequate statistics, under-reporting, arrest avoidance and a reluctance to take legal action for a variety of reasons, including the horrors sometimes of court proceedings, are just some of the factors that make an accurate assessment of the situation practically impossible. But the statistics which are available indicate that the problem is widespread, that it occurs across all age, social, economic and ethnic ranges and that it is a huge drain on resources, ranging from law enforcement to social welfare, to health care. The most useful indicators as far as the widespreadedness, so to speak, of this problem come from accommodation figures in women's refuges and crisis care accommodation centres, although some States, such as New South Wales and South Australia, are keeping reasonable statistics through collating police and crime statistics. Nevertheless, community, police, legal and government responses to the problem leave much to be desired.

It would surprise no one to hear that law enforcement agencies are frequently called to situations involving family violence. It has been reported for many years that the only mention of domestic violence made to police officers in training situations has been a negative one. They are told that, as far as possible, they should avoid becoming involved in domestic arguments. They are told that the parties are likely to unite again and generally to unite against the well-meaning police officer. In fact, of course, many women who are victims of criminal assault at home put up with the violence rather than call the police. Yet as it is a crime to beat, bash and abuse another human being, presumably including the human being to whom one happens to be married-although I understand there are some people who would question that-the question which arises is: Why, when police are called by a victim, do they still fail in some States to take action which they would otherwise have taken if a stranger beat, bashed or abused another person on the street? There is no question that a regrettable double standard exists in this situation. An extract from the book Even in the Best of Homes typifies this sort of situation. The woman wrote:

I called the police several times. Sometimes I went to the police station. They didn't come every time I called. They told me they didn't like being involved in domestic violence. They told me there was nothing they could do. They told me to tell my lawyers to get off their--
expletive deleted-
and do something . . .
She pointed out at that stage that she had a court injunction to protect her from violence but that it was not very satisfactory. She said:

Often my husband had fled the scene by the time they arrived. He conveniently came back every time . . . they left . . . I was usually sporting huge bruises whenever I saw them, and once my step-daughter came home in the middle of it and rang the police herself, but even that didn't make any difference. They still said they couldn't arrest him, or charge him with anything or do anything at all. I begin to wonder what the police are for.

When we consider the difference between the police action in that sort of case and what it would have been if two strangers had been indulging in one-sided fisticuffs, we realise she is probably quite right. Again, there is probably no need in this place to canvass the sorry history of laws which, for a long time, enshrined the traditional right of a man to rule his household, including the euphemistically described right of chastisement. There are still men today who argue that a man has every right to give his spouse a clip around the ears when she does not do what he wants, and that may range from getting his tea on the table when he comes home to providing sexual services whenever he demands it. Wife beating, of course, is no longer explicitly condoned by society or by the law, but the persistent belief that it may be justifiable has frequently rendered such legal sanctions as do exist ineffective. There is an obvious legislative and judicial reluctance to place a wife's safety before the liberty of the husband. In fact, it is often said in rape cases that it is better that 10 women be raped and the rapist be not caught than that one innocent man be unfairly tried. I do not know that that ever applies to crimes against property. It certainly seems to apply to crimes against women.

The requirement of proof beyond a reasonable doubt in criminal law is inherently difficult to achieve in situations of family violence because witnesses are rare and those witnesses who are present are often very young children and counter allegations are common. A review of the legal remedies available to victims of family violence reveals several glaring weaknesses, including the lack of immediate protection for threatened victims, the inadequate enforcement of existing sanctions, the limited legal protection available to people not legally married but whose relationship exposes them to the same threats, the inability of the court system to direct the parties to support services-indeed, the limited number of support services which are available-and of the courts to require the parties to negotiate a constructive resolution to the problem, and, finally, the enormous social, emotional and financial costs to the victims of family violence.

The ultimate goal of legal reforms, I would suggest, must be the embodiment of the two aspects of protection: First, to remove immediate sources of danger, and to deter future resort to violence as a secondary measure. Only strong law enforcement will demonstrate that society opposes the use of physical force as a means of resolving disputes, whatever the circumstances. Unfortunately, all too often society is presented with, for its approval, quite the reverse of that. An article in the West Australian of 13 April this year, headed 'Macho figures take some blame', states:
Macho heroes such as actor Clint Eastwood have a lot to answer for . . .
The ideals they stand for-male dominance, female subjection, violence as the way of dealing with most problems-provide a social climate in which rapists thrive.

Indeed, it is a climate in which violent men can justify their behaviour. The courts also have a case to answer as far as their treatment of incest is concerned. I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald earlier this year headed 'Pity for the ''poor'' molester, but no justice'. The reporter notes:
The criminal justice system has all but broken down in incest cases, according to experts in this field . . . the Family Court is also far too lenient in granting access to victims.
One of the cases reported said that a mother was distraught because she discovered:
. . . her husband had been committing bizarre sexual practices on their two young children, both under the age of seven.

She then discovered, to her concern, that that man will get off scott-free and will still have access to the children. Many people are concerned that many offenders found guilty even of the serious crime of rape are released on bonds and are given access to their families. Julie Stewart, the co-ordinator of the Women's Legal Resource Centre, said:
When offenders can rape their children usually with impunity and can get access to their children through the Family Court, as now happens on a large scale, it shows just how hopeless the system is.

That also contradicts a comment that was made in Adelaide recently by a gentleman from the Central Methodist Mission who said that even when there is a hint of violence husbands are not given access to their children. That is patently false. We also need to challenge the myth of the Lolita figure-the argument that girls, in particular, entice or encourage their fathers to assault them sexually. One wonders after one has been to a place such as the Adelaide Children's Hospital or talked to anybody else who has had dealings in this area how an 18-month old baby girl can entice anyone to do anything. Society needs to assess the myths that it throws up to justify its frequent lack of action in this area. We also need to end the myth that if women behaved appropriately the bashings they are sometimes forced to undergo would not occur. The Age in April ran a story entitled 'The blind distress of deserted wife-bashers' in which it is said:
These men often insisted that everything would be fine when their partners returned home.

The article stated that the men felt that their wives tended to over-react and that it would all get sorted out if the two could only get back together again. They would behave in an embarrassed way and describe their behaviour as a regrettable loss of control, usually associated in their minds with drinking; or deny it; or dismiss their actions as just a shove or a clip over the ear. The article continued:

Generally they seemed to believe that it was up to their partners to behave in a way which would not incite them-that is the men-to violence. They often thought, however, that their partners had problems ranging from over-sensitivity, to being unable to control the kids, or failing to learn to stay out of the man's way when he had had a hard day--

A classic case of blaming the victim. Where do we go from here? That the problem is there is undeniable. That resources are limited and often inappropriately extended is also undeniable. It is important then that the services that we offer women and children to whom violence has become a way of life are orientated towards the family as a whole.

Two crucial aspects I think need to be stressed when considering the sorts of services that governments should be providing. First, they must not be developed as a replacement for the refuge system or used as an excuse to curtail the much needed extension of that system. There is no question at all in my mind or those of many other people that when women are fleeing from an intolerable and violent situation what they need most is the psychological, emotional and counselling support of other women who understand what they have been through. They do not need to be immediately judged, questioned or asked to consider how they have exacerbated or brought on the problem. Those services must not only be maintained; they must also be expanded.

We must also recognise the inequalities of power within domestic relationships and acknowledge that they themselves bring on many of the problems. Various reports have argued for a range of services to assist families in crisis. These reports always stress their support for refuges as well as advocating more broadly based community crisis intervention services. These centres would act as a focus for information and contact with government and voluntary services. The services need to encompass counselling and support to the family as a whole or to violent men independently. They need to incorporate referral to legal and other welfare services, as well as mediation, and they need to provide 24-hour crisis counselling such as, for example, in South Australia's crisis care unit which aims to cater for all personal emergencies in consultation with other services where necessary.
Mr David Wehner, a clinical psychologist who founded the South Australian domestic violence response team, was reported in an article in the Canberra Times. The article stated:
. . . if the Government investigated the causes of and solutions to wife and child battering as eagerly as it did for AIDS and cancer research, answers could be quickly found.
'If the community gave resources into the area of spouse abuse in proportion to the population seriously at risk . . . we probably would not have such a big problem,' he said.
Mr Wehner . . . was very critical of the Government for failing to recognise the cost and extent of domestic violence.
He said research in South Australia had shown that 10 per cent of Adelaide families were affected by domestic violence and the total cost to the State was between $7 million and $10 million.
Police were called to 20,000 domestic conflicts a year, general practitioners were seeing three or four battered women every two weeks and women's shelters were overrun.
Something similar was thrown up in an investigation in the Australian Capital Territory last year. The article went on to state:

Mr Wehner said successive governments had ignored the problems and the situation had been compounded by the criminal justice system which had abdicated its responsibility by either not charging or not punishing offenders . . .
'If the Government was serious they would not only be funding shelters and increasing the number of shelters they would be addressing the men, the offenders, systematically.
'There is no excuse for not coming up with a systematic analysis of the problem and designing and implementing an intervention system . . .

I would say that most of us would heartily agree with that. It was very disappointing therefore to note a few weeks ago that one of the very few access hand-over centres in Australia is in danger of folding for lack of Federal funding. It was a pilot project which operated in Adelaide and which had proved its effectiveness in assisting women to hand over their children to husbands who had a history of violence. It has got to the stage where some organisations in South Australia are actually encouraging women not to comply with access orders if it means that they or their children are likely to be placed in a vulnerable position. There are means by which governments can provide services and assistance to these people. For example, it has been done in Santa Clara in California and in other parts of the world to assist children who suffer from incest and women who suffer from domestic violence. There is no reason why, with good will and sufficient funding, similar assistance could not be provided to Australian women and children. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the Australian Democrats have highlighted as a matter of public importance this very important subject of the increasing social problem of violence against women and children. Senator Haines spoke at length on it, but she did not speak at any great length-indeed, less than five minutes-on the need for the Commonwealth Government to fund programs to counteract this problem. I understand that, because it is a very difficult area. I will come to it later.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is largely a hidden one; it is rarely spoken of. Families do not like airing their private problems in public, so we find that counselling services rarely get the information they need before the problem is well developed. Whilst we recognise that this is an area which is of growing concern to the community, there are only a handful of reports from State governments and there are none from the Federal Government on the subject. Even though the awareness is increasing, the reports should be more plentiful. The lack of reports is not surprising, I suppose; how can we legislate for decent human behaviour? Senator Haines, in her desire to alleviate the problem, has suggested that it can be overcome by Commonwealth funding to counteract that violence. I think 'alleviate' may have been a better word to use than 'counteract'.

I have spoken to groups of women who are affected by this tremendous problem, and even they find it very difficult to come up with sensible legal solutions with which they would be happy. Indeed, Al-Anon, which is one group of women which is very active in Tasmania, has said that most violence is associated with spouses who have an alcohol problem. The women are very definite about the fact that they will not accept money from any source at all. They have a rule that they raise any money they need, because they underline that they are a self-help group and it is only through self-help that this problem can be overcome. It is through encouragement to the members of their group that they are able to educate each other on how to alleviate the problem.

Last year the then Attorney-General signed a reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission to inquire into the legal and non-legal problems of domestic violence in the Australian Capital Territory. That sounded all very good, but the Australian Capital Territory is the last jurisdiction in Australia to look at this problem of domestic violence. The reference to the Commission limits the inquiry to violence between adults, whether or not they are married or living together, and ignores completely the area of children. I believe that is a great pity. A report in the Canberra Times of 23 October 1984 gave us some indication of the findings of a phone-in that was held last year in the Australian Capital Territory. It states:
Preliminary findings of a recent phone-in on domestic violence have blown away the myth that such violence occurred only in lower-class families . . .

The findings had shown that of about 120 people responding to the phone-in, 40 per cent of offenders came from professional, managerial or senior administrative positions, and 32 per cent came from trade and manual positions.
The survey response (0.05 per cent of the Canberra population)--
so not a very big percentage of the Canberra population used the phone-in-
had been ''comparatively high'', and represented double the number who had responded to a similar survey in Victoria . . .
The phone-in was conducted by the Australian Law Reform Commission . . .

The preliminary findings showed also that a quarter of the callers had put up with violence for 15 or more years, and over one third for more than five years; that the advent of children in marriage might be a critical feature in precipitating the violence, and in one third of the cases children had witnessed the violence; that alcohol was involved in 42 per cent of the violent incidents, and that 10 per cent of assaults involved sexual assault.
Of the 33 per cent of the women who had called police to an incident, a great number reported dissatisfaction with police response . . .

We find similar reports in other areas. The Institute of Family Studies has gone into this area in quite some detail. It says that the number of cases of children battered each year is as many as 13,500-that is, 37 children physically injured each day-and that is considerable assault, not minor assault. In Brisbane it has been estimated that fatal child abuse is now the third major cause of violent death in Australia for pre-school children-I believe that is a very worrying figure-with 3.77 per 100,000 at risk. It is also the fifth major cause of violent death of all children up to 15 years, so those figures are pretty horrifying.

In a survey of about 300 parents presenting for marriage guidance counselling in New South Wales, it was estimated that in 27 per cent of the cases the husband had beaten his wife; in 4 per cent of the cases the woman had beaten the man; and in about 4 per cent of the cases both spouses were violent. The major causes, according to the response from the spouses, were drink or jealousy. I believe that there are other reasons, and I am quite sure it would not be denied that the frustrations of unemployment must well be considered one of those reasons. In 1974 there were 155,600 unemployed and in April 1985 there were 614,200. One does not wonder at the increase in violence. There is also the additional problem of the duration of unemployment, which went from an average of 6.5 weeks in 1974 to an average of 45.5 weeks in 1984.

I was Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare which inquired into homeless youth. The members of the Committee travelled to each State and Territory and we came to a very early conclusion that the majority of the youth had been abused and turned out by their parents; not only abused by the father but also abused by the mother. As we toured around and spoke to boys and girls and those in charge of them, it became very obvious that a group of young unloved Australians was growing up in the saddest situations one could possibly imagine. Their parents were either unable or unwilling to look after them. We were told by a social worker that families did not like taking court action against fathers in cases of incest because that upset and disrupted the whole financial stability of the family. We were told by one teacher that an eight-year-old boy and his seven-year-old sister went home after school to find that mum and her de facto spouse had gone-just moved away, lock, stock and barrel. The children did not know what to do. They went back to school and slept under the building that night. When the teachers realised something was wrong the children were taken into care. The Committee heard many other very sad reports.

It is not just a case of only men indulging in violence. That was stressed by Senator Haines today. In cases of violence involving a husband and wife, the man is the violent one in the majority of cases. Mothers, in their frustration, also indulge in dreadful violence towards their children. I shall give some figures that indicate either a tremendously rapid increase in such incidents or greater acceptance of reporting them. Since 1977 the medical profession in New South Wales has been required to make reports of serious forms of child abuse. In 1980 there were 921 incidents, in 1981 there were 1,528, in 1982 there were 3,000 and in 1983 there were 6,442.

One report that was drawn to my attention in which I was certainly interested was commissioned by the Tasmanian Government. It is the report of the Hopcroft Review into Domestic Violence in Tasmania. The Government has taken up three of the recommendations that that report put forward. The first recommendation was that amendments be made to the Justices Act. Tasmania is one of the States that have proposed law reforms relating to domestic violence. The other States are New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia. I am not sure whether legislation is the total answer.

The second recommendation proposed the establishment of crisis intervention centres throughout the State. Members of the crisis intervention service have been recruited and are presently being trained at the Police Academy at Rokeby. When the police answer a call of a crisis nature, such as a request to come to a home to restrain a parent or a husband, a police officer plus a member of the crisis intervention team, who will have been trained specifically in that area, will go to that home to do what they can and to provide short term counselling. Members of this team are being trained only in relation to short term crisis counselling.

The third recommendation that the Tasmanian Government adopted should be looked at in light of the criticism that is often so easily levelled at the police force. I believe that the police are often in a very difficult position, not having actually witnessed an incident.
