Police in Tasmania are presently being trained in crisis intervention in cases of domestic violence. I believe that that will go a long way in providing help in the situations that Senator Haines talked about.

John Edis Hospital in Tasmania is setting up a program under the responsibility of the mental health division. It is co-ordinating and training voluntary groups of men in long term counselling. I guess women will become involved later. It is hoped to tie in the work of those counsellors with the legal system making counselling a condition of a suspended sentence or bail. Education in this area has been suggested for the schools in Tasmania. In April this year a course was provided in Victorian schools.

I refer the Minister in the chamber, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), to one matter. He was told of and given the recommendations from the Hopcroft report. As far as I know, he has done absolutely nothing about them. I refer to the recommendations in the area of family law. Because time is rapidly running out, I ask for leave to have those recommendations incorporated in Hansard so that I can get a response from the Minister as to what action he may have taken. The recommendations have been sent to him and it would be of great assistance if the Government would look at them.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

That S114 AA (6) providing that the power of arrest cease to have effect six months after the date specified in the order, include the additional phrase ''or until further order'' to cover intractable harassment likely to exceed six month's duration.

That all actions for contempt be the responsibility of a Federally appointed law officer. That where appropriate the complainant alleging that the non-molestation order has been breached be able to provide evidence of this by affidavit to avoid appearing in court.
That the regulations concerning the attachment of a power of arrest direct that the judge
attach a power of arrest to all ''ex parte'' orders concerning personal safety
attach a power of arrest once a complaint has been filed that a personal safety or exclusion order has been breached
attach a power of arrest automatically once it is established that a personal safety or exclusion order has been breached
that the judge in all other cases when exercising his discretion as to whether or not to attach a power of arrest:
to give priority to the victim's need for protection and the utility of the arrest power in clarifying the enforcement function of the State police should any violent incidents subsequently occur.

to treat it as exceptional not to attach a power of arrest in all cases other than where the violence is an isolated instance of abuse, where the injury and threats were not serious, and where there is a formal undertaking by the offender, acquiescenced by the victim that such behaviour will not be repeated and there appears to the Court highly probable that the violence or offending behaviour will not be repeated.

That caution be exercised in deeming an ''ex parte'' application ''unmeritorious'' and consideration be given to the extreme difficulties faced by the victim of family violence who seeks to invoke the law's protection while still cohabiting with her violent spouse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing a proposal from my colleague Senator Haines that funding by the Commonwealth for programs to counter increasing violence against women and children is a matter of public importance. I support that proposition. Having listened to the appalling, quite harrowing and horrific statistics that Senator Walters mentioned-for example, that in Queensland child abuse is the third highest cause of death among children of pre-school age-I have cause to wonder about only one thing and that is the apparent reluctance of our society to recognise this problem for what it is. One of the most amazing things about domestic violence is that it continues and figures continue to be released by the media and in government reports, yet precious little is done about it.

SPEECH.PARA: We discuss many things in this place. Often enough they relate to the financial interests of large or even small groups, or to fine points of law. Seldom do we devote time to the urgent problems of the largest minority group in the community-children-who because they are generally smaller than adults, because they have virtually no rights, because they have no electoral clout whatsoever, suffer a wide variety of bad treatment and deprivation and often repeated and protracted injury and abuse. It is historically true, for the reasons that I have stated, that children have always been victims, but one would hope and expect that in a society which is becoming better educated and which, hopefully, is becoming more enlightened, that there would be better understanding of the fact that children do inherit the earth. They take over everything from their elders, no matter how unwilling their elders are to surrender their influence and possessions. Violence to and abuse of children, with the attendant warping of mind and body, cast dark shadows of many kinds into the future. I believe that many of these problems stem from the Victorian concept that children are somehow the property of their parents or guardians. Another concept, in itself respectable enough, is that the home should be a place where privacy and the rights of householders are respected. That these principles should be extended to a stage where people starve, abuse and generally mistreat their children with impunity seems to me quite intolerable.

There seems to be another regrettable notion, held even by government, that somehow the importance of children increases with their age and, presumably, their size. Hence, in the last few weeks the Australian Labor Government has cut assistance to pre-schools, presumably, with the idea that it is a justifiable economy and that small children and their education do not matter. The fact is that pre-school children are by nature probably at the best and most efficient learning phase of their lives. After all, this is the time when children learn a language which is foreign to them-although their native language-simply by observation. It has been appreciated and proved in many experiments throughout the world that children can learn many other things with great facility at that age. This is not an argument for forcing education on them-let me make that quite clear-but it is certainly an argument for allowing them access to the forms of education they would naturally wish to acquire. An intelligent community or government would recognise this fact and see that proper pre-schools are very much in the interests of the community and that child minding centres, which do not provide a significant and expert educational input, are correspondingly less than satisfactory.

Child abuse is not a new phenomenon, despite major increases in reporting of such incidents in recent years. In the last century practices such as baby farming were rife, and children worked long hours in terrible conditions in factories, as chimney sweeps, and in mines. Many children died as a direct result of being over-laid in bed by drunken parents. Others suffered a variety of inflicted injuries and were exposed to all kinds of physical and mental torture. It was against this background that public awareness and indignation were aroused in the United States following the case of a young child who had been seriously abused over a long period. A volunteer missionary trying to get help for her finally turned in desperation to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in New York, having been told: 'The parents have a right to correct the child. You will be arrested if you interfere'. On the bringing of the case before the Society the statute books were searched in vain for some law which would justify the rescue of the child. There were none. Animals were protected but children were not. Finally it was decided, incredible though it may sound now, that the child should be treated as a little animal of the human race. Officers of the Society seized the child and the scissors with which she had been beaten about the face and body, and brought her before the Supreme Court. The ensuing public outcry led to the first Society for the Protection of Children in New York and the first Bill of Children's Rights in the United States.

In most developed countries there is now an awareness by professionals of both the problem of child abuse and the identification of some of its causes. As a result there has been a variety of treatment programs for children and parents, training programs for workers and a growth of self-help groups in the community. Nevertheless child abuse continues. We have no evidence to show that despite increased knowledge and awareness of it, it is on the decline.

Child abuse takes some bizarre forms indeed. Some years ago I was told by professionals in the child care area that, among other things, a practice exists which goes by the name of zonking out. Zonking out involves women, who perhaps because they have a boyfriend or do not want to look after their children properly, go to the doctor and get a prescription for valium, panquil or a similar tranquilliser which they say they need. They then use that tranquilliser to keep their small children in a state of permanent tranquillity or stupor simply because they do not want to go to the trouble of looking after them. I was assured that a number of cases of this kind were known. They are probably a good deal more common in the community than is understood. I heard of the case of one child who had been treated in this way. The single mother had a boyfriend and the child was given tranquillisers every day. This child was occasionally given water and crusts of bread. I think it was a boy. When he was taken into care he was stunted to the extent that he was virtually half the size of a normal child of the same age.

I raise this point because I believe it is symptomatic of the submerged nature of this program to which Senator Walters has referred. It is terrifying, for instance, to think that doctors hand out tranquillisers to people apparently for no reason whatsoever other than that they are asked for. They are handed out without any kind of investigation or insurance in regard to what they are to be used for. It is terrifying that we have instances of this zonking out, which is a known phenomenon to those people who work in this field although it may not be well known to the community. I believe there is a certain resistance in the community even to recognise the fact that this sort of thing actually happens.

We must also consider other forms of child abuse-institutional, socio-economic, political and legal-because they are real, large scale and essentially preventable. There have been significant advances in the last 10 years or so concerning children's rights and welfare, with dedicated work being carried out by top notch people in many fields, new services for children, the beginnings of legal representation and a growth in skilful advocacy. But a great deal more needs to be done. Basically those things are good and are useful, but they do not recognise the fact that society itself has much to do with the problem of child abuse. The patterns of life that we are developing in our communities are largely responsible.

I once talked to a group of people from a high-rise housing commission home unit block in a suburb of Sydney, which will remain nameless for the time being. I was told that there was a pretty high rate of child abuse there. I was not surprised to hear it. The reason, on the account I was given, was that a young mother may well be rearing a child in one of these places, which are more like beehives than anything else. They contain huge numbers of people stacked on top of each other, family after family. The units have thin walls and no proper soundproofing. The child cries; the mother has people beating on the walls, shouting 'Can't you shut that kid up?'. If we persist with this kind of pattern it will be surprising if we do not have more child abuse rather than less. One can sympathise with the problems of such a person living in isolation, among neighbours who are not particularly friendly and may well be hostile. She does not even have a piece of bare ground to walk on because some of these blocks of units are built on very small allotments. The situation is so bad that we could not contrive worse if we tried.

I saw something of a contrast to this 10 years ago when I visited China. I will not idealise China or its developments but I saw a block of high density accommodation in Peking which had been built deliberately in the style of townhouse development. It was no more than two storeys high and anybody could quite easily walk down to ground level where there were garden and trees. Although bathroom, kitchen and toilet facilities were shared I thought it was more important sociologically and socially to have contact among people. It provided a more human environment than giving everybody their own bathroom and kitchen in a block of home units in which there was no real outlet for the family and no answer to the problems created by bringing up children inside such blocks. Another point which we as a society could look at is that grandmothers, particularly in China, are very closely associated with the care of children. The natural relationship between the very old and the very young is recognised and used. It is traditional and something that we ought to look at more.

Several other courses of action in this direction are desirable. The international exchange of information on what is a good social background for people and what is being done to ameliorate this problem of child abuse should be expanded and strengthened because it is a world-wide problem, not just an Australian problem. All governments, even those with existing services such as ours, must recognise the need for services to abused families and abusing families and afford them appropriate political priority. Any senator who has been, as I have, to a number of women's refuges cannot fail to be struck by the irony of their environment. Women's refuges are the final refuge from violence of abused families-Usually there is a locked gate, apparently to keep abusers out because they might come and repeat their offence. Inside they have the most pathetic makeshift furniture; they are always short of money and they have none of the facilities that one would expect a refuge of that kind, which is after all basic and fundamental to have. It is a surprise to me that society tolerates that situation too. I gather from what I have heard recently that that situation is not improving but is becoming worse as time goes on.

It should be recognised that the majority of children who are abused become victims of that abuse when they are very young. Consequently, by the time many of these children reach school age they have been emotionally damaged and thus later become the next generation of abusing parents. This link has been demonstrated and proved. Parents who have been abused as children are likely to abuse their own children. They see this as a normal pattern of life. In a family in which a male child has seen his mother beaten by the father, he will see that behaviour as his right and responsibility in the next generation. As a result, the problem is self-perpetuating. Because of that, it has an even greater demand on our attention. This is not a single isolated set of circumstances which has been created; rather, it is a set of circumstances which is doomed to perpetuate itself generation after generation. Naturally, the worse they become, the worse they will be again in the succeeding generation.

It is essential that there be provision of services for children under the age of five as much as possible. In the light of that, I return to my earlier criticism of the Federal Government's recent withdrawal of subsidies to pre-schools. It is particularly disturbing in the light of that situation, since pre-schools at least provide a period of separation, and thus a breathing space, for potentially abusing parents and their children. The young mother in the home unit block that I mentioned can at least get away from the problem for a time if there is a place to which the child can go, where that child can be in its own peer group, and the mother is given some chance to be away from the problem.

Community support services for parents must be developed further. The Royal Alexandra Hospital for Children in Sydney has had a marked degree of success in involving non-professional volunteers in early intervention in abuse cases. Often a potentially abusing parent is reluctant to seek professional advice about problems because of fear of repercussions from involving the 'authorities', as they are called, and partly because the parents find it easier to share their anxieties with other parents who might be in a similar situation. Such self-help advisory services are of the utmost value. Finally, I urge the Government to give them all the support it can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic of the matter of public importance this afternoon is:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Commonwealth Government to fund programs to counteract the increasing social problem of violence against women and children.

This matter has hardly raised a clamour of dissent. In fact, it would be difficult to argue against such a statement. However, I do not believe that what we have heard so far really substantiates the notion that simply funding programs is the way to deal with this extremely pervasive and still largely hidden problem.

Initially, I will address a comment made by Senator Walters about recommendations from a conference in Tasmania on domestic violence and, specifically, recommendations about changes to the Family Law Act. I simply state that I have been assured that a response will be given to the points in that document which refer specifically to changes that need to be made to the Family Law Act. It would be interesting to know just what response the Tasmanian Government has made to the very many recommendations directed from that conference to the Tasmanian Government.

The recommendations about the Family Law Act can be reduced to four points: The need for access centres; a national agency for the collection of maintenance; power of arrest to be extended past six months after an original order in cases of molestation or threatened molestation; and all actions for contempt to be dealt with by the Federal Court of Australia. As I said, responses to those points have been promised.

The matter before us is of topical importance. However, I would much rather be addressing a topic of even more pressing importance, which relates not to private violence, but to the dreadful public violence which has just been perpetrated against the people of Queensland, particularly against women whose medical records have been confiscated. But perhaps we can deal with that in some other way. I feel, though, that when we are addressing a matter which is of very personal importance, it would be remiss of me not to refer to that quite startling occurrence about which we have just heard in the last couple of days.

Awareness in the Australian population has been rapidly growing over the last 10 years in relation to domestic violence of all types, much as a result of the activities of the women's movement. Domestic violence is as old as humanity itself, but it has remained largely hidden from history-a private matter about which society at large has been loth to concern itself. In the past, refuges were commmonly provided by religious institutions, but only as a last resort, and they would often be to the women concerned a great humiliation and a symbol of defeat and of worthlessness.

The emergence of the second wave of feminism in the late 1960s was predicated on the identification and, more importantly, articulation of all sources of women's oppression, both public and private. For the first time, domestic violence was discussed publicly. Society was forced to recognise its existence, not just in homes where it might be written off as an inevitable response to poverty and deprivation, but right across every spectrum. This is a phenomenon in which there is no discrimination on the grounds of race, religion or social origin. However, most of the victims are, by definition, relatively powerless, within households and elsewhere, women and children.

The notion that personal and private business was of no concern to the community generally was the first enormous hurdle that had to be overcome. More importantly, we had to overcome attitudes of police and politicians and public perceptions. The police, with very good justification, were often very frightened to interfere in what were known in those days as 'domestics' and, in fact, I understand that involvement in household fights of one sort or another has been the greatest cause of injury and even death in the police force in the past. Police simply lacked the expertise to deal with these very difficult situations. They were often extremely frustrated when, having intervened, they then found that the charge was dropped.

The attitude of politicians generally was that it was an extremely dangerous matter to involve laws of one sort or another in domestic situations. There were even accusations that those who did try were encouraging the break-up of families; that simply to provide refuge for women under threat, or their families as well, was in fact somehow destroying the family. This attitude existed despite evidence of the most dreadful physical and sexual abuse. The public perception of battered women was that they were somehow deficient, at least, or at worst, actually deserving of such treatment.

At the United Nations level it was notable, but not surprising, that at the International Women's Year Conference in 1975 in Mexico, the document produced, 'World Plan of Action', included no mention at all of violence of any type against women. However, the mid-decade document in 1980-the Program of Action produced in Copenhagen-carried a strong statement on the subject, as will the Forward Looking Strategy, which is the document which will emerge looking towards the year 2000 and which will be worked on at the United Nations Conference in Nairobi in July of this year, celebrating the end of the United Nations Decade for Women.

Most nations now recognise the need for the judiciary and enforcement personnel to be trained formally and deliberately, first to deal sensibly and sensitively with the victims of domestic violence and, secondly, to deal with the offenders no less severely than with the perpetrators of any other category of assault. This shows that, as in many spheres of social progress in Australia and elsewhere, the early work of the women's movement has been translated into political action, predominantly, in this country, through the policies of the Australian Labor Party.

As one who has been closely involved with these developments over the past 15 years, I can see in most States enormous improvements in many aspects of official and legal procedures: Facilities such as refuges and sexual assault referral centres which did not exist 10 years ago; more political awareness among women generally of their rights and of the support structures available; and a much better understanding in the community generally of the extent and the destructiveness of domestic violence. There is little reliable data, as every speaker has already commented. We do not know how many people are injured at home. Of course, fatalities are recorded but injuries are rarely recorded as domestically produced and are rarely so reported. To quote an injured woman: 'Medicos side-step the issue. They don't know how to recognise domestic violence. They certainly don't know how to handle it'. Any sort of documentation about incest, an even more recently uncovered and, shall we say, discovered domestic phenomenon, is even less well known. To quote an American publication of the Bureau of Justice Statistics:

Various studies have produced widely varying estimates of the magnitude of the problem of family violence. A major reason for the divergence of such estimates, aside from any methodological issues, is the perspective from which the problem is examined. Family violence is a criminal justice issue as well as a social, moral, and psychological issue. An estimate of the number of persons who have suffered psychological as well as physical abuse will be larger than an estimate of persons who have been criminally abused as long as some forms of abuse are thought to be outside the scope of the criminal justice system.

Closer to home, we have a report of the New South Wales Task Force on Domestic Violence which reported to the New South Wales Government in July 1981. As a result of a study in the western suburbs this report comments:
In all areas domestic complaints calls exceeded those about other assault, in some areas three times as many.
It makes reference to more comprehensive figures from the United States as follows:

In the United States, according to the few studies so far completed, 50 to 60 percent of the nations 47 million married couples have had at least one violence incident and 10 to 25 percent suffer violence as a common occurrence.

I do not know that the figures would be very different in Australia. There have been considerable initiatives by the Federal Labor Government to deal with this and allied problems. The funding of refuges through health commission money in 1974 was a completely new initiative. It could not be reversed by the coalition Government, so apparent was the need. It engendered varying degrees of acceptance by and of co-operation from the States. The services barely expanded but managed to survive during those years. Recently, as a result of another Labor Government, we have seen greatly increased funding under the women's emergency services program of 1983-84. More recently, in 1985, the supported accommodation assistance program has provided a great deal more flexibility in funding. It has allowed refuges to bring their workers' wages up to award rates, it has allowed a considerably expanded level of services and it has introduced migrant services into the women's emergency services program.

Children's services are absolutely essential to any reasonable approach to the sorts of problems that develop within families and which can erupt in violence. In 1972 the McMahon Government introduced an Act which for the first time, provided children's services with Federal funding. Following that, there was greatly increased emphasis by the Whitlam Government. In those days funding went largely to the establishment of pre-schooling in many States. We now believe this responsibility should be taken over by the States. The story with children's services is very similar to that with refuges: The services survived during the lean years of the coalition Government; in 1983 the Labor Government came to power with a promise of greatly increased funding for children's services; by 1989 we will be able to double the number of children's services places that we inherited from the Fraser Government in 1983.

Other extremely important aspects of our initiatives towards increasing the security of families, towards the better functioning of families and towards dealing with the inevitable problems of families were the introduction of the Family Law Act in 1975 and some extremely important amendments to it that were made in 1984. Our Royal Commission on Human Relationships in 1977 allowed much better articulation of the needs of families.

Let us not forget the vitally important role of housing in providing the means by which people are able to get away from intolerable domestic situations. As any refuge worker will tell us, there is a crucial need for affordable housing, public if necessary, to which women and their children can be directed in the event that the family home becomes absolutely intolerable. Constitutionally, the States must accept much of the responsibility for the services that go to making family life valuable and tenable. The role for the Commonwealth Government seems in many respects to be that of providing an overview, providing direction and providing evaluation which currently does not exist in the plethora of services which are available, some of them very good and some of them not so wonderful.

What we are doing, which may be of news to some people and which is particularly relevant to the subject of this matter of public importance, is organising a national conference on domestic violence which is planned for November this year. The conference will be held in Canberra and will be followed in February next year by a second conference on child abuse. We intend to bring expert speakers from overseas. It will be an opportunity for a thorough overview of all types of domestic violence in Australia in 1985 and, we hope, an opportunity for sensible forward planning to be made so that funds that are made available, as suggested by Senator Haines in her MPI, are valuably used and so that all other services are expanded in the interests of developing the best possible environment for families to flourish.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion on the matter of public importance has concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: THE AUSTRALIAN SPORTS COMMISSION AND THE OFFICE OF THE STATUS OF WOMEN

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report by the Working Group on Women in Sport

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper on women, sport and the media has been in our possession for only a short time and it has not been possible to do any more than look at the recommendations. They seem to me to be sensible and will reward further reading. Although I have only had a short time to read the report, I wish to give my congratulations to the members of the Group, including my political opponent Senator Crowley, who was the convenor of the Group, and to the members of the Group, some of whom we noticed were in the Senate earlier today, for the work that they have done and the information that they have given us.
The critical recommendation that emerges concerning women and sport is recommendation 8, which reads:
That government assistance to sports associations should be equitable.

It goes on to expand on that recommendation. As I have gone around Australia as Opposition spokesman for the status of women and have talked to groups of women, and as those women have set out for me what they see as problems facing them in society, among the issues raised has been the apparent discrepancy in the access of women and women's sports associations to a fair share of public funding.
I just went back and had a look at the policy of the Liberal and National parties and the summary of our policies affecting women. It states that we have:
Commitment to equality of opportunity for all Australian individuals and their families and opposition to discrimination of any kind . . .
It states further:

We are committed to policies and approaches which will give women genuine freedom of choice, whatever their age and circumstances, to pursue the life-style that suits them and their families best and allows them to realise their full potential as citizens, wives, mothers.

What Senator Crowley and her Group has been doing is entirely consistent with that thrust. The point that has been put to me by representatives of women's groups-I am reminded particularly of a meeting I had in Western Australia; I am sure the particular woman has in fact appeared before Senator Crowley's Group-is that there does seem to be gross inequity in the way in which public money is made available on a gender basis for the support of sport. It does not seem equitable or fair. The question arises: Is funding for sport in fact funding to allow participation by the greatest number of Australians in pursuit of a healthy lifestyle, or is it in fact simply to ensure that we win more medals at some Olympic Games? Is it merely for the support of elitist sportsmen and sportswomen? If it is the former-I hope that that is what it is and that a considerable amount of money goes to the support of many Australians-what this Group has sought to lay down in its report is entirely fair. Before Senator Crowley came in I was congratulating the Group on its work.

The question of a fair go for Australian women is at issue. If what the Group is seeking is generally what is set out in recommendation 8-that is, that government assistance to sports associations should be equitable-it will find complete acceptance from the Opposition of that recommendation and of the sentiment that is behind it insofar as it seeks equality of opportunity for all Australians, including the 51 per cent of Australians who happen to be of a particular gender. If one looks at the figures for the allocation of money to sport, it does seem that there has been an imbalance. It is hard sometimes to make an exact judgment. Some sports associations that receive money may have men and women members and it is hard to determine how the money is distributed. But the clear impression which one gets from looking at the way in which Commonwealth money goes out is that it has gone disproportionately to sportsmen. If this report can assist in achieving equality of opportunity for all Australians, and what our policy sets out as our belief, that there should be absolute equality of opportunity for both sexes, we will be well pleased.

I will need to read the detail of this quite voluminous report now to see whether its reasoning bears out what I have just said. But on the surface and on a first examination it seems an admirable report and one which will be extremely helpful to the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rarely do I rise to speak on a report about which I have such comprehensive understanding. I am pleased to say that this report is one that--
—You weren't here. We would have let you speak first.

—I appreciate that. I thank the honourable senator for his comments so that I am able to speak to this report myself. I take this opportunity to put on record my thanks to my colleagues-one man and a number of women I worked with on the Group. In particular, I thank the Government, which acted on one of the many recommendations that were part of its policies for women. This was a program of the Labor Government when it came to office in 1983. On an initiative from the Office of the Status of Women in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Prime Minister Hawke asked that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) and the Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) establish a Working Group on Women in Sport. It fell to my fortunate lot to chair that Group. The Group was set up in June last year and had its first meeting in September. We were charged to bring our report in within six months. We are just over time but well within budget. We received 118 written submissions, we held public meetings in every State and Territory and we had hearings with the media and sporting organisations. We heard evidence from journalists and staff of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in Melbourne, Sydney, Darwin and Perth. All of the evidence and the submissions from the public hearings confirmed the very reason for our existence. The problem for women in sport was that they received, and have ever received, very little recognition in the face of quite remarkable achievements. They still have very insufficient media coverage and they draw very uneven and insufficient funding-a point to which Senator Peter Baume has referred-and they are still victims of prejudice and ignorance in the media.

SPEECH.PARA: The report further illustrates and records evidence that some of the difficulties facing women in sport pertain to the insufficiency of training for women in administration and coaching, access to facilities, support equipment and so on. It is not the business of this Group to devote most of its time to carping or to criticising. It feels that it was very important to record the prejudice and the insufficiencies that I have just listed, but the point of our recommendations is to address the ways in which all those problems can be overcome.

The first recommendation addresses the establishment of a women's sports promotion unit to be established within or under the auspices of the Australian Sports Commission and answerable to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. We recommended that the women's sports promotion unit comprise five people with a majority at least of women, although this might seem to contravene the sex discrimination legislation. Under that legislation exemptions to promote equality of opportunity are allowed. We would argue that, under those terms, it was a useful recommendation. The women's sports promotion unit should draw from women with experience in sport and sporting administration, a knowledge of sport, a knowledge of media and also from the Office of the Status of Women. It should address the many recommendations that are listed under that first significant reference.

In our examination of the media we encountered any number of examples of what we could only call perpetual prejudice against women in sport. Remarks such as 'women's sport is second rate'; Ian Chappell's claim as reported in the Clancy part of the National Times recently, that we had to get these equal rights women back in their places, illustrate in a classical way that there is a prejudice amongst some sports journalists and many people in the community against women's sport. They have insisted that it is not excellent. If honourable senators read the report they will find any number of examples that it is excellent.

In my final minute, I would like to mention the wonderful piece of serendipity that we have established a women's sports promotion unit with the letters WSPU. I refer to the women's social and political union headed by the Pankhursts to establish voting rights for women in England. Those votes have been won, but the struggle for rights for women and for their voice to be heard in public office continues. We feel it is a very fortuitous piece of serendipity that the women's sports promotion unit will continue the struggle for the rights for women, for the recognition of their ability, their achievements, and public acknowledgment of same and, as Senator Baume said, their equal access to opportunities in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

We are debating the report by the Human Rights Commission on the Queensland electricity supply and related industrial legislation. Regrettably, the Human Rights Commission is a totally denigrated body. It is being used blatantly as a propaganda arm of the Government paid for, yet again, by the overburdened taxpayer. It has served one useful purpose in that as the servant of government it has exposed this Government. Queensland is a sovereign State. Its Government has a right and a responsibility to make laws on behalf of all its people. As with any government, not everyone agrees with laws introduced, amended or repealed by it. However, under our democratic process a number of procedures can be followed by those who dissent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, in Queensland? Queensland doesn't know the meaning of the word.

—Senator Reynolds dissents. These are the procedures she should follow. If considered illegal, the laws can be tested in the courts; if legal but unpopular, opposition can be expressed in the ballot box at the appropriate time. Any bully-boy Mafia-type stand-over tactics, as we have seen in the recent blockade of Queensland and the black listing of innocent companies, have the potential to undermine and destroy our democratic process. Neither the Australian Council of Trade Unions nor the trades and labour councils were elected by the people to govern Queensland or Australia, yet they attempt to act as de facto governments.

SPEECH.PARA: At the request of Senator Reynolds, the Human Rights Commission-what a misnomer-rushes up to Queensland and comes up with a quickie report which was just as predictable and is just as shonky as its report on the Community Services (Aborigines) Act 1984. The Human Rights Commission pays scant attention to the rights of the people of Queensland to be able to obtain essential services, or the resultant hardship to the community when those services are removed. At a recent forum Professor Lachlan Chipman stated:

It is important to realise that bodies like the Human Rights Commission cannot be dismissed as a collection of well meaning, concerned, responsible citizens. Perhaps they are, that is not the point. The record of the Commission has been quite appalling when it comes to the protection of fundamental individual rights and the Commission itself has been party to the most serious violation of such rights.

Perhaps the Commission could be more usefully employed investigating the infringement of individual rights of the majority by those unions involved in industrial blackmail, bullying and blockades. At no stage does the Commission recognise the right of a sovereign State to make its own laws. Instead, it urges the Federal Government to denigrate State rights by passing laws that override the State. This hits at the very heart of our Constitution and I am amazed, as will all the people of Queensland be amazed, that this report to diminish our States rights was initiated by a Queensland Labor senator. The result is that we have the Labor Government introducing a Bill which, it is generally considered, may be found to be unconstitutional. It is being introduced simply to appease the Government's masters, that elite group in Melbourne who are the political power brokers of the Labor Party-the ACTU. We have a non-elected group attempting to destroy our democracy. In any struggle between the elected Government and a non-elected power group, the Government cannot afford to lose for the sake of people of this country and our State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am extremely disappointed that Senator Parer should speak along the lines he did. His is the kind of speech that I would have expected from a member of the National Party, but it is not the kind of speech that I would have expected from a member of the Liberal Party. I wonder whether Senator Parer has even bothered to read the recommendations of the Human Rights Commission report on the Queensland Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985. I am certainly very proud to be associated with the Human Rights Commission and I certainly endorse its recommendations which I will read to the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: The Human Rights Commission, having found that the Queensland Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985 is inconsistent with Article 8 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which prohibits forced or compulsory labour . . . recommends- (a) that the inconsistencies be brought to the attention of the Queensland Government with the object of persuading that Government to repeal the Act or at least amend it to limit its operation to emergency situations and in a manner consistent with the observation of human rights.
Of course, the Queensland minority Government-and I stress that it is a minority government, although everyone on the other side of this chamber gets up and talks about democracy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not everybody.

—I am glad that Senator Missen agrees with me about what is going on in Queensland, both industrially and in human rights generally. Furthermore, the Human Rights Commission said that if the Queensland Government did not repeal the Act or bring it into line with Australia's obligations, the Commonwealth Government should consider introducing legislation which would make the provisions of Article 8 applicable as part of the law of Australia. Apparently unknown to the Queensland minority Government, Queenslanders want to be considered part of Australia--
—Not if you are running it.

—Senator Boswell is not aware of the basic numbers game in regard to support for the Queensland senators in this place. The Australian Labor Party attracts more support than the National Party at Federal level and it certainly attracts far more support at State level.
—Wait until the next election.

—We are waiting for the next election because we know just how much Queenslanders are absolutely fed up with being dictated to by the Queensland minority Premier. He has only 39 per cent of the vote and yet he can dictate to Queenslanders.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I finish I wish to say how disappointed I am that the Queensland Governor, Sir James Ramsay, did not see fit even to read the report which Queensland Labor senators sent to him. I hope that his successor might look on this report a little more favourably. In a letter to me, his aide said merely that he acknowledged receipt of my letter, signed by myself and other Labor senators, containing a copy of the Human Rights Commission Report No. 12. The letter says:
The Report has been put before His Excellency and he feels that a meeting with you is not required.

I know Sir James Ramsay and I have always admired him. I am most disappointed to find that he is not concerned about the basic infringement of human rights in Queensland, in terms of both this industrial legislation and events this week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my appreciation of this report from the Human Rights Commission. I do this as a member of the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties, among other things. I am surprised by the speech made by Senator Parer. Obviously he is one of the people who, unfortunately, have not been able to get a copy of this report, which is in very short supply at the moment. I regret that the report is not in sufficient supply to be read by all honourable senators. I believe that the report is a good one. It follows a report that the Commission made on the Queensland Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985 and is a reference to the number of Acts-five in all-which have been passed by the Queensland Government. One may not agree with some of the courses that have been taken by unions and by governments, both Federal and State, in this matter, but at the same time it is important to look at the particular points of human rights associated with the legislation that has been passed.
—It is a bit like our Scrutiny of Bills Committee, isn't it?
—Yes, but unfortunately there is no Scrutiny of Bills Committee in Queensland.
—Or a Public Accounts Committee.
—Or a Public Accounts Committee or a second chamber of the Parliament. This is very regrettable and it perhaps accounts for the quick and rather foolish legislation which is sometimes adopted there.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Human Rights Commission for having passed judgment on these matters. When we created the Human Rights Commission and the legislation was before this Parliament, I endeavoured by amendment to ensure that questions of State laws, which might offend against the implementation of a Commonwealth-honoured covenant to which we were committed were dealt with. Unfortunately I did not succeed, but at that time I referred to Mr James Crawford, lecturer in law at Adelaide University, who pointed out that under the powers which the States had and which they still have it can be said:

As to matters presently governed by State laws, the only relevant head of jurisdiction is section 9 (1) (c) which refers to 'laws which should be made by the Parliament . . . on matters relating to human rights'. Now it is quite clear that this is not restricted to matters on which the Commonwealth has already legislated, which are covered by section 9 (1) (a). Therefore it must relate to proposed reforms on matters within the Commonwealth power but presently governed by State law. It follows that the Commission can investigate, with a view to proposing reforms of any subject matter of State law provided that the Commonwealth can legislate for it. So the question becomes: What is the extent of Commonwealth legislative power over matters covered by the Convention.
I commended that view and I am glad to see that the Commission is adopting it and is rigorously coming forward and pointing out defects in the Queensland law.

Senator Reynolds spoke of the conclusions which have come from the Commission. I think we should refer to the important findings in this document. In the briefest of terms one can say that there are records there of breaches in the five Acts that the Queensland Government has carried-breaches of human rights, of freedom of expression, which is covered in the international covenant, of matters of presumption of innocence, which is something that should be ensured to the Australian people, and also of freedom of association, which has been restricted. The various sections of these Acts are referred to in the report.

It is important that in the dog fight that is now going on in Federal and State affairs, we should not forget that this legislation represents a blow to Australia's character as a human rights nation, that we have expressions in our Acts which reverse the onus of proof and which have the effect of inhibiting union officials from making statements relating to industrial disputes and that certain expressions in the media have been presumed to be conclusively true. That is a disgraceful performance by any government which should be highlighted as has been done in this report. The presumption of innocence is completely struck down by section 14 of the Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Act. Section 5 of that Act erodes the financial stability of unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the report of the Human Rights Commission on the Queensland electricity supply and related industrial legislation has been very interesting. Unfortunately it has been a truncated debate, as debates on papers always are. One is forced to deal with complicated matters in a very brief compass. I must say, however, that the report which has been brought down by the Human Rights Commission has the very obvious disadvantage that it represents the examination of only a tiny segment of the issues which are raised by the Queensland disputes. Looking at the functions of the Commission which are set out in the report, we find that it has the power to examine enactments. It also has the power to inquire into any Act or practice that may be inconsistent with or contrary to any human right.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect that many electors in Queensland would rather regret that Senator Margaret Reynolds was so selective in the reference she sent to the Commission. In particular, they might have wondered why she did not ask the Human Rights Commission to examine the extent to which the interference by trade unions with the rights of an authority to employ sub-contractors and with the supply of electricity to the people of Queensland were actions which trespassed upon the human rights of the people of Queensland. I think there is a widespread dissatisfaction in the Australian community with the way that trade unions so often trample upon the rights of their fellow Australians. We know of the closed shop. We know of the disruption of the supply of essential services. We know of the blackmail of small businesses by transport unions which will not enable them to ply their business. We know that one of the greatest fetters on human freedom in this country is the activities of some trade unions which choose to act often in defiance of the law as indeed the unions were acting with respect to the blockade to Queensland. It is a very sorry fact that the private employers who were the subject of this industrial blackmail in the blockade of Queensland would not have been game to exercise their legal rights under the Trade Practices Act for fear of further trade union action against them.

If the Human Rights Commission really wishes to be taken seriously in this country it ought to look to a more balanced approach and examine the infringement of human rights across the board and not just narrow matters which are referred to it by Senator Margaret Reynolds. The great majority of people in Australia, especially those in Queensland, would regard this report as singling out the aspect of the trampling on human rights which least concerns them. They would be much more concerned by the absolutely scandalous behaviour of trade unions in this dispute and would be very interested to know why that matter was not put before the Human Rights Commission. I believe that if the Human Rights Commission wants to be taken seriously as a body it will have to do much better than it has done in this report. It will certainly have to look more widely at ways in which freedom is being trampled on in this community. I do not believe that most people would regard this report as focusing on the matters which are most reducing human rights in this, our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: — The report of the Human Rights Commission on the Queensland electricity supply and related industrial legislation clearly is a pathetic beat-up, an attack on the Queensland Government by some Federal Government quasi-body. The Human Rights Commission which, incidentally, costs the taxpayers $5m, is a great example and living proof of how bodies such as these do not protect human rights in a democracy which must reflect a balance of the various rights of the individual. The report bases much of its comment on the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. This Covenant is not even part of our Australian law. The Australian people have never adopted this Covenant as an Australian law. Australia is a signatory to the Covenant. However, I hope that the Federal Government, and Senator Reynolds in particular, understand that before a treaty can have any effect it must be enacted into a law through this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Covenant is written in very general terms designed to cover a wide range of countries, many of which do not enjoy the same freedoms as those enjoyed by Australia. Yet the Human Rights Commission has decided that it has overriding authority and is even overriding our law. Like all treaties, it is written in vague and rather imprecise terms. It is meant to express principles rather than precise meanings. For example, the term 'public order' used in the Covenant is largely unknown in the common law world. What an insult to the people of Australia to have it said that we are bound by a covenant which we have not even voted upon and which contravenes many accepted common law terms.

I will point out how ludicrous and out of touch this report is. The report found that a section of the Covenant headed 'Slavery and the Slave Trade' had been contravened. How ridiculous! All the Queensland Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985 does is to allow the Electricity Commissioner to direct any person who, in his opinion, is capable of restoring and maintaining electricity supplies. How any reasonable, thinking Australian could consider that as an onset of slavery is honestly beyond my comprehension and it should be the comprehension even of Senator Reynolds. All the Queensland Government is trying to do is to guarantee Queenslanders an essential service.

The motives of this report are all too clear. The Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Labor Party did not like the widespread Queensland public support the Queensland Government was getting so it called this inquiry in an attempt to legitimise its criticism. The Human Rights Commission flew to Queensland and flew out on the same day. Apparently it thought that was enough time. It did not even interview the Queensland Government. Where was the Human Rights Commission--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted under Sessional Orders for the consideration of Government papers has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented by the statement that was made that the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights was not adopted by this Parliament. I was present in the Parliament and moved the amendment that read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Approval is given to ratification by Australia of the Covenant.
That motion was carried by this Parliament when we carried the motion to establish the Human Rights Commission. I ask that that be noted on record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not see where the honourable senator himself was misrepresented. Nevertheless, perhaps as a statement of fact it is useful to have Senator Missen's explanation recorded.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was adjourned earlier in the day I was just completing my contribution to the second reading debate and indicating that the Opposition either warmly supports or does not oppose the package of various taxation amendment provisions which are contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill. I had reached the stage of making reference to rebates for dependants and had said that the measure will be backdated to 1 May 1984. That is retrospective. Notwithstanding our general objection to retrospective legislation, this retrospectivity is to correct an error rather than to impose a liability and as such, it is something which is supported by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DRIED FRUITS CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration of House of Representatives message.
House of Representatives message:

The House of Representatives transmits to the Senate the Bill intituled ''A Bill for an Act to amend the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Act 1978', and for related purposes'', and acquaints the Senate that the House of Representatives has disagreed to the amendment made by the Senate, for the Reasons shown in the annexed Schedule.
SCHEDULE OF THE AMENDMENT MADE BY THE SENATE TO WHICH THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES HAS DISAGREED
Pages 1 and 2, clause 3, line 11 (page 1) to line 37 (page 2), leave out the clause.
Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate
The Senate amendment is not acceptable because-

This amendment does not take account of the fact that increasing competitiveness, and complexity, of international marketing in dried vine fruit due to intervention by governments and technological advances dictate the need for wide in-house expertise for the continued effective performance of the commercial functions of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation (ADFC).

The Government proposal that there be 2 additional members from the business community, with specialist skills in areas such as finance and marketing outside the industry, would bring fresh insights and considerably broaden the experience and expertise within the Corporation membership and strengthen its decision making base.
The Corporation's functions are commercial and therefore its membership should be capable of meeting the full spectrum of commercial demands placed upon it.

The Australian Dried Fruits Association (ADFA) comprises both growers and packers. The Government's proposals would ensure that the industry, through the ADFA, would continue to have a direct influence on the appointment of 6 of the 10 members. The ADFA provides nominations for the 4 grower members and is consulted on the existing 2 specialist members who have traditionally been from the packing sector. The ADFC would be consulted in regard to appointment of the 2 specialist members from outside the industry.
The amendment is not acceptable to the Government. It is the wish of the Government that Clause 3 of the original Bill be restored.
The House of Representatives desires the reconsideration by the Senate of the Bill in respect of the said amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee does not insist on the amendment of the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

What has happened is similar to what happened on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill that has just been dealt with. There has been ill informed meddling by people who think they can attract a few more votes by doing a bit of grandstanding, while simultaneously sabotaging the interest of the very people from whom they hope to get votes. The Government is equally adamant on this question.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party's lowest rural vote was when you were the shadow Minister.
—Senator Chipp should go and wash the blood off his hands. He should preside over a few more national service ballots and send a few more conscripts to Vietnam.
—Order! Senator Walsh, I do not think that kind of outburst is required.
—Whatever I may or may not have been guilty of, I did not send any conscripts to die in Vietnam. I did not preside formally over the ballots that sent them there.
—Order!

—The Government will not accept the ill informed amendment which meddlers in the Senate have moved, as I said, for no reason other than a bit of populist grandstanding. The Australian Dried Fruits Corporation is different from the Australian Wheat Board in that it will continue to exist whether this Bill is agreed between the two Houses or not, but the additional expertise which the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) sought to make available to the Board by this Bill will not be available to the Board and the dried fruit producers will be commensurately disadvantaged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Opposition will vote against the motion moved by Senator Walsh. Our vote is not ill informed.
—It is most informed.

—It is a most informed vote, as Senator Messner said. It represents the wishes of the people whom the Bills affect. After a lot of consultation with the various organisations-something the Government has not had-they have asked us to move an amendment. We have done that. It is not an ill informed vote. The comments of Senator Walsh are a reflection on a vote of the Senate. We do not accept the motion that has been moved and, if the Australian Wheat Board ceases to exist after 1 October, be it on the Government's head.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY PRODUCE MARKET SUPPORT LEVY BILL 1985DAIRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985DAIRY PRODUCE MARKET SUPPORT BILL 1985DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Prior to the commencement of the debate on the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill, the Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill, the Dairy Produce Market Support Bill and the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill, I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate a matter of great importance. Senators will be aware that a number of amendments to these Bills have been circulated. These amendments are a misguided attempt by certain parties to assist the dairy industry. In particular, I understand that one of the amendments is directed at retaining export pooling for an interim period, yet export pooling is the single biggest contributor to the sorry state in which the industry now finds itself. The Government showed its vehement opposition to these proposed amendments in the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: At a Press conference this morning, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) reaffirmed unequivocally the importance that the Government attaches to the package of dairy marketing arrangements proposed by these Bills, and in particular the immediate termination of export pooling. The Minister stated that the Government is not prepared to implement these Bills with the amendments which have been suggested. Rather, the Government will allow the existing arrangements to continue to operate. This option would surely see adjustment of the dairy industry, which all parties agree is necessary, but it would be a brutal adjustment with no certainty that the industry would be better off with this adjustment. Senators should note also the Minister's observation this morning that while the legislative framework of the present arrangements will continue to operate, underwriting which is at present provided by the Government pursuant to administrative arrangements will cease to operate on 30 June 1985. Nor would the Government propose to provide underwriting as long as the old arrangements continue. As well, the Minister would, of course, need to weigh carefully other decisions on key elements of the present arrangements if these were to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will not delay for long the long awaited debate, but the rather extraordinary procedure which the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has followed in giving us a mini-second reading speech and holding us all in terrorem is very unusual. I have to say that the record of this Government in dealing with the dairy industry is such that it is beyond me how we are supposed to take seriously any such comments. The attitude of this Government to the dairy industry was quite different when there was a Victorian election pending. All of a sudden the Government has developed a totally new approach because the election is out of the way. Quite frankly, we just do not take seriously the sorts of comments that have been made. We will put our views about the dairy industry. There will be a long second reading debate. We will move our amendments and I hope that they will be carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — What a fascinating few minutes we have just had in this chamber. In all the time I have been here I do not think I have seen a similar situation. In this chamber we have Standing Orders, a Constitution and privilege so that we can do and say things without fear or favour. Yet here we have a Minister of the Crown, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), with the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill, Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill, Dairy Produce Market Support Bill and Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill threatening us--
—Browbeating us.
—Browbeating us, blackmailing, whatever one likes. What a fascinating experience it has been for all of us.
—We are a House of review.

—As Senator Harradine has just said, we are a House of review. We know how much attention the Australian Labor Party pays to the review capabilities of this House. We have had three short outbursts from Senator Walsh reflecting on the prospective votes in this chamber. In all rural legislation we have seen the attitude of the Labor Party to the rural sector. We have seen it not only in legislation that the Government has introduced but also in the innuendos in its mini-Budget. The rural sector is one of the great export earners at a time when this Government is in trouble, when international attitude towards this Government is reflected in the value of the dollar and when our balance of payments is in all sorts of problems. It is the one bright spot. It can pull us out. Yet if ever a sector has been singled out for special treatment by this Government, it is the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: We listened to comments relating to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill and the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Amendment Bill. The Opposition wants to maintain a majority of growers on their own boards. We want them to handle their own money and products. It is on record now that after 1 October the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, will be the biggest wheat seller in the world. Be that on his head.

These four Bills deal with milk that is generally entitled manufactured milk as against market milk, which is the milk that is produced for human consumption, supplied through home deliveries and sold in cartons and bottles. Manufactured milk goes into cheese, butter, casein and whole milk powder.

There has been a dramatic rationalisation in the dairy industry over the last few years. It has had problems and it is well aware of them. The number of farms has decreased from 49,000 in 1964 to 18,300 in 1985. In terms of direct employment that means a reduction from 115,000 in 1964 to 50,000 in 1985. In the last 10 years there has been a drop from 388 factories employing 21,700 people to 264 factories employing 17,900 people. So over time the dairy industry has come to grips with its problem. That can be seen in the figures I have just mentioned. Milk production has fallen from 7.2 billion litres in 1970-71 to 6 billion litres in 1984-85. The dairy industry recognises that the optimum production which it needs at this point is about 5.3 billion litres.

For all its troubles the dairy industry is still a great contributor to our overseas earnings and to our gross domestic product. In 1983-84 it pumped into the Australian economy $1 billion and was responsible for $350m in export earnings. If only those figures could be reflected in the amount of money that has been earned by the farmers. Farm income per work year of family labour in 1983-84 was only $4,325 for dairy farmers. I have two tables which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The tables read as follows-
PRICE CHANGES IN DAIRY PRODUCE COMPARED TO OTHER ITEMS, USING 1970 AS A BASE OF 100
Milk 341 Butter 260 C.P.I. 389 Average Earnings 535 Farmers' Costs 489
