Australia 2.87 4.30 Canada 3.99 6.00 United States 4.51 5.58 United Kingdom 3.22 4.37 France 4.54 5.17
Australian prices for these commodities have been frozen since 1982-manufactured products account for 50 per cent of farmers' incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the tables, one can see that dairy farmers' prices have increased but at a lesser rate than the consumer price index and their costs have increased at a greater rate than their incomes. On top of that we still produce the cheapest products of any of the countries mentioned in the second table. That puts into perspective the contribution that the dairy industry makes to our economy and to the CPI, vis-a-vis other countries. Our products are still cheaper than those of most other countries. Indeed, they are still cheaper than the countries we are competing against that are dumping those products on the world markets.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry calculates that if the Kerin plan were implemented it could cost, giving the worst scenario, the jobs of up to 25,000 industry people. In reality, that would cost the Australian taxpayer $100m in welfare payments as well as the $20m promised in reconstruction funds. The Minister for Primary Industry has put up little defence or denial that the main thrust of this package is to force domestic prices of dairy products down close to export prices. Export prices are corrupt prices in that they are obtained through the dumping of milk products on the world market by the European Economic Community in particular.

Mr Kerin, in his second reading speech, admitted that world export prices are grossly distorted because of subsidised production, especially in the case of the EEC and, to a lesser extent, the United States of America. The level of subsidies can be gauged from a table I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
A COMPARISON OF PRICES RECEIVED BY FARMERS FOR MANUFACTURING GRADE MILK, IN USc/KG (ACTUAL BUTTERFAT CONTENT) New Zealand 11.7 Australia 14.2 United States 27.8 United Kingdom 21.6 France 20.6

TALK.START.PARA: —The higher prices paid in these countries are in addition to other support mechanisms such as the threshold price for imports, import restrictions and import subsidies. New Zealand is the only country that has an efficiency advantage over Australia, and this is estimated at 22 per cent. Because of the artificially low export prices, it is estimated that there is a consumer transfer to dairy farmers of $96m. In the National Farmer Mr Kerin said:

SPEECH.PARA: We must face fundamental international reality in terms of market and fundamental economic reality in terms of the state that our economy is in.

This statement would have to be the ultimate in political hypocrisy. This Government now expects the farm sector to face reality and compete against subsidised exports being dumped on our markets. More importantly this Government refuses to deregulate that part of the community which most governs our cost. I refer to the labour market, which is the most overregulated and protected cartel outside the communist countries. This whole exercise smells of a shady deal that has been done with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Government will force down food prices under the guise of economic reality so that it can artifically lower the consumer price index in order to do a wages deal with the ACTU. Of course it is the farmers' livelihoods that are being treated with such cynicism.

The four dairy Bills the Senate is discussing are the Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill, the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill, the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill and the Dairy Produce Market Support Bill. The Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill gives the Australian Dairy Corporation more flexibility to borrow money to meet shortfalls in any particular fund. It will be able to shift money from one fund to another or borrow on the international money market. Most importantly, it will end export pooling by 1 July 1985. The Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill sets out the amount of levy put on milk to support the export of prescribed products. A three-year average for exports is to be calculated and domestic prices will be set at 130 per cent of that. A levy will then be applied to support exports. Any market underwriting collections will go into such a support fund.

The Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill provides for a levy on butter, butter oil and cheese. This levy is to provide support further to that provided by the all-milk levy and is designed to safeguard milk prices if they fall rapidly. The Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill sets for support purposes a variable levy with a maximum rate of 45c per kilogram of milk fat. This replaces the other levy system which applied to certain products only. It is estimated to work out at about 1.5c per litre, to be paid by the milk producer. The Government has also indicated that it will underwrite export returns at a level of 90 per cent of a three-year average. That is in case prices collapse below the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade minimum. There will also be $40m adjustment assistance for the whole industry, not just for the farmers. There is a sunset clause that will cut off in 1990-91, with a review in four years.

The industry has expressed quite a few concerns about this legislation and, as everybody will be aware, there has been a lot of consultation over the last few days. The cutting out of export pooling after July 1985 will cause some difficulties. The fear is that if this goes through before production levels fall people currently exporting will flood the domestic market or will cut each other's throat on the high return export market. If I may put that in another way, if a farmer had had a cow joined or artificially inseminated yesterday, depending on how he carries out his herd breeding, he would be looking at a commitment of at least 19 months by the time he gets through the rest of this lactation period and the next lactation period. Finishing the pooling system by July 1985 is too soon a cut off to allow the industry, and more particularly individual farmers, to adjust. That 19-months period is an absolute minimum. The industry is asking for a further two years of the existing system to allow for a less traumatic adjustment.

One of the other concerns is that the cutting of support levels by reducing product levies will cause a quick depression of domestic prices, which of course is what the Australian Labor Party is all about. The Kerin plan is for the existing system to operate for 12 months and then be adjusted downwards by a formula which the industry estimates will reduce levies by 50 to 60 per cent in one year. The industry wants the present system to continue for two years and then be phased out in four equal steps by 1991. Another concern is the determination of export support payments. The industry is not happy about the three-year averaging, with one year being a forward estimate, and is not happy about the inclusion of whole milk powder in the prescribed products export scheme. The argument is that because of the high value-added content of whole milk powder there will be a bonus levy for this product. The whole milk powder manufacturers deny this. The industry wants the ADC to determine the amount of levy payable by relating it to the milk content of exported products. I will deal with that a little further when we are considering the proposed amendments in the Committee stage.

Following consultation with the industry, the Opposition will move to amend three of the Bills in the Committee stage. The proposed amendment to the Dairy Legislation Amendment Bill provides for the carrying on of export pooling for a further two years, for the reasons I have indicated. There are other amendments which are basically sequential upon that proposed amendment. We propose an amendment to the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill. This amendment will more closely define prescribed products, and is mainly to remove whole milk powder from the prescribed list. I will give more reasons for that proposed amendment when we deal with it in the Committee stage. There are consequential amendments to that proposed amendment also. The other proposed amendment, to the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill, will ensure that the present domestic pricing arrangements will continue for another two years and then be phased out in four equal steps by 1991. I foreshadow that those amendments will be moved in the Committee of the Whole. They have been circulated.

Even though the dairy industry as a whole does not like the Kerin plan and does not want it to be instituted, and in spite of all the invective we heard from Senator Walsh, the industry basically accepts the thrust of the plan. The proposed amendments basically allow the Kerin plan, except for the provisions pertaining to whole milk powder, to be phased in over a longer period so that the industry will have more time to adjust. I will explain those provisions in a little more detail when the Bills get to the Committee stage. The Opposition will not be opposing the second readings of the Bills but will be moving the amendments circulated in my name when in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collard has criticised in fairly round terms the approach the Australian Labor Party has taken to rural industries, in particular to the dairy industry, and has criticised the present Government for its attitude expressed, as he says, through these four dairy Bills. If one takes a quiet and proper approach to these Bills it will be seen that they create a scheme which is essential for the well-being of the dairy industry. The Bills deal with the way in which payments made for milk and milk products are to be distributed amongst producers and manufacturers. Accordingly, they affect the dairy industry profoundly, as has been illustrated by the interest the dairy industry has taken in the Bills. As Senator Collard says, many people from the industry have come to Canberra to put their case. They have put their case properly, with force, and most impressively. The fact is that payments can be distributed by an untempered market, by detailed regulation, as is presently the situation, or by both market forces and regulations operating in various degrees. It is a matter of looking at these various means of distributing the income raised from the dairy industry and seeing in what way it can most fairly be distributed, having regard not only to the producers and the manufacturers of milk-though they are of great importance-but the public.

SPEECH.PARA: The present situation in the dairy industry has arisen in circumstances in which it has been heavily regulated. That is accepted. The situation is an unhappy one. Farmers who work hard and efficiently are denied adequate rewards for their efforts and Australian consumers pay substantial subsidies for overseas consumers of Australian products. Australian consumers pay substantially more for similar products. In those circumstances there is general agreement that extensive change is required to the industry in the interests of both that industry and the consumer of its products. There is agreement as to the general thrust of what the reforms should be. In contrast to what Senator Collard has said, the dairy farmers and all the people in the dairy industry agree that the general thrust of the reforms put forward by this Government are correct. The argument does not go to the general thrust of the plan; the argument is about the timing and the details of the reforms suggested.

In dealing with the present legislation it is important to keep some things in mind. First, the reform of the dairy industry is necessary, and is seen as being necessary by those connected with it. People who have come to see members of parliament in Canberra or in the electorates in the various States have said that. They understood that reform was necessary and they praised the general thrust of the scheme put forward by this Government. Reform of the dairy industry is seen as necessary, and is, in fact, necessary.

Secondly, the reform of the industry has been widely and responsibly discussed within industry and by government. This is certainly not a scheme that has been brought forward out of the dark and revealed suddenly in a flash of light. It has been discussed within the industry and extensively by those responsible in the Government, and it has come forward as a result of those discussions.

Thirdly, the general approach of the legislation before the Senate has wide acceptance in the industry following those discussions. Fourthly, unless something is done, and done quickly, the present situation, with all its faults-and they are numerous-will persist. Something has to be done. We cannot simply remain static because the industry is in need of overhaul. Unless that is done quickly the whole situation will drift on. It has been suggested here that we wait for two years before we do something. What will happen over those two years? What will motivate the industry to move to a situation where it becomes viable in all its dimensions-not only some of them-unless something is done quickly? To delay is simply to delay the inevitable.

Fifthly, few changes are ever introduced which do not give rise to the argument that the interests of at least some people are prejudiced. That argument has been put forward in this case; that some people will be affected adversely. It is proper that those arguments be listened to and be considered. Those arguments have been listened to and have been considered by the Government. The sixth point is that this legislation will bring benefits to the consumers of dairy products and to the large--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the farmer?

—And to the large majority of people in the dairy industry. Senator Boswell says: 'What about the farmer?'. That is a very legitimate question. Of course the farmers should be kept very much in mind, and the fact is that farmers have been kept very much in mind. As I said before, farmers have given approval to the general thrust of the scheme to be brought forward by this legislation.
—I don't know what farmers you were talking to. You must have been in Queen Street, Melbourne.

—There are very few farmers in Queen Street, Melbourne. No doubt Senator Boswell will put the argument that farmers are put at risk by this legislation. That is a fair proposition; but that will be a minority of farmers. I would be interested to hear whether Senator Boswell has evidence that more than a small minority of farmers will be put at risk by this legislation. Of course, it should be a matter of concern to all that people are put at risk. However, an argument that the risk is universal or is faced by a majority of farmers is ill-founded.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, to argue that some farmers are put at risk by the proposed scheme and to ignore the risks that those very farmers face under the present one is to argue selectively. In other words, it is not good enough to say that a significant number of people are adversely affected if the honourable senator cannot then go ahead and say that the alternative that he suggests will benefit them and others as well. The honourable senator cannot simply produce an argument that there are some unfortunate effects of a particular piece of legislation, and say that responsibly, without putting forward an argument and producing evidence to show that alternative legislation, or the failure to put that legislation into operation, will give greater benefit to the people whom the honourable senator purports to represent. He must produce evidence and an argument other than one of simply condemning the legislation and saying that some people may be adversely affected by it.

The fact is that the dairy industry as a whole, and the Australian people who purchase its goods, will gain mightily by this legislation. Provision has been made to accommodate the adjustment of those adversely affected by the scheme. Senator Collard mentioned the fact that $40m has been made available to facilitate the adjustments that may occur in the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the farmers' money. They put that in. It is not a government grant.
—I do not see where that argument gets Senator Boswell. All I am saying is that $40m-
—Don't talk about the Government being so magnanimous as to put in $40m.
—Does Senator Boswell want to hear an answer?
—Senator Boswell, you are on the list to speak after a few other speakers. I suggest you keep your comments until then.

—I want to answer that, Senator Boswell. Of course the $40m may come from the farmers. But that was not the argument. The argument was whether money is available to facilitate the adjustments. I am simply saying that it is. If the honourable senator is saying that the $40m is not there to facilitate the adjustments that may be necessary as a result of this legislation he may say so during his speech. But it is not to the point to simply say: 'Look, even though there is $40m, that comes from a source from which I would prefer it not to come'. That is no argument at all. I agree with the honourable senator that a decision to reform ought to be made after balancing the advantages and disadvantages that will flow from it. There are usually perceived disadvantages to some following reform, but if the reform is worth while, the advantages that flow from it make it essential.

SPEECH.PARA: In the present instance the advantages that will flow from the reforms encompassed by this legislation are absolutely essential. Why? The fact is that there is an overproduction of milk. There is a distortion in the sale and distribution of milk products. Senator Collard, in a speech in which he put his arguments strongly and firmly, nevertheless failed to address the central issue in this matter-the question of the market and what the market demands. There is presently a distortion in the sale and distribution of milk products and in the money that comes from those products which has been brought about by mechanisms including those over which entities other than the Commonwealth has control. That is to be remembered. The Commonwealth has only part control over the milk industry. For example, the European Economic Community has created circumstances in which surplus milk has been produced in floods. Senator Collard said that the EEC has acted irresponsibly. I agree with that. But what can this Government and this country do in that situation?

Honourable senators opposite may be able in this debate to give some assurances about what they believe the States can do. For example, State governments have regulated the dairy industry under their jurisdiction so that some of those in it profit greatly and others lose. It would be interesting for people here to go to States like New South Wales and Queensland and talk to them to see whether those States would allow the flow of Victorian milk into their States. That is something we could do-deregulate the State markets to allow Victorian milk, the milk most efficiently produced in this country, to flow north. Victorians produce about 60 per cent of Australia's milk. Of that amount, 87 per cent forms the basis of manufactured products. Those manufactured products are exposed to severe competition from other countries, and it would be very helpful if there were markets available for them in this country. Given the keenness of honourable senators opposite to see something done about the industry, here is one way in which they could show that they are intent upon doing just that, by going to the States from which they come and influencing those States to open their markets to Victorian milk.

I have spoken about the limited role the Commonwealth Government can play in the bringing of order and profitability to the dairy industry. But the Federal Government has a significant potential to effect reform of the dairy industry through its power over the returns received for exported milk products. This legislation will carry forward much needed reform by abolishing the present pooling of returns from the sale of dairy products whereby the returns for exported products are subsidised. At the moment, levies are raised on domestic sales of certain products and distributed across all production, including production for export sale. At the moment there is no levy on milk which is used to produce products for export sale or on the sale of goods so produced. This means in fact that the returns from the sale of milk products on the domestic market subsidise Australia's export of such products.

Australia's exports have been mentioned. It has been pointed out that the rural industry, and the dairy industry in particular, contributes mightily to our export earnings and that the industry should be praised highly for that. The fact is that, as things now operate, Australians are subsidising very substantially the price paid for Australian milk products used overseas. It also means that all producers get the same return, irrespective of their ability or industry. On the other hand, the scheme to be introduced by this legislation will ease the burden presently placed on the Australian consumer. Further, it will reward the farmer who displays greater ability and industry than his fellows. It has to be kept in mind that this scheme will continue to support the dairy industry. It will ensure that producers will receive at least 130 per cent of the average financial returns for milk products exported over three years, including the current year and the two immediately preceding. The means of financing the necessary mechanisms will be raised from a levy to be paid by farmers on the sale of their milk. The scheme will include all milk and not, as formerly, only milk used to produce milk products. In the beginning a levy will be paid by the consumer on the purchase of certain milk products, specifically butter, oil and cheese. The levy paid by the consumer will be phased out according to a formula provided for in the legislation. There has been some concern about this from the farmers who have come to Canberra and who have approached members of this place. Provision is also made, as I have said, to facilitate adjustments which are required in the industry.

It is said that there ought to be a two-year delay in the introduction of this scheme. The fact is that a delay in instituting this scheme would be a delay in bringing order and profitability to dairying and the manufacture of dairy products and, at the same time, a delay in bringing relief to the Australian consumer. The reality, whether it is perceived as a grim reality or otherwise, is that any delay is a delay in achieving the inevitable. Inevitably reform must be introduced. If it is put off, that simply means that the cure for the industry is delayed.

It has been suggested that the scheme could be improved by making certain amendments to it. The suggestions include the continuation of the pooling system for two or more years-Senator Collard touched on this-instead of cutting it off from 1 July 1985. A suggestion also was made that the method used to calculate the market support payments under the scheme should be altered. Another suggestion was the use of a formula different from that contained in the legislation, to phase out levies on milk products.

I wish to make some comments on those three suggestions. The first was that the pooling provisions be continued for two or more years. The reality of pooling is that it is the central cause of the industry's present problems. Amongst other things, it has caused the following difficulties: Firstly, it has augmented the costs, in particular of milk products; secondly it has encouraged over production of milk; thirdly, it has provided the greatest degree of assistance to the otherwise least viable part of the market; fourthly, it has stopped or hampered the development of new products and new markets; and fifthly, it has directed the minds of manufacturers towards production rather than marketing. Indeed, that was the situation to which Senator Collard referred. He argued his case in terms of the efficiency with which the Australian industry produces its milk. There can be no doubt that he is correct in saying that. Indeed, his analysis is a worthy one. His speech will be worth reading in Hansard. But what he ignored is efficiency in the market-place. One can have the efficiency in production and efficiency in the market-place. In my view, what honourable senators opposite must turn their minds to in the arguments which will follow is the question of how one can make the marketing of milk an efficient exercise. There can be no argument that the milk is efficiently produced; indeed, that is one of the great tragedies in this situation. As Senator Collard has pointed out, farmers in this country produce milk and milk products much more efficiently than elsewhere, but they do not receive from the market the sorts of returns that they should receive. As he said, the markets are distorted. Among others, the European Economic Community creates problems, the ramifications of which are tragic to many farmers. That is unfortunately the situation that they face.

The second suggestion was that the method of calculating market support payments be changed from that provided in the scheme presented in this legislation to one based on a milk yield formula. That suggestion diminishes too greatly the part that the market should play in the industry. The Government intends to give the market its proper place in this scheme. It should not be the sole determinant but it has a proper place in the determination of where the industry goes. It is the Government's intention through this legislation, to give the market its proper place in the scheme of things.

The third suggestion was that the phasing out of the levy on milk products should be accomplished by a number of equal steps rather than according to the formula set out in the scheme. The fact is that the scheme is based, and based correctly, on the proposition that there be flexibility and sensitivity to the adjustments that occur in the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unpredictability, as well, though.
—I follow what Senator Macklin is saying, but the fact is that it is expected that this scheme may work in different ways; in other words, that the effect on the industry may be different--
—It is a loser every way you look at it.

—I will answer Senator Macklin first. I put it this way: The scheme should be so arranged that it is able to meet whatever eventualities develop, whereas if we have, as it were, a fixed phasing out, that fixture makes the whole scheme too rigid to accommodate the problems that may arise in different situations. If there is a fixed means of phasing out the situation may be held too rigidly, which may not operate to the benefit of the whole scheme. I understand that honourable senators opposite say that there ought to be a number of equal steps to phase it out; if we do not have that the scheme becomes too uncertain. As the scheme operates there will be more flexibility, which will be to the benefit of industry and the consumer.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills will replace the legislation on which the dairy industry presently operates. The legislation, when enacted in 1977, contemplated a scheme of assistance to the industry to be introduced in three stages. It is an indication of the difficulty that we have in wrestling with the problems that have occurred in this industry and is illustrative of those problems that only one stage of the three proposed stages has ever been brought into operation. That scheme has been found wanting. I have not heard any suggestion that the scheme which was introduced by Mr Sinclair should be maintained in its pristine form. The industry is constantly changing. One can understand that, given the effects of world and local markets and the fact that many people have come into the industry and have increased production recently. All these things make a very fluid situation within which the dairy industry operates. Given that the scheme is not working at present, other schemes must be looked at. In that context this scheme, which unashamedly is based very largely on a consideration that the market place ought to decide issues in terms not only of the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which market? The overseas subsidised market? That is an unreal market.

—That is true. After proper consideration, this Government has gone ahead to look for an alternative to the scheme which has been found wanting. Senator Watson says that overseas products are subsidised. That is so.
—It is not a true market.

—Of course it is not a true market; it is unjust and unfair. I am willing to agree with all those propositions, but the difficulty is: What do we do now? Senator Collard gave a series of figures to indicate the situation regarding Australian farmers. It is a tragic one. Something has to be done. The Opposition says: 'Look at these farmers. Look at how they suffer as a result of the activities of European countries'. I can only agree with the Opposition there, but it is only a step along the path. What do we do about it? We cannot declare war on the European countries and blow up their vast lakes of milk. We have got to look at what can be done in the real situation. That is what this legislation does; it looks at the real situation. Certainly there are tensions and problems in trying to adjust to the real situation, but unless we adjust we will get nowhere. The whole thing just goes further and further down the hill gathering speed until there is complete disaster. We have faced that problem and we have found what we want. On coming to office we found the scheme wanting. It was not sufficiently oriented to the market. I take the point that the market has been distorted, nevertheless that is the market we have to face. To ignore the proper part the market should play in the scheme contained in the legislation presently being considered would be to retreat to failure. That is the reality of the matter. If we retreat, we retreat to failure. Such a retreat would be irresponsible.
—You had a better alternative.

—No doubt the honourable senator will be able to talk about the different alternatives. In looking at those alternatives he must remember that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and this Government have looked closely, and sympathetically-I use the word advisedly-at all those alternatives. No matter which way they looked, the reality is that none produced as good a scheme as the one presently before the Parliament. As I said, the general thrust of that scheme has been accepted.
—In whose opinion is that?
—Senator Boswell may be speaking to different farmers and farmer organisations from the ones that I have spoken to. The general thrust has been accepted across the industry.
—You listened to the ACTU but you don't take any notice of the dairy farmers.

—I will say something about the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the workers. Senator Collard said a few things about the ACTU and the workers. I am sure it was simply the puff of debate. To try to place the problems of the dairy industry on the backs of workers and on the ACTU is really irresponsible. I am not saying that Senator Collard is irresponsible; I am saying that the effect of that is irresponsible. The workers have nothing to do with this.
—They won't have a job after you have finished with them-20,000 will be out of work.

—The fact of the matter is that the workers and the ACTU have contributed mightily to this country. If the honourable senator reads the report of the Hancock Committee of Review on the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems which was tabled in this House yesterday he will see the contribution that both the workers and the ACTU have made to this country. It is just not right to criticise decent, honest Australian workers and their peak organisations for problems which have nothing to do with them, problems which this Government has responsibly tried to cure.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill implements two decisions of the Government which were announced a short time ago.
Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974

The first decision is that there will be no Commonwealth funding of any new or additional services provided in nursing homes to other than nursing home patients, where those services are not approved or approved-in-principle prior to 21 August 1985. Commonwealth funding for services which have been so approved before that date will be maintained, with adjustments for necessary cost increases.
At present, the Commonwealth funds a number of services which are provided in nursing homes, for both nursing home patients and aged or younger disabled persons in the surrounding community.

To date, the Government has considered it reasonable that the Commonwealth should fully meet the costs of these services. However, the direction of Commonwealth funding in this field is changing rapidly. Further decisions in this area will be announced at a later date.

It is expected that this measure will save $0.5m in the remainder of the 1985-86 financial year and $0.5m in the 1986-87 financial year, and that savings will accumulate at the rate of $0.5m in later years.
Social Security Act 1947
The second decision is to discontinue, as from 1 November 1985, the payment of family allowance in respect of student children who have attained the age of 18 years.
There will be some limited exceptions to the new rule. In general, these are designed to ensure that groups of people in needy circumstances will continue to receive family allowance.
This decision will enable scarce welfare funds to be directed to the many impoverished and needy members of our community.
It is expected that savings from this measure will be in the order of $20m in the remainder of the 1985-86 financial year and $30m in the 1986-87 financial year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Defence Re-establishment) Act 1965 to provide that no further loans or guarantees are to be granted under the Defence Re-establishment Loans Scheme in respect of applications received after 14 May 1985.

The Defence Re-establishment Loans Scheme was designed to assist eligible veterans to make the transition to civilian life by providing finance for them to establish business or agricultural ventures. Decisions by successive Governments not to increase the loan amounts have meant that the loans no longer provide a useful contribution to the cost of establishing a business or agricultural venture. The maximum value of the loans has not been increased since 1975. Budget restrictions will not permit increases in the loans.

The Scheme has been managerially inefficient because of legislative and public accountability requirements. The cost of administering the loans is high and in the financial year which ended on 30 June 1984, approached 20% of the value of the loans issued during that year.

The Re-establishment loan, at $10,000 for agricultural ventures and $5,000 for business ventures, is simply a cheap alternative source of a small part of the finance required to re-establish a serviceman or woman in civilian life. The Government believes this scheme is now out of date, because its objective as a re-establishment measure is not being met and it is inefficient to administer. This is reflected in the fact that only about 200 loans are approved each year.

Applications for loans and guarantees under the scheme, received on or before 14 May 1985 will be processed normally. Loans and guarantees which have been granted will not be disturbed by this amendment. 14 May 1985 was the date of the Government's statement of the intent to abolish Defence Re-establishment loans.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to certain savings proposals announced by the Treasurer on 14 May 1985 which affect the Repatriation pension system. The Bill now before the Senate makes amendments to the Repatriation Act 1920, the Interim Forces Benefits Act 1947, the Repatriation (Far East Strategic Reserve) Act 1956, the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962 and the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940.
Standard of Proof

As the Treasurer stated, the Government has recently reviewed the conditions applying to the grant of Repatriation pensions as part of its overall economic review of forward estimates of expenditure. In this review the Government paid particular attention to a recent decision of the High Court which involved an interpretation of the onus and standard of proof required under section 47 of the Repatriation Act 1920 to be applied by the Repatriation Commission when it determines a claim for a disability pension by a veteran or a claim for a war widow's pension in respect of a veteran's death.

Section 47 of the Repatriation Act, which was inserted in 1977, states that the Repatriation Commission must grant a claim for pension unless it is satisfied, beyond reasonable doubt, that there are insufficient grounds for granting the claim.

In February this year the High Court, by a majority of 3 to 2, gave its decision in the case of Repatriation Commission v O'Brien. In this decision, the High Court confirmed a view previously expressed by the Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia that section 47 of the Repatriation Act 1920 could require that a disability pension or war widow's pension be paid even in a case where there is no evidence which points to there being a reasonable possiblity of a connection between the veteran's incapacity or death and the veteran's war service. On this view, in order for a pension not to be granted it would appear that the Repatriation Commission would have to demonstrate conclusively that the cause of a veteran's incapacity or death was not contributed to in any way by anything related to the veteran's period of war service. Honourable Senators will appreciate that such an onus of disproof at the criminal standard is virtually impossible to satisfy in almost all cases, particularly where the origins and development of the disease that cause the veteran's death are not fully explainable by medical science.

Before the 1977 amendment, section 47 had required Repatriation determining authorities to give the claimant the benefit of any doubt as to the existence of any fact, matter, cause or circumstances which would be favourable to the claimant and as to any question which arose for decision under the claim. Determining authorities were also directed to draw from the evidence furnished to them, including medical opinions, all reasonable inferences in favour of the claimant. The legislation also stated that the onus of proof lay, not on the claimant, but on the person or authority contending that the claim should not be allowed.

While there was a good deal of confusion about the exact meaning of this ''benefit of doubt'' provision, it was understood that the ordinary civil standard was to be applied to the proving of material facts.

Mr Justice Toose, who conducted the Independent Inquiry into the Repatriation System, thoroughly examined the standard of proof issue. In his report in 1975 he said (at p. 254) ''I am of the view that matters, such as the criminal burden of proof beyond all reasonable doubt, do not arise in pension proceedings. 'Benefit of doubt' in the Repatriation legislation arises only in the matter of adjudicating if the determining authority is in doubt''. His Honour concluded that the provisions of the then section 47 had proved unsatisfactory and should be amended. His Honour then recommended (at p. 256) that ''the Act should provide that a determining authority, when considering the evidence, should draw all reasonable inferences in favour of the claimant and accept as proof any credible evidence of the claimant which is not contradicted. In weighing the evidence, if there is any doubt, that doubt should be resolved in favour of the claimant''.

When the Second Reading Speech to the 1977 amendments of the Repatriation Act is examined, it is clear that the then Government intended to clarify the meaning of section 47 consistent with the views expressed by Mr Justice Toose. There is no indication that the Government intended that section 47 be so substantially modified as to impose a standard of disproof at the criminal standard to the determination of Repatriation pension claims. It would seem that the Government of the day was intending to clarify that the 'benefit of any doubt' in section 47 meant the benefit of any reasonable doubt.

Since section 47 was amended in 1977 there has been a good deal of judicial consideration of the present standard of proof contained in section 47. In October 1981, in Repatriation Commission v Law, the High Court stated that the standard of proof in Repatriation pension matters required that ''in relation to any fact necessary to establish entitlement, the Review Tribunal must be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the fact does not, or did not, exist before it could refuse an application or dismiss an appeal by a claimant''. In 1982, in Lennel v Repatriation Commission, the Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia indicated that there was to be no automatic grant of pension when a veteran died of a disease, the cause of which was unknown. However, in 1984, in O'Brien v Repatriation Commission, the Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia said that, in order to satisfy the criminal burden of proof applied by the Act, the Commission would not necessarily satisfy the Tribunal beyond reasonable doubt that there are insufficient grounds for granting a claim even if there was no material which pointed to a connection between incapacity or death and war service. This view was confirmed by the majority decision of the High Court in O'Brien's case in February this year.

In his minority decision in that case, Mr Justice Brennan described the present section 47 as ''a piece of administrative legerdemain'', because it ensures that in the administration of the Act the prescribed conditions of eligibility should not be required but that claims be granted unless it appears beyond reasonable doubt that those criteria are not fulfilled. His Honour suggested that section 47 needed to be applied on the following basis: if the facts of a case supported a reasonable hypothesis of requisite connection between incapacity or death and war service then the Commission must grant the claim; if a reasonable hypothesis of entitlement arises on some of the facts then the Commission must grant the claim unless other facts dispel the hypothesis; if however, the Commission is satisfied that there is no reasonable hypothesis of entitlement on the known facts or that any such hypothesis contended is dispelled by other facts, then there are insufficient grounds for granting the claim.

I remind Honourable Senators that the Parliament legislated as recently as last year to set up a three-tiered determining system. This was hardly a sign that the Parliament believed that there was to be virtually automatic acceptance of disability and war widows' pension claims.

It has always been accepted that the Repatriation pension system should be generous. Nevertheless generosity seems to have gone beyond reasonable bounds in a situation where a pension must be granted in respect of a veteran's incapacity or death even if there is no evidence raising a reasonable possibility of a link between the incapacity or death claimed and the veteran's period of eligible war service. This in fact is the position because the effect of section 47, in the light of its interpretation by the Courts, is to bring the determination of disability pension claims close to one of automatic acceptance for the vast majority of claims. It is not surprising that claims for disability pension are pouring into the Department of Veterans' Affairs and that expenditure on disability pensions and war widows' pensions is increasing rapidly-by 55 per cent and 70 per cent respectively over the past three years.

The Bill I am now introducing draws on Mr Justice Brennan's proposition. It provides in respect of all claims for pension that where the Repatriation Commission is reasonably satisfied that the material before it does not raise a reasonable hypothesis of a connection between the death and incapacity of a veteran and the veteran's war service, or that any such hypothesis which has been raised, has been dispelled, a pension shall not be granted.

The requirement that there be established such a reasonable hypothesis of a war service connection is intended to ensure that a pension is not payable merely because there is a theoretical connection which is of a remote, fanciful or tenuous nature.
In addition, it is proposed to continue to apply the criminal standard of proof to claims for pension in respect of:
first, a disability where a veteran had overseas war service or where, during service in Australia in World War II, the veteran was personally engaged in direct combat against the enemy;
second, a disability where a veteran was allotted for operational service in Korea, Malaya/Borneo or Vietnam;

third, a disability suffered by a member of the Defence Force where he served on peacekeeping duties overseas or where the member is involved in hazardous duties so designated by the Minister for Defence; and
fourth, death for these three categories except where the veteran or member died or dies 40 years or more after eligible service.

In respect of claims in relation to the four categories I have just mentioned, I want to make it clear that a claim must be granted unless the determining authority is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that there are insufficient grounds for doing so. This is the standard of proof, subject to the proposed requirement that there be a reasonable hypothesis of a link between death or incapacity and service, that presently applies.

Apart from these types of claim for pension I have specified, all other pension matters arising for determination under the Repatriation legislation will be determined on the civil standard of proof in the ordinary way i.e. that the determining authority is not to grant a pension unless it is reasonably satisfied that there are sufficient grounds for doing so.

As far as the change in respect of a war widow's pension is concerned, Honourable Senators will accept that there are very few conditions which would take 40 years or more to manifest themselves. This is why it is proposed by the Bill that in cases of death more than 40 years after a veteran's war or other qualifying service, a claim for war widow's pension will be determined on the civil standard of proof as I have described it. At present it is not unusual for deaths of veterans aged over 80 to be accepted as war related in circumstances where common sense suggests that the ageing process or normal causes of death in the community were reasonable explanations.

The inequity of the law as it stands is evident if we consider two groups of widows. On the one hand are those widows whose husbands, on whom they were usually financially dependent, were killed during service or died as a direct result of injuries or disease suffered during war service. On the other hand there are widows receiving war widow's pensions who are not in financial need, whose veteran husbands had full working lives, were available for the period since war service to help with family responsibilities but whose deaths did not disclose evidence of a direct connection with war service.

In both cases, war widows' pensions are payable and precisely the same tax free and means-test free pensions and treatment entitlements apply, although it is often difficult to see any evidence linking the deaths of recently deceased veterans to their war service.
I emphasise that in future a war widow's pension will continue to be payable to a widow of a T &PI pensioner.
Assessment of the Rates of Disability Pension

The Bill, by amendments to the Schedules to the Repatriation Act 1920, proposes changes to clarify the circumstances in which disability pensions are to be paid at a rate higher than the general rate.

Since 1920, there has been a special rate of disability pension payable in circumstances where, because of total and permanent incapacity resulting from war service, a veteran has been unable to resume or to continue in civil employment. The Special or T&I rate pension was designed for severely disabled veterans of a relatively young age who could never go back to work and could never hope to support themselves or their families or put away money for their old age. It was never intended that the T&I rate would become payable to a veteran who, having enjoyed a full working life after war service, then retires from work possibly with whatever superannuation or other retirement benefits are available to the Australian workforce.

Determining authorities have found the application of the present legislative provisions difficult because the provisions, unchanged since 1920, contain outmoded and imprecise terms. The amendments clarify the eligibility criteria and make it clear that, to qualify for T&I pension, a veteran must be eligible for the 100% general rate pension. In addition, the T&I rate pension can become payable only when a veteran is totally and permanently disabled by accepted disabilities and is thereby precluded from continuing to engage in remunerative work. If a person has had the usual span of a working life or has retired voluntarily or has left employment for reasons other than accepted disabilities, a T&I pension is not payable. It would be in only very rare cases that any veteran beyond the normal retirement age could be eligible for this pension. Special provision is made by the Bill to cover veterans who are under 65 years of age, are unemployed, and are genuinely seeking to engage in remunerative work.

An intermediate rate pension may be payable where a veteran is prevented by accepted disabilities from engaging in other than part time or intermittent work. The Bill clarifies the test for this rate of pension in a similar way. Part time work is to be less than 20 hours work a week.
Dependant's Pension

The Bill also contains amendments to delete from future grants of disability pension the provision of separate nominal benefits to the wives and children of such pensioners. The rates of dependants' pensions have not changed for more than 20 years. Some entitlements are as low as 28 cents per fortnight and cost more to pay than the benefits themselves are worth.

It is also intended to delete some now outmoded provisions whereby small pensions are payable to those members of a deceased veteran's family, other than a wife or child, e.g. the parents or grandparents of an unmarried veteran. These people are now provided for in the general social security system.

It is proposed that no new grants of these dependants' benefits be made. Existing beneficiaries will have payments frozen at current levels. I emphasise that the dependants' pensions referred to in this context do not include war widows' pensions and orphans' pensions.
Savings Provisions

The modifications proposed to the application of section 47 and the criteria for the assessment of Intermediate and T&I rate pensions will apply to future determinations of pension claims and the assessment of pension increases. Pensions already granted will not be affected by these amendments. The amendments relating to Special Rate and dependants' pensions and to the O'Brien decision will apply as from the date of effect of this legislation.

Where the amendments relating to the application of the civil standard of proof are proposed to apply to claims for pension, they will apply to all such claims and applications for review lodged from 15 May.

Because of the backlogs in the determining system, it is most unlikely that any claims or applications for review lodged from tomorrow onwards will be determined before the amending legislation comes into effect. In any event claims and applications for review will be determined as closely as possible to the order of their lodgement in the Department.
Financial Impact

Since the High Court's decision in Law's case in October 1981 there has been a dramatic increase in the number of disability pension claims lodged which goes far beyond what might have been expected, even allowing for the ageing of the overall veteran population. In 1980-81, 22,000 claims for pensions and applications for increase were lodged. In 1984-85 there are likely to be 33,500 entitlement claims and 15,000 applications for increase in pension-a total for the year of 48,500. In short the number of claims will have increased by 120 per cent in four years. This increase is despite the fact that the number of surviving veterans will have decreased during the same period from 636,500 to about 560,000.

Acceptance rates have also increased dramatically. In 1981-82 the acceptance rate for pension claims at the first level was 50.9 per cent. The acceptance rate following the O'Brien decision is approaching 80 per cent and still rising. At the Veterans' Review Board, reviews of entitlement claims have an acceptance rate of 87 per cent. The acceptance of war widows' claims by the Veterans' Review Board is now close to 100 per cent.

The financial impact of this trend is enormous. Whereas in 1981-82 expenditure on disability pensions was $303m and on war widows' pensions $206m, the 1984-85 figures will be $469m and $350m-increases of 54.8 per cent and 70 per cent respectively.

In relation to T&I pensions, up to 1981-82 there was a steady decline in the number of pensioners. By early in 1982 there were 14,000. Since then there has been a continual growth in their numbers to the present figure of 21,800.

It is estimated that, if the trends in lodgement of claims and acceptance rates for disability and War Widows' pensions were to continue, expenditure in 1989-90 would be $650m a year higher than this year's expenditure.
Savings from the legislative amendments in this Bill are expected to be $36.8m in 1985-86 and substantially more in subsequent years.
Conclusion

Honourable Senators are aware of the Government's intention to rationalise and simplify Repatriation legislation through a new Veterans' Entitlement Bill. That Bill will be introduced later in these sittings but, so that Senators and ex-service organisations, in particular, may study its content, it will not be debated until the Budget Sittings. The changes announced in the Treasurer's statement need to be enacted as soon as possible through amendments to the existing Repatriation legislation. These amendments will be incorporated into the Veterans' Entitlements Bill at the earliest opportunity after passage of this Bill.

I repeat that in the determination of claims for disability and war widows' pension the legislation continues to protect the legitimate claims and rights of the veteran community. The Act will continue to provide that the requirement to submit evidence in support of a claim for pension shall not be taken to impose any onus of proof on a claimant. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will continue to have statutory responsibility for investigating relevant matters where a claim for pension is made. The Act will continue to provide that, in determining any claim, a determining authority is required to act according to substantial justice and the merits and all circumstances of a case. The Act will continue to take account of difficulties that lie in the way of ascertaining facts for any reason attributable to the effects of the passage of time, including on the availability of witnesses, or to any deficiency in official records.

Finally, let me reiterate the Government's commitment generally to the continuation of generous and effective benefits and treatment for those who suffer because of their war service for Australia. Australia has by far the most comprehensive and generous repatriation benefits in the world. After the Bill I have introduced becomes law this will still be the position but the savings achieved, in addition to helping to meet the objectives of the total savings package, will provide scope for future improvements in repatriation hospitals and in programs to care for our ageing veterans and war widows.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.
