DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY PRODUCE MARKET SUPPORT LEVY BILL 1985DAIRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985DAIRY PRODUCE MARKET SUPPORT BILL 1985DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Dairy Produce Market Support Levy Bill and related Bills which has just been resumed is on a package of dairy Bills-four all told-which have come to be known in common parlance as the Kerin plan for the dairy industry. I say at the outset that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is at least a Minister with whom one can debate matters. He is certainly a robust debater, but in such debates and negotiations one knows that one will not be subject to personal abuse and that indeed there is a possibility of discussing the issue, rather than discussing one's individual personal failings or otherwise, as is the case with the Minister who represents the Minister for Primary Industry in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to note very carefully one important matter in regard to the legislation before us and that is that it has been the result of a very long and difficult process of negotiation. The package, by and large, is accepted by the industry and I shall make some comments about that later in my speech. It has been accepted not without a great deal of heartache and difficulty in bringing together the various dairy industries throughout Australia. The industries in each State have different needs, different outlooks and different structures. The industry is to be commended for seeking to come up with a cohesive and coherent response to the legislation which is before us. It has done that by looking at four amendments. It should be noted that those amendments, unlike some of the comments made by Senator Cooney, do not go to the heart of the plan as it is set out. They go to the way that the plan is to be implemented. One item which changes the plan is the subject of the third amendment by the Opposition and it deals with the milk content. While it changes the plan in terms of the application of money, it is not essential to the plan itself. By choosing either the milk content or the f.o.b. price, one ensures that the plan essentially remains the same. I argue that the industry's position on that is more rational and coherent than the plan currently before us, and as I am given to understand that it is not even the Department's first choice anyway, it is an item that we could dispense with or move to alter as the industry has suggested.

This package of Bills will establish a new marketing arrangement for the Australian dairy industry. I would hope that we might be able to debate that without the type of intervention from Senator Walsh, his attempted blackmail and his suggestions that this chamber should not even be engaged in the process of legislation. We were told that to even suggest any amendments was tantamount to overstepping the mark. It is rather interesting to note that when Senator Walsh was in opposition and the Australian Democrats were working with him on various pieces of legislation he was quite happy to take a totally different viewpoint. Indeed, he voted with us to defeat a number of pieces of legislation which became the basis for the double dissolution in 1983. Then it was a different matter. Now that he is in government the whole situation seems to have changed. This is a pity and the types of remarks that he made do not contribute to reasonable debate in the primary industry area and certainly cannot form the basis for a reasonable coming together of minds. I believe that is still possible, provided Senator Walsh is not part of the discussion on these items. I believe that there is still time to come to an accommodation between the industry and this Government so that we can put in place by the end of this week a plan which, while it might not be all things to all people, at least is generally acceptable to both sides.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Serum Laboratories-Telecom-International Year of Peace-Taxation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 7 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to speak about the plight of the haemophiliac and the shortage of blood supplies available for the treatment of his condition. I use the masculine gender as haemophilia is a condition that afflicts only males. The haemophiliac receives his life-saving factor VIII blood products from the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission in Melbourne. Factor VIII is the best and safest treatment available for haemophiliacs. The supplies from CSL are of good quality and the breakthrough with heat-treated factor VIII was welcomed by the haemophiliac community. But the problem is that it is not being produced in sufficient quantity to ensure supplies to all haemophiliacs in all situations.

SPEECH.PARA: This shortage results in doctors having to compromise their treatment of haemophiliacs because they cannot often give them enough factor VIII, which, in turn, increases the length of recovery time for the patient and also hospital and medical costs. I believe that the production rate at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories is below the national production rates given by the World Health Authority. I also believe that presently a committee is looking into the CSL's methods of production and its efficiency, and it seems that there is general agreement that there is considered to be scope for improvement in the CSL's operations.

My concern is with the haemophiliac who cannot receive sufficient quantities of factor VIII for treatment. I am told that the shortage is more acute in New South Wales than Queensland, but at the moment in Queensland, if a haemophiliac were to be involved in a car accident, for example, and required emergency surgery, all the supplies of factor VIII available in the State at that particular time would be totally used on that one patient. That would throw the whole system into chaos. When a haemophiliac does not have sufficient supplies of the safe heat-treated factor VIII, he must revert to the less safe cryoprecipitate for treatment. The haemophiliac became the unfortunate innocent victim of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome epidemic when he was sent AIDS infected blood products last year.

The breakthrough with the safe heat-treated factor VIII was greeted with much delight. One can only feel for the haemophiliac who maybe has been tested positive and the haemophiliac who has escaped this fate so far being forced to inject himself with the not so safe product because not enough supplies of the safe product are being produced. The only safe AIDS-free product is factor VIII. To quote the Red Cross blood transfusion service:
There is a great difference in risk between the heat treated production and cryoprecipitate.

I ask the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) to imagine how hopeless and rejected haemophiliacs must feel when they cannot get supplies of factor VIII. Firstly, through no fault of their own, they may have to be given a life-saving blood product which may inject AIDS into their systems. They now have to live continually with the knowledge that they have a chance of falling victim to AIDS-a disease which has been described as incurable at the present stage of medical knowledge. Secondly, to compound this problem, they are being forced to inject themselves on many occasions with unsafe blood products. They are denied any choice of blood products. They are denied access to safer products. They are compelled to take the risky product. They feel that the authorities have discarded them. I do not wish to criticise the authorities concerned as they were not to know at the time that the blood they distributed was AIDS contaminated. But surely they do not have to aggravate the plight of positive-tested haemophiliacs by denying them, through shortages in production, the safer blood product for further use.

The advent of the AIDS virus in the community has no doubt put a lot of strain on the blood supply services. Donors have been hesitant to donate blood and the need to heat treat the blood destroys 15 per cent of the plasma, meaning that this shortfall has to be made up. However, I am concerned that the haemophiliac is becoming an innocent victim when he is prevented from receiving adequate supplies of life-saving factor VIII because the only source, CSL, is producing inadequate supplies. I would like the Federal Government to involve itself urgently and ensure that CSL lifts its production rate to a suitable level. The shortage may have come about because more donors are needed. The Federal Government could help by, for example, running a public education campaign which specifically allays the fears that are in the community about donating blood. As has often been suggested, more facilities are needed for handling donors at the various State levels. If this is so, Commonwealth assistance could help to provide these facilities. Finally, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories could lift their production rate to meet the World Health Organisation standards and to meet the need in the community for factor VIII. This may require more equipment or staff, but surely in an industrially advanced country such as Australia, with its high standard of living, a government facility which has vested in it the sole responsibility for the production of an important medical product must be continually monitoring whether it is meeting that need.

The supply of factor VIII for the treatment of haemophiliacs is not at a suitable level. I therefore ask the Federal Government to exercise its duty to ensure that the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories remedies the problems preventing it meeting the supply demand, at the earliest possible moment, so that adequate supplies of factor VIII are produced to enable the proper treatment of all haemophiliacs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday during the adjournment debate I brought to the attention of the Senate three examples which I thought were very good indications of inaction by government departments and which reflected very poorly upon the concept of open government much promulgated by this Government and the provision of basic information to members of this Parliament. In passing, I recall that on that occasion the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, undertook to look at the matters I had raised. I can assume only that the Minister is still looking or alternatively that he has had the misfortune to have sought advice from the departments concerned. Accordingly, he may be, as I am, still waiting for an answer.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening I again find it necessary to make reference to the Department of Foreign Affairs and its somewhat stunted sense of information distribution. However, before I touch on that matter-later I will also refer to the emerging saga of the International Year of Peace-I address a few remarks to that oft-maligned public authority, Telecom Australia and the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. In this case, I do not wish to add to the list of those who have had cause to direct many sharp barbs in the direction of Telecom. In this instance Telecom happens to be the innocent victim of the less than efficient performance of the Department of Administrative Services in certain areas. As honourable senators are only too well aware, the Department of Administrative Services has the responsibility of meeting the various needs of Federal parliamentarians. Despite the years-there would be many-of collective experience that the Department of Administrative Services could lay claim to in this area, I venture the opinion that there are significant areas, particularly in the area of parliamentary services, in which that Department demands improvement.

On 14 May, some five months after I became a senator, my office in Adelaide, having received numerous complaints from the public that we were difficult to contact by telephone, resolved to take up the matter with Telecom. I should mention at the outset that my Adelaide office has, since the time of my taking up office, been located in the Commonwealth Parliament Offices in the Commonwealth Bank building. The first course of action my office took was to ring directory assistance and put itself in the position of a member of the public wanting to get my telephone number. When my office spoke with Telecom's directory assistance service it was told that Telecom did not have a listing for Senator Vanstone. My office then spoke to a Telecom supervisor and was finally informed that Telecom had received advice from the Department of Administrative Services on 29 April 1985 that the Commonwealth Parliament Offices entry in the directory should be amended to include, amongst other names, my name. That, I am told, was the standard, six-monthly alteration to Telecom listings.

I do not think it is unreasonable to criticise the Department of Administrative Services for taking some four months to advise Telecom of a new senator's entry. I should add that I have spoken to the relevant managing officer and I am sure that he will attend to the matter promptly. I know him to be an efficient and sincere public servant. My point is that, given that Telecom is supplying my office with the right information, the public servants below the officer I spoke to are doing a number of things. Firstly, they are causing my office bother and concern. Secondly, they are hindering access by members of the South Australian community to one of their new senators for whom they are paying. Thirdly, they are letting down very badly the officer in charge of that section. Fourthly-perhaps this should have gone first-they are letting down their colleagues because they are adding fuel to the ever-growing anti-Public Service fire.

I turn now to the Department of Foreign Affairs. Last week I was critical of the delays in the provision of basic information about Australia's involvement in the International Year of Peace. Having now studied this much prepared reply from the Department, I could be forgiven for suspecting that the Department was, in the very first instance, less than enthusiastic to have a member of parliament gain any information about the International Year of Peace activities as planned by it.

In the letter from the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) the Department makes reference to a structure of national and State co-ordinating committees for the International Year of Peace. I thought it reasonable to ask who constitutes these committees, especially when we consider that some $3m has been allocated to the International Year of Peace program in Australia. Not wishing to experience yet another three months delay in requesting information from that Department, I took a chance and had my office telephone it and ask about the committees. At this stage I should say that on the telephone the relevant officer from the Department was most helpful and I thank him for his co-operation and assistance. It appears that neither national nor State committees have been formalised, but I do understand, if I may use the vernacular, that names are being thrown around for the national committee. I hope that this Government will invite public nominations for the national committee to ensure that a responsible and balanced management of the international year program develops. After all, this Government does a lot of singing and dancing about the need for public consultation.

In conclusion, I think membership of this national committee for the International Year of Peace should be drawn from a very wide section of the community and not simply appointed by the Government from the ranks of its own supporters and from fellow travellers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to speak briefly on the matter of the current debate going on within the Australian Labor Party, the coalition, the Government and the Australian community concerning the Australian taxation system. I wish briefly to talk about how a retail sales tax would affect the people of the outback. Listening to discussions these days, it is obvious that people are not considering how such a tax would affect the people in the outback, where freight costs are now extremely high. If we have a retail sales tax the cost of living in the outback will be increased. There has been a good deal of speculation about whether the Federal Government will opt for a broadly based consumption tax in the form of a retail sales tax in its proposed tax reforms. Although there is clearly a lot of disagreement within elements of the Federal Government and the wider community on the desirability of the introduction of such a tax one thing on which there can be no disagreement or doubt is that a retail sales tax would have a relatively heavier impact on people living in remote areas than it would have on people living in the more densely populated parts of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: People who live in the outback, including those living in the larger urban communities in the outback, such as Alice Springs and Darwin-I suppose, for that matter, we could include Katherine, Tennant Creek, Nhulunbuy and others-would have to pay proportionately even more than they do now for goods which are more expensive in these areas than they are in the southern States. While I talk of the main towns of the Northern Territory we must remember all of those very isolated Aboriginal settlements, and mining areas-the various places that are extremely remote and have, as I have said, a particularly heavy freight element in their cost of living.

The Northern Territory Government has approached me as it is not unnaturally concerned at the prospect of a retail sales tax. It has prepared a briefing note which details the implications of such a tax for the Northern Territory. It shows clearly that Territorians are already paying between 11 and 27 per cent more on average for basic food items than are their southern counterparts. It also shows that people in remote areas could find themselves paying retail sales tax at a rate 50 per cent higher than that paid by a person living in Sydney or Melbourne. Although I am talking about the Northern Territory, this situation applies in the rest of outback Australia. It applies to Western Australia-to the Kimberleys. It applies to the desert areas in northern South Australia, going up towards the border. It applies to the remote parts of western Queensland. In fact, a large number of people live in these areas and will be affected tremendously unless there is recognition of their plight if a retail sales tax comes about.

I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a briefing note prepared by the Northern Territory Government. I urge all members of the Government, and for that matter all members of parliament and other interested people, to take note of its conclusions and, in particular, its proposal that if a consumption tax is introduced taxation zone allowances be increased to a level commensurate with the incremental consumption tax paid by persons living in the more remote parts of the Commonwealth. I know that most members of the Parliament, and particularly senators, have visited the outback. I ask them to call to mind all of the small settlements which they have visited and the cost of items, particularly food items held in their little canteens and stores, and to note just how expensive they are now compared with those in the towns and cities. One must also consider the increase in fuel prices, of some 4c a litre, that occurred throughout Australia only some two or three weeks ago. The removal of some of the subsidy will also bring about an increased petrol price. This will initially increase freight costs, which will flow on to increase the cost of other articles. It frightens me to think of how some of these aboriginal and white families living in the outback will cope with the tremendous problem of ensuring that their families eat reasonably well. In fact a lot do not eat reasonably well now because already costs are so high.

If a retail sales tax is applied without proper consideration, all I can say is that a lot of people in the outback will be severely hurt by it. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who is the Minister in charge of the House at the moment, has consented to my incorporating in Hansard the briefing notes titled 'Implications for the N.T. of a Retail Sales Tax (RST)'. As I said before, this applies to people of the outback. I formally seek leave to have the briefing notes incorporated, as well as a spatial price index list which refers to remote communities and which is marked 'Attachment 1'.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
BRIEFING NOTE-IMPLICATIONS FOR THE N.T. OF A RETAIL SALES TAX (RST)

In the present debate in Australia on tax reform, the introduction of a consumption tax in the form of a retail sales tax (RST) covering almost all goods and services, has been widely advocated. This tax is seen by its supporters as a means of making possible substantial reductions in personal income tax.

Discussion on the equity implications of a RST has focused on its differing relative impact at different income levels. Scant attention has been given to the differing relative impact on persons living in different parts of the Commonwealth. In public finance terminology, the attention has been on vertical equity, but not also on horizontal equity.
A RST will have a relatively heavier impact on Territorians than on Australians as a whole because the general level of costs and prices is higher in the Territory than it is at the national level.

There is no comprehensive measure available of price differences by location in Australia. However, some indication of general price relativities can be obtained from the ''Experimental Index Numbers of Relative Retail Prices of Food'' produced by the ABS.

Taking the weighted average of food prices in the six State capitals as the base (index number=100), the ABS in its most recent compilation (May 1983) calculated the following index numbers for the main Territory centres:
Darwin 111 Alice Springs 117 Katherine 117 Tennant Creek 114 Nhulunbuy 127
This means, for example, that food prices in Darwin are 11% higher than the average for the State capital cities.
In Territory centres other than those listed above, the price differences are even greater.

The N.T. inquiry into freight and related costs produced index numbers showing the extent to which food prices are higher in the more remote communities of the Territory than they are in the main Territory centres.
Using Darwin or Alice Springs (as appropriate) as the base (index number=100), the inquiry compiled index numbers for selected communities (refer attachment 1).
The inquiry found that the cost of the selected ''basket'' of food items varied from 2% to 50% above the applicable Darwin or Alice Springs price.
From this it can be concluded that the average cost of food items in the remote communities of the Territory is roughly between 20% and 70% higher than in the State capital cities.
A RST has a compounding effect on the tax burden on persons living in remote areas, where costs and prices are inevitably higher.
This can be illustrated in the following hypothetical example:

In this example, a person living in Borroloola pays $14.80 in tax for purchasing the $100 item, whereas a person living in, say, Sydney or Melbourne, pays $10.00 for purchasing the same item. Thus, the Borroloola person has an effective tax rate of 14.8%, even though his nominal tax rate is 10%. In other words his RST rate is effectively about 50% higher than for a person living in Sydney or Melbourne.
Another way of assessing the higher relative impact of a RST on the Territory is to consider levels of overall consumption expenditure.

The '1984 survey of household expenditure, Australia', conducted by the ABS, showed that average weekly expenditure on goods and services by territory households was $446.88-27% higher than the corresponding national figure of $351.40 (it should be noted that this survey did not extend to remote areas, hence the territory figures are probably on the low side).
Whatever rate of RST is struck, the amount of RST paid by territory households will be of the order 27% higher, on average, than Australian households generally.

For example, if the rate of RST is 12.5% (as has been widely suggested) and the tax covers 90% of consumption expenditure (allowing for some exemptions), on the above figures the average territory household would be paying over $500 more per annum than the average Australian household.

The above analysis indicates that an across the board consumption tax in the form of a RST would be inequitable in that it would impose a heavier tax burden on Territorians and other persons living in remote areas of Australia, than on other Australians.

It would be impractical to compensate people exactly for the higher effective rates of consumption tax which occur at different localities in Australia. However, a mechanism does exist whereby reasonable redress could be obtained-namely, the taxation zone allowance arrangements.

In the event of a RST coming into existence, there is a strong case on equity grounds, for taxation zone allowances to be increased to a level commensurate with the incremental consumption tax paid by persons living in the more remote parts of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the matters that were raised tonight one by one, adequately or inadequately, seriatim, and all the other tautologies that we usually use in this place. First of all, Senator Boswell was concerned about the plight of haemophiliacs and the shortage of factor VIII, as he has obviously been informed, available to treat this condition. In his speech he seems to have laid a considerable amount of blame on the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories for its lack of production, for its inefficiency of production and, I think, for its lack of quality of production.
—No, I didn't say quality.

—I am sorry, I think there is a misconception here and I think I should clear it up. Factor VIII is produced by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories from plasma supplied to the Laboratories by the Red Cross blood transfusion unit. The amount of factor VIII which can be produced by CSL is limited by the amount and quality of plasma it gets. The issue has been complicated more recently by the problem of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, as Senator Boswell has said, because the heat treatment of the cryo-precipitate, which is the form of factor VIII that Senator Peter Baume and I used to use, reduces the effectiveness of it by about 15 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take up two points that Senator Boswell made during his speech. He said that he believed the production rate at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories is below the national production rates given by the World Health Organisation and that presently a committee is looking into the methods of production and efficiency of CSL. He said that it seems there is general agreement that there is scope for improvement in its operations. The first thing of which I inform Senator Boswell is that CSL's production yields of factor VIII are considerably higher than world standards and considerably higher than most standards in the northern hemisphere. It was the first laboratory outside the United States to produce in great scale the heat treated precipitate which almost entirely eliminates the possibility of the transmission of AIDS. Any suggestion that in this area of production CSL is less than world standard is quite untrue.

Secondly, there is no committee investigating the methods of production and the efficiency of CSL. I think there is general agreement amongst those who have the expertise to understand, and who knows the facts, that CSL performs remarkably well given the quality of the material supplied by the Red Cross. There is a problem with the supply of factor VIII but that problem is predominantly in New South Wales where, for the last six or seven years, the Red Cross blood transfusion service, which has a monopoly on blood collection in this country, has failed for all sorts of reasons-I dare say that the difficulty has increased in recent times-to provide sufficient plasma to the CSL for it to give adequate units of factor VIII to that State. The CSL produces factor VIII and distributes it throughout the country in proportion to the amount of serum it gets from each State. I have no knowledge that Queensland has been unable to produce adequate serum for this purpose. I know that there has been a problem in New South Wales for many years.

CSL produces quantities of factor VIII at levels which are determined by the haemophiliac therapy review group in Australia on which CSL has representatives, as have doctors who treat haemophilia. The last time I was able to find out, the only State in which production was inadequate was New South Wales. That was because of its failure to get sufficient of the base product. It is a matter of the Government urging CSL to produce sufficient factor VIII; CSL produces as much factor VIII as it can. We may have to increase the supply of base material, namely, plasma, but that is not the fault of CSL. Its production methods are very efficient. For some reason, in recent months, there has been an attack on CSL over its production of factor VIII. One attack was made in the New South Wales Parliament by a member who is of the same party as mine. He made a long and very detailed speech on the production of factor VIII. CSL replied in great detail and demonstrated that the assertions he made in the New South Wales Parliament were false. In fact, some of those assertions were the sorts of things that Senator Boswell said in the chamber tonight. I am not suggesting that Senator Boswell has made them up but someone with a vested interest may be providing information of this type, which is patently false, to members of parliament around the country in an effort to discredit CSL.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I want it recorded in Hansard that I in no way intended-
—There is no point of order if Senator Boswell merely wants something recorded in Hansard.

—Senator Boswell may not have intended to attack the efficiency of CSL but that is the gist of his claim that its production rate is lower than world standards and that a committee is looking into the production of factor VIII. There is no such committee. In this day and age, with the possibility of the transmission of AIDS, there is a very real problem for haemophiliacs. Some haemophiliacs have, unfortunately, contracted AIDS from blood transfusions in the past and particularly from the use of the cryo-precipitate which was used before we knew about the problem of AIDS. The cryo-precipitate can be treated and supplies of that are supposed to have gone back to CSL to be heat treated to get rid of the AIDS virus as far as possible. Haemophiliacs should not have to use the cryo-precipitate because no heat treated product is available. I do not know what the situation is in that regard in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: As for assisting people with haemophilia and increasing the collection of serum in these difficult times, as we all know, some people stopped giving blood because they thought, in some strange way, that that could cause a problem with AIDS. The Federal Government, in combination with the State governments, including the Queensland Government, has conducted a considerable campaign to assist through the supply of AIDS testing kits et cetera, not only those who are likely to get AIDS, but also by ensuring that blood, as much as is humanly possible these days, is tested for the possibility of its being contaminated with AIDS.

The Government has made grants for education, support and counselling services specifically for haemophilia and it has also supplied the money for the antibody testing of all haemophiliacs in Australia. There are about 1,500 haemophiliacs in Australia. They are spread quite widely through the community. It has not been possible for the Commonwealth to provide a counsellor for each haemophiliac but the Commonwealth has supplied funds. In conjunction with State health authorities it has provided counsellors. The positioning of those counsellors is the responsibility of the State governments. At the same time, the Red Cross has had a considerable advertising campaign to attract more donors, particularly, initially, female donors, so that it can ensure that its blood supplies are sufficient for the treatment of trauma and people having surgery and also for the treatment of haemophilia and the production of factor VIII. As I said earlier, In New South Wales that has been a problem but it has been a continuing problem for a long time.

The Government has also sent the President of the Australian Federation of Haemophilia to all States to help in the education campaign and to provide assistance for those with haemophilia. I suggest that if any haemophiliacs are feeling uncertain about what should be done they should contact their Federation and get the counselling that they need. I do not know the truth of the assertion that if one haemophiliac were involved in a car accident his treatment would wipe out the whole of the supply of factor VIII in Queensland. I can remember the days when Senator Baume and I used to treat haemophilia. That probably would have been the case then if we had had to treat victims of very severe accidents. At one stage I had under my care in hospital the two worst haemophiliacs in Australia. They had the lowest level of factor VIII. In exchange for samples of their blood, which the CSL used as a standard, I used to get more factor VIII, fortunately, than I was supposed to get. Those patients had a penchant for being involved in accidents. We would have to use fresh blood, as Senator Baume said. I would be surprised if there was inadequate factor VIII to cope with traumas like that, even in Queensland. I will refer Senator Boswell's speech to the CSL and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to get more detailed answers.

Senator Vanstone has experienced problems with the Department of Administrative Services. I have heard similar statements over the last 11 years. We have all been trying to do something about it, but have not succeeded. I will refer her concerns about the national committee on the International Year of Peace to Mr Hayden. I merely make the wry remark-if that is what it can be called-that it always interests me that people on the opposite side of the chamber, when they are in opposition, get up and thump the table and insist that the Government should appoint committees which are broad-based, not only with government supporters or Labor supporters; but when in government themselves they appoint committees which are hardly broad-based and composed of other than government supporters, except in a few token cases. One of those token cases is interesting. I remember that Sir Jack Egerton was kept on the Reserve Bank by the Liberal Government on the grounds that he was a Labor supporter.

Senator Kilgariff expressed concern about the effects of a broad-based consumption tax on people in the outback. I can assure Senator Kilgariff that before any such tax is introduced, all those factors he presented, and many others, will be taken into consideration, as I am sure they have been by those vigorous supporters of broad-based consumption tax in his own party. I am sure that such a change will not be made in this community without wide consultation, not only with members of parliament but with members of the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. I thank Senator Grimes for his very detailed and complete answers to the questions posed in my speech. I wish to have it recorded in Hansard that I in no way implied criticism of Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in my speech. If the Minister interpreted it that way, I apologise to CSL.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
